{"Status": "Complete", "Paper Overview": {"type_of_reference": "JOUR", "Title": "Galaxy cluster cores as seen with VLT/MUSE: New strong-lensing analyses of RX J2129.4 + 0009, MS 0451.6 - 0305, and MACS J2129.4 - 0741", "authors": ["Jauzac, Mathilde", "Klein, Baptiste", "Kneib, Jean-Paul", "Richard, Johan", "Rexroth, Markus", "Sch\u00e4fer, Christoph", "Verdier, Aur\u00e9lien"], "author_address": ["AA(Centre for Extragalactic Astronomy, Durham University, South Road, Durham DH1 3LE, UK; Institute for Computational Cosmology, Durham University, South Road, Durham DH1 3LE, UK; Astrophysics Research Centre, University of KwaZulu-Natal, Westville Campus, Durban 4041, South Africa; School of Mathematics, Statistics &amp; Computer Science, University of KwaZulu-Natal, Westville Campus, Durban 4041, South Africa; Institute of Physics, Laboratory of Astrophysics, Ecole Polytechnique F\u00e9d\u00e9rale de Lausanne (EPFL), Observatoire de Sauverny, CH-1290 Versoix, Switzerland), AB(Institute of Physics, Laboratory of Astrophysics, Ecole Polytechnique F\u00e9d\u00e9rale de Lausanne (EPFL), Observatoire de Sauverny, CH-1290 Versoix, Switzerland; Sub-department of Astrophysics, Department of Physics, University of Oxford, Oxford OX1 3RH, UK), AC(Institute of Physics, Laboratory of Astrophysics, Ecole Polytechnique F\u00e9d\u00e9rale de Lausanne (EPFL), Observatoire de Sauverny, CH-1290 Versoix, Switzerland; Aix Marseille Universit\u00e9, CNRS, LAM (Laboratoire d'Astrophysique de Marseille) UMR 7326, F-13388 Marseille, France), AD(Univ Lyon, Univ Lyon1, Ens de Lyon, CNRS, Centre de Recherche Astrophysique de Lyon UMR5574, F-69230 Saint-Genis-Laval, France), AE(Institute of Physics, Laboratory of Astrophysics, Ecole Polytechnique F\u00e9d\u00e9rale de Lausanne (EPFL), Observatoire de Sauverny, CH-1290 Versoix, Switzerland), AF(Institute of Physics, Laboratory of Astrophysics, Ecole Polytechnique F\u00e9d\u00e9rale de Lausanne (EPFL), Observatoire de Sauverny, CH-1290 Versoix, Switzerland), AG(Institute of Physics, Laboratory of Astrophysics, Ecole Polytechnique F\u00e9d\u00e9rale de Lausanne (EPFL), Observatoire de Sauverny, CH-1290 Versoix, Switzerland)"], "journal_name": "Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society", "volume": "508", "publication_year": "2021/11/1", "start_page": "1206", "end_page": "1226", "keywords": ["gravitational lensing: strong", "Techniques: imaging spectroscopy", "Galaxies: clusters: general", "Galaxies: clusters: individual (RX J2129.4 + 0009", "MS 0451.6 - 0305", "MACS J2129.4 - 0741)", "Astrophysics - Astrophysics of Galaxies", "Astrophysics - Cosmology and Nongalactic Astrophysics"], "url": "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2021MNRAS.508.1206J", "abstract": "We present strong-lensing analyses of three galaxy clusters, RX J2129.4 + 0009 (z = 0.235), MS 0451.6 - 0305 (z = 0.55), and MACS J2129.4 - 0741 (z = 0.589), using the powerful combination of Hubble Space Telescope (HST) multiband observations, and Multi-Unit Spectroscopic Explorer (MUSE) spectroscopy. In RX J2129, we newly spectroscopically confirm 15 cluster members. Our resulting mass model uses 8 multiple image systems as we include a galaxy-galaxy lensing system north-east of the cluster, and is composed of 71 haloes including one dark matter cluster-scale halo and two galaxy-scale haloes optimized individually. For MS 0451, we report the spectroscopic identification of two new systems of multiple images in the northern region and 112 cluster members. Our mass model uses 16 multiple image systems and 146 haloes, including 2 large-scale haloes and 7 galaxy-scale haloes independently optimized. For MACS J2129, we report the spectroscopic identification of one new multiple image system at z = 4.41, and newly measure spectroscopic redshifts for four cluster members. Our mass model uses 14 multiple image systems, and is composed of 151 haloes, including 2 large-scale haloes and 4 galaxy-scale haloes independently optimized. Our best models have rms of 0.29, 0.6, 0.74 arcsec in the image plane for RX J2129, MS 0451, and MACS J2129, respectively. This analysis presents a detailed comparison with the existing literature showing excellent agreements, and discuss specific studies of lensed galaxies, e.g. a group of submillimetre galaxies at z = 2.9 in MS 0451, and a bright z = 2.1472 red singly imaged galaxy in MACS J2129.", "doi": "10.1093/mnras/stab2270", "custom1": "eprint: arXiv:2006.10700", "issn": "0035-8711", "number": "1"}, "ADS link": "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2021MNRAS.508.1206J", "Publisher link via ADS gateway": "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/link_gateway/2021MNRAS.508.1206J/PUB_HTML", "Action": "Scanned and googletag.sizeMapping()\r\n                        .addSize([1024, 0], [[970, 90], [728, 90]])\r\n                        .addSize([768, 0], [728, 90])\r\n                        .addSize([0, 0], [320, 50])\r\n                        .build();\r\n                    gptAdSlots[\"ad1\"] = googletag.defineSlot('/116097782/mnras_Supplement_Ad1',\r\n                            [[970, 90], [728, 90], [320, 50]], 'adBlockHeader')\r\n                        .defineSizeMapping(mapping_ad1)\r\n                        .addService(googletag.pubads());\r\n                    \r\n\r\n                    \r\n                    var mapping_ad2 = googletag.sizeMapping()\r\n                        .addSize([768, 0], [[300, 250], [300, 600], [160, 600]])\r\n                        .build();\r\n                    gptAdSlots[\"ad2\"] = googletag.defineSlot('/116097782/mnras_Supplement_Ad2',\r\n                            [[300, 250], [160, 600], [300, 600]], 'adBlockMainBodyTop')\r\n                        .defineSizeMapping(mapping_ad2)\r\n                        .addService(googletag.pubads());\r\n                    \r\n\r\n                    \r\n                    var mapping_ad3 = googletag.sizeMapping()\r\n                        .addSize([768, 0], [[300, 250], [300, 600], [160, 600]])\r\n                        .build();\r\n                    gptAdSlots[\"ad3\"] = googletag.defineSlot('/116097782/mnras_Supplement_Ad3',\r\n                        [[300, 250], [160, 600], [300, 600]], 'adBlockMainBodyBottom')\r\n                        .defineSizeMapping(mapping_ad3)\r\n                        .addService(googletag.pubads());\r\n                    \r\n\r\n                    \r\n                var mapping_ad4 = googletag.sizeMapping()\r\n                        .addSize([0,0], [320, 50])\r\n                        .addSize([768, 0], [728, 90])\r\n                        .build();\r\n                    gptAdSlots[\"ad4\"] = googletag.defineSlot('/116097782/mnras_Supplement_Ad4',\r\n                        [728, 90], 'adBlockFooter')\r\n                        .defineSizeMapping(mapping_ad4)\r\n                        .addService(googletag.pubads());\r\n                    \r\n\r\n                googletag.pubads().addEventListener('slotRenderEnded', function (event) {\r\n                    if (!event.isEmpty) {\r\n                        $('.js-' + event.slot.getSlotElementId()).each(function () {\r\n                            if ($(this).find('iframe').length) {\r\n                                $(this).removeClass('hide');\r\n                            }\r\n                        });\r\n                    }\r\n                });\r\n\r\n                googletag.pubads().addEventListener('impressionViewable', function (event) {\r\n                    if (!event.isEmpty) {\r\n                        $('.js-' + event.slot.getSlotElementId()).each(function () {\r\n                            var $adblockDiv = $(this).find('.js-adblock');\r\n                            var $adText = $(this).find('.js-adblock-advertisement-text');\r\n                            if ($adblockDiv && $adblockDiv.is(':visible') && $adblockDiv.find('*').length > 1) {\r\n                                $adText.removeClass('hide');\r\n                            }\r\n                            else {\r\n                                $adText.addClass('hide');\r\n                            }\r\n                        });\r\n                    }\r\n                });\r\n\r\n                googletag.pubads().setTargeting(\"jnlspage\", \"article\");\r\n                googletag.pubads().setTargeting(\"jnlsurl\", \"mnras/article/508/1/1206/6350584\");\r\n                googletag.pubads().enableSingleRequest();\r\n                googletag.pubads().collapseEmptyDivs();\r\n            });\r\n        </script>\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n    \r\n    \r\n    \r\n        <script type=\"text/javascript\">\r\n   <div class=\"title-wrap\">\r\n                    <h1 class=\"wi-article-title article-title-main accessible-content-title at-articleTitle\">\r\n                        Galaxy cluster cores as seen with VLT/MUSE: New strong-lensing analyses of RX\u2009J2129.4\u00a0+\u00a00009, MS\u20090451.6\u00a0\u2212\u00a00305, and MACS\u2009J2129.4\u00a0\u2212\u00a00741\r\n<i class='' title='' ></i>                    </h1>\r\n\r\n                </div>\r\n                <div class=\"wi-authors at-ArticleAuthors\">\r\n                    <div class=\"al-authors-list\">\r\n Jauzac</a><span class='delimiter'>, </span>\r\n\r\n                                    <span class=\"al-author-info-wrap arrow-up\">\r\n<div class=\"info-card-author $(this).siblings('.ati-toggle-content').toggleClass('hide');\r\n        });\r\n\r\n        // In Chrome, an anchor tag with target=\"_blank\" and a \"mailto:\" href opens a new tab/window as well as the email client\r\n        // I suspect this behavior will be corrected in the future\r\n        // Remove the target=\"_blank\"\r\n        $('ul.wi-affiliationList').find('a[href^=\"mailto:\"]').each(function () {\r\n            $(this).removeAttr('target');\r\n        });\r\n    });\r\n</script>\r\n\r\n \r\n    </div>\r\n    <div id=\"MobileMicrositeSearchTerm\">\r\n\r\n                        <a href=\"javascript:;\" id=\"MobileMicrositeSearchIcon\" class=\"mobile-microsite-search-icon mobile-search-submit icon-menu_search\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search</span></a>\r\n\r\n                    </div>\r\n                </div>        </div>\r\n    </div>\r\n    \r\n    <div class=\"dropdown-panel mobile-account-dropdown\">\r\n        <ul class=\"site-menu site-menu-lvl-0\">\r\n            <li class=\"site-menu-item site-menu-lvl-0\">\r\n                <a href=\"\" class=\"nav-link mobile-account-signin js-nav-dropdown js-header-account-info-user-fullname\" id=\"header-account-info-user-fullname-mobile\">\r\n                    \r\nSign In                    <i class=\"mobile-nav-arrow icon-general_arrow-down\"></i>\r\n                </a>\r\n                <ul class=\"site-menu site-menu-lvl-1 individual-menu\">\r\n                    <li class=\"dropdown-signin-form\">\r\n                        <div class=\"spinner\"></div>\r\n                    </li>\r\n                </ul>\r\n            </li>\r\n                <li class=\"site-menu-item site-menu-lvl-0\">\r\n                        <a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"nav-link mobile-account-institution js-nav-dropdown\">\r\n                            University of Utah\r\n                        </a>\r\n\r\n                    <i class=\"mobile-nav-arrow icon-general_arrow-down\"></i>\r\n                    <ul class=\"site-menu site-menu-lvl-1\">\r\n                            <li class=\"dropdown-institution-item\">\r\n\r\nUniversity of Utah\r\n                            </li>\r\n\r\n                        <li class=\"dropdown-institution-signout\">\r\n                        </li>\r\n                    </ul>\r\n                </li>\r\n                            <li class=\"site-menu-item\">\r\n                    <a href=\"/my-account/register?siteId=5326&amp;returnUrl=%2fmnras%2farticle%2f508%2f1%2f1206%2f6350584\" class=\"register nav-link\">Register</a>\r\n                </li>\r\n        </ul>\r\n    </div>\r\n    \r\n    <div class=\"dropdown-panel mobile-nav-dropdown\">\r\n\r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n\r\n<div class=\"navbar\">\r\n    <div class=\"center-inner-row\">\r\n        <nav class=\"navbar-menu\">\r\n\r\n        </nav>\r\n            <div class=\"navbar-search-container js-navbar-search-container\">\r\n                <a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"navbar-search-close js_close-navsearch\">Close</a>\r\n                    <div class=\"navbar-search\">\r\n                        <div class=\"microsite-search\">\r\n                            <label for=\"navbar-search-filter\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search filter</label>\r\n                            <select class=\"navbar-search-filter at-navbar-search-filter\" id=\"navbar-search-filter\">\r\n                                                                    <optgroup label=\"Search within this journal\">\r\n                                                <option class=\"header-search-bar-filters-item\" value=\"Issue\" >This issue</option>\r\n                                                <option class=\"header-search-bar-filters-item\" value=\"\" selected=&quot;selected&quot;>All  Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society</option>\r\n\r\n                                    </optgroup>\r\n                                    <optgroup label=\"Search beyond this journal\">\r\n                                                <option class=\"header-search-bar-filters-item\" value=\"Parent\" >All  RAS Journals</option>\r\n                                                <option class=\"header-search-bar-filters-item\" value=\"Journals\" >All  Journals</option>\r\n                                    </optgroup>\r\n                            </select>\r\n\r\n                            <label for=\"MicrositeSearchTerm\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search input</label>\r\n                            <input class=\"navbar-search-input microsite-search-term at-microsite-search-term\" type=\"text\" maxlength=\"255\" id=\"MicrositeSearchTerm\" title=\"search input\">\r\n\r\n                            <a href=\"javascript:;\" id=\"MicrositeSearchIcon\" class=\"microsite-search-icon navbar-search-submit icon-menu_search\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search</span></a>\r\n\r\n                        </div>\r\n                    </div>                <div class=\"navbar-search-advanced\"><a href=\"/mnras/advanced-search\" class=\"advanced-search js-advanced-search\">Advanced Search</a></div>\r\n            </div>            <div class=\"navbar-search-collapsed\"><a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"icon-menu_search js_expand-navsearch\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search Menu</span></a></div>\r\n    </div>\r\n</div>\r\n<input id=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" name=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"False\" />\r\n\r\n<input id=\"routename\" name=\"RouteName\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"mnras\" /> \r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n                    </div>\r\n                </div>\r\n            </div>\r\n            <div id=\"ContentTab\" class=\"content active\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleFulltext widget-instance-OUP_Article_FullText_Widget\">\r\n        <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\" data-widgetname=\"ArticleFulltext\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                    <h2 scrollto-destination=304594307 id=\"304594307\" class=\"abstract-title js-splitscreen-abstract-title\" >ABSTRACT</h2>\r\n<section class=\"abstract\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">We present strong-lensing analyses of three galaxy clusters, RX\u2009J2129.4\u00a0+\u00a00009 (<em>z</em> = 0.235), MS\u20090451.6\u00a0\u2212\u00a00305 (<em>z</em> = 0.55), and MACS\u2009J2129.4\u00a0\u2212\u00a00741 (<em>z</em> = 0.589), using the powerful combination of <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> (<em>HST</em>) multiband observations, and Multi-Unit Spectroscopic Explorer (MUSE) spectroscopy. In RX\u2009J2129, we newly spectroscopically confirm 15 cluster members. Our resulting mass model uses 8 multiple image systems as we include a galaxy\u2013galaxy lensing system north-east of the cluster, and is composed of 71 haloes including one dark matter cluster-scale halo and two galaxy-scale haloes optimized individually. For MS\u20090451, we report the spectroscopic identification of two new systems of multiple images in the northern region and 112 cluster members. Our mass model uses 16 multiple image systems and 146 haloes, including 2 large-scale haloes and 7 galaxy-scale haloes independently optimized. For MACS\u2009J2129, we report the spectroscopic identification of one new multiple image system at <em>z</em> = 4.41, and newly measure spectroscopic redshifts for four cluster members. Our mass model uses 14 multiple image systems, and is composed of 151 haloes, including 2 large-scale haloes and 4 galaxy-scale haloes independently optimized. Our best models have rms of 0.29, 0.6, 0.74\u00a0arcsec in the image plane for RX\u2009J2129, MS\u20090451, and MACS\u2009J2129, respectively. This analysis presents a detailed comparison with the existing literature showing excellent agreements, and discuss specific studies of lensed galaxies, e.g. a group of submillimetre galaxies at <em>z</em> = 2.9 in MS\u20090451, and a bright <em>z</em> = 2.1472 red singly imaged galaxy in MACS\u2009J2129.</p></section>                        <div class=\"article-metadata-panel clearfix at-ArticleMetadata\"></div>\r\n<div class=\"kwd-group\"><a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;gravitational lensing: strong&quot;\">gravitational lensing: strong</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;Techniques: imaging spectroscopy&quot;\">Techniques: imaging spectroscopy</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;Galaxies: clusters: general&quot;\">Galaxies: clusters: general</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;Galaxies: clusters: individual (RX\u2009J2129.4\u00a0+\u00a00009, MS\u20090451.6\u00a0\u2212\u00a00305, MACS\u2009J2129.4\u00a0\u2212\u00a00741)&quot;\">Galaxies: clusters: individual (RX\u2009J2129.4\u00a0+\u00a00009, MS\u20090451.6\u00a0\u2212\u00a00305, MACS\u2009J2129.4\u00a0\u2212\u00a00741)</a></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=304594309 id=\"304594309\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec1>1 INTRODUCTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Clusters of galaxies are the most spectacular strong lenses in the Universe. Due to the high-mass density in their cores, it is not uncommon to observe giant arcs and multiple images of sources located behind them. This gravitational lensing effect distorts, and magnifies the light emitted by background galaxies, transforming these clusters into cosmic telescopes (for a review, see e.g. Massey, Kitching &amp; Richard <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib70\" data-open=\"bib70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Kneib &amp; Natarajan <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Hoekstra et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Treu &amp; Ellis <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib96\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib96\" data-open=\"bib96\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Kilbinger <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Bartelmann &amp; Maturi <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). Such strong-lensing features are extremely useful to map the total mass distribution within the central regions of clusters (e.g. Richard et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib84\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib84\" data-open=\"bib84\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Jauzac et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib41\" data-open=\"bib41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Johnson et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Coe, Bradley &amp; Zitrin <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Caminha et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017b</a>; Williams et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib101\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib101\" data-open=\"bib101\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Diego et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib25\" data-open=\"bib25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Mahler et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib67\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib67\" data-open=\"bib67\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Lagattuta et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>; Sharon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib90\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib90\" data-open=\"bib90\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>). These mass models can then be used to constrain the physics of Dark Matter, such as its self-interaction cross-section (see Harvey et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Wittman, Golovich &amp; Dawson <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib102\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib102\" data-open=\"bib102\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), or test the cosmological paradigm (e.g. Jullo et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib52\" data-open=\"bib52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010a</a>; Acebron et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1\" data-open=\"bib1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Natarajan et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib74\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib74\" data-open=\"bib74\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Jauzac et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), but also to probe the early Universe and thus the epoch of reionization (e.g. Atek et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2\" data-open=\"bib2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Bouwens et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Livermore, Finkelstein &amp; Lotz <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib64\" data-open=\"bib64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Atek et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Ishigaki et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). Hence, the need to have accurate and precise mass models for a large number of galaxy clusters.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Over the past two decades, the precision of strong-lensing mass modeling of galaxy clusters has dramatically increased. This is mainly due to the combination of powerful post-processing algorithms and high resolution imaging. On the one hand, the use of the Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) sampling of the parameter space in the Bayesian framework allowed for robust estimations of the most likely mass models for a given set of constraints (e.g. our team uses <span class=\"small-caps\">Lenstool</span> which is presented in Kneib et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib57\" data-open=\"bib57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>; Jullo et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010b</a>; Niemiec et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib77\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib77\" data-open=\"bib77\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>). On the other hand, the quality of observations with the <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> (<em>HST</em>) provided astronomers with the deepest and highest resolution images of strong-lensing clusters (e.g. Postman et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib79\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib79\" data-open=\"bib79\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Schmidt et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib89\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib89\" data-open=\"bib89\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Treu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib97\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib97\" data-open=\"bib97\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Lotz et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib65\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib65\" data-open=\"bib65\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Steinhardt et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib92\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib92\" data-open=\"bib92\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>, see also the webpages of <em>Hubble</em> Frontier Fields,<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn1\" data-open=\"fn1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">1</a></sup> GLASS,<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn2\" data-open=\"fn2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">2</a></sup> RELICS<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn3\" data-open=\"fn3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">3</a></sup>, and BUFFALO<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn4\" data-open=\"fn4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">4</a></sup> surveys). This resulted in mass models with an unrivalled precision for numerous galaxy clusters (e.g. Zitrin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib104\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib104\" data-open=\"bib104\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011b</a>; Richard et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib84\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib84\" data-open=\"bib84\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Johnson et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Jauzac et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Diego et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). High-resolution imaging allows precise measurements of the location of multiple images. However, if their exact distance, i.e. their redshift, is not measured, then mass models are highly degenerate, and the resulting mass distribution is biased, hence the strong need for measurements of spectroscopic redshifts (\u0394<em>z</em> &lt; 0.01, see Lagattuta et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib59\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib59\" data-open=\"bib59\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Richard et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib85\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib85\" data-open=\"bib85\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Grillo et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Jauzac et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016a</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>; Mahler et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib67\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib67\" data-open=\"bib67\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib68\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib68\" data-open=\"bib68\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>; Lagattuta et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>; Remolina Gonz\u00e1lez, Sharon &amp; Mahler <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib80\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib80\" data-open=\"bib80\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). As shown in Johnson &amp; Sharon (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>), Cerny et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), and Remolina Gonz\u00e1lez et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib80\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib80\" data-open=\"bib80\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), the spectroscopic redshift information is mandatory in order to obtain precise strong-lensing mass models.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The Multi-Unit Spectroscopic Explorer (MUSE; Bacon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib4\" data-open=\"bib4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) is a second-generation integral field spectrograph at the Very Large Telescope (VLT). MUSE large field of view of 1\u2009arcmin<sup>2</sup> is perfectly adapted to the observation of the core of galaxy clusters (Richard et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib85\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib85\" data-open=\"bib85\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib86\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib86\" data-open=\"bib86\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2021</a>; Grillo et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Caminha et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017a</a>,<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">b</a>; Chiriv\u00ec et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Rescigno et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib81\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib81\" data-open=\"bib81\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>), where most multiple images are likely to be observed (e.g. Kneib &amp; Natarajan <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>). Its high sensitivity between 4750\u2009\u00c5 and 9350\u2009\u00c5 enables the detection of sources with redshifts up to <em>z</em> = 6 (Bacon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). Over the past 6\u00a0years, strong cluster lenses have been commonly observed with MUSE, leading to the measurement of spectroscopic redshifts for multiple images, their multiplicity confirmation, as well as the identification of new multiple image systems which are not even detected in <em>HST</em> observations (e.g. Richard et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib85\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib85\" data-open=\"bib85\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Jauzac et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016a</a>; Caminha et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017a</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>; Lagattuta et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In this paper, we present MUSE observations, and their subsequent strong-lensing analyses, for three well-known galaxy clusters: RX\u2009J2129.4\u00a0+\u00a00009, MS\u20090451.6\u00a0\u2212\u00a00305, and MACS\u2009J2129.4\u00a0\u2212\u00a00741. These clusters have been observed with <em>HST</em>, and already have strong-lensing mass models published in the literature (more details are given bellow, but e.g. Richard et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib83\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib83\" data-open=\"bib83\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Zitrin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib104\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib104\" data-open=\"bib104\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011b</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib105\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib105\" data-open=\"bib105\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; MacKenzie et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Monna et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Caminha et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>) which are used as references in this analysis, and referred to as <em>fiducial models</em> in the rest of the paper).</p><ul class=\"roman-lower\"><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">RX\u2009J2129.4 + 0009 (<em>z</em> = 0.235, RX\u2009J2129 hereafter) was observed as part of the CLASH survey, and was first modelled with <span class=\"small-caps\">Lenstool</span> for the Local Cluster Substructure Survey (LoCuSS, PI: G. P. Smith, see Richard et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib83\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib83\" data-open=\"bib83\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>). This model relied on a single system of multiple images which redshift was updated by Belli et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). Then, Zitrin et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib105\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib105\" data-open=\"bib105\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) published a model which uses four multiple image systems, two being spectroscopically confirmed. Desprez et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) presented a revised model, including one galaxy\u2013galaxy lensing system located \u223c80\u00a0arcsec from the cluster centre, in the vicinity of an isolated cluster galaxy. Finally, Caminha et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>) presented a strong-lensing mass model which takes advantage of the MUSE observations presented in this paper.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">MS\u20090451.6\u00a0\u2212\u00a00305 (<em>z</em> = 0.55 \u2212 MS\u20090451 hereafter) is originally known for its large brightness in the X-rays (e.g. Ellingson et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>; Molnar et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib71\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib71\" data-open=\"bib71\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>; LaRoque et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib61\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib61\" data-open=\"bib61\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>; Gioia et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1990</a>; Donahue et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>; Geach et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>), and hosts several strongly lensed submillimetric sources with radio counterparts (e.g. Takata et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib93\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib93\" data-open=\"bib93\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>; Borys et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>; Berciano Alba et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib11\" data-open=\"bib11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; MacKenzie et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). Increasingly precise strong-lensing mass models were obtained by Borys et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>), Berciano Alba et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>), Zitrin et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib104\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib104\" data-open=\"bib104\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011b</a>), and most recently by MacKenzie et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>), where they included sub-millimetre detections. The latter relies on 8 multiple image systems located in the south of the cluster, leaving the north poorly constrained. However, more recent imaging with <em>HST</em>, and spectroscopy with VLT/X-Shooter and Keck/LRIS, allowed the identification of 8 new multiple image systems, including a quintuple image at redshift <em>z</em> = 6.7 in the north (Knudsen et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Richard et\u00a0al. in preparation). The giant arc identified in Borys et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>), and the system at redshift <em>z</em> = 6.7, are the only multiple image systems with confirmed spectroscopic redshifts.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">MACS\u2009J2129.4\u00a0\u2212\u00a00741 (<em>z</em> = 0.589 \u2212 MACS\u2009J2129 hereafter; Ebeling et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib27\" data-open=\"bib27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>) is part of the Cluster Lensing And Supernova survey with <em>Hubble</em> (CLASH; Postman et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib79\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib79\" data-open=\"bib79\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). It was modelled by Zitrin et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib103\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib103\" data-open=\"bib103\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011a</a>) and more recently by Monna et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) using CLASH photometry (Zitrin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib105\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib105\" data-open=\"bib105\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>), and VLT-VIMOS spectroscopic data (Rosati et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib88\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib88\" data-open=\"bib88\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). Among the 9 multiple image systems used in the mass model presented by Monna et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), two systems are not spectroscopically confirmed. Then, Caminha et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>) presented a strong-lensing model using <span class=\"small-caps\">Lenstool</span>, which takes advantage of the MUSE observations presented in this work.</p></li></ul><p class=\"chapter-para\">This paper is organized as follows. Section \u2009<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">2</a> presents the details of the pipeline used to extract the spectra from the MUSE datacubes. Section\u2009 <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2-4\"></span><a href=\"#sec2-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">2.4</a> describes redshift measurements, and presents our results for the three galaxy clusters. Section\u2009<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">3</a> details the strong-lensing mass models of RX\u2009J2129, MS\u20090451, and MACS\u2009J2129. Section\u2009<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4</a> presents our results and discusses them with regards to previous strong-lensing analyses of these clusters. We finally conclude in Section\u2009<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5</a>. Throughout the paper, we assume a standard cosmological model with \u03a9<sub><em>M</em></sub> = 0.3, \u03a9<sub>\u039b</sub> = 0.7, and <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> = 70\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u2009Mpc<sup>\u22121</sup>. At the redshift of RX\u2009J2129 (<em>z</em> = 0.235), 1\u00a0arcsec covers a physical distance of 3.3734\u2009kpc. At the redshift of MS\u20090451 (<em>z</em> = 0.55), 1\u00a0arcsec covers a physical distance of 6.412\u2009kpc. Finally, for MACS\u2009J2129 (<em>z</em> = 0.589), 1\u00a0arcsec corresponds to 6.63\u2009kpc. All magnitudes are measured using AB system.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=304594316 id=\"304594316\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2>2 MUSE OBSERVATIONS AND ANALYSIS</h2>\r\n                    <h3 scrollto-destination=304594317 id=\"304594317\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-1>2.1 Observations and data reduction</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">RX\u2009J2129, MS\u20090451, and MACS\u2009J2129 were observed with MUSE on the VLT. Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> gives the details of the observations, including dates, pointing positions, ID, seeing conditions, and total exposure time for each data set. Observations were taken using MUSE WFM-NOAO-N mode, in good seeing conditions with full width at half maximum (FWHM) of \u2248\u20090.5, 0.8, and 0.9\u00a0arcsec for RX\u2009J2129, MS\u20090451, and MACS\u2009J2129, respectively. At each pointing, three exposures were taken, slightly shifted (by \u223c0.5\u00a0arcsec) in order to mitigate systematics from the image slicer and detectors.</p>                        <a id=\"304594319\" scrollto-destination=\"304594319\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl1\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl1\" data-id=\"tbl1\"><span class=\"label\">Table 1.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Summary of MUSE observations for all three clusters. Columns\u00a01\u20133 indicate, respectively, the name of the cluster, its average redshift, and the ID of the ESO programme (PI: Kneib for all observations). For each pointing, we give the observation date in column\u00a04, the total exposure time in column\u00a05, the right ascension (R\u2009A), and declination (Decl.) of the centre of the field of view in columns\u00a06 and\u00a07, and the FWHM of the seeing during the observations in column\u00a08.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Cluster<span aria-hidden=\"true\" aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Observation date<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Exposure time<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>R\u2009A<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Decl.<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Seeing<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>(s)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>[J2000]<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>[J2000]<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>(arcsec)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>RX\u2009J2129\u00a0</td><td>0.235\u00a0</td><td>097.A-0909(A)\u00a0</td><td>2016-08-05\u00a0</td><td>8940\u00a0</td><td>322.42149\u00a0</td><td>0.09310\u00a0</td><td>0.5\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>2016-09-04\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>322.41189\u00a0</td><td>0.08682\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>MS\u20090451\u00a0</td><td>0.55\u00a0</td><td>096.A-0105(A)\u00a0</td><td>2016-01-10\u00a0</td><td>8682\u00a0</td><td>73.55165\u00a0</td><td>\u22123.01837\u00a0</td><td>0.8\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>2016-01-11\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>73.54106\u00a0</td><td>\u22123.00965\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>MACS\u2009J2129\u00a0</td><td>0.589\u00a0</td><td>095.A-0525(A)\u00a0</td><td>2015-06-17\u00a0</td><td>8772\u00a0</td><td>322.36602\u00a0</td><td>\u22127.69040\u00a0</td><td>0.9\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>322.35192\u00a0</td><td>\u22127.69040\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>Cluster<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>z</em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>ESO programme<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Observation date<span aria-hidden=\"true\" aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr><tr><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>(s)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>[J2000]<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>[J2000]<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>(arcsec)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>RX\u2009J2129\u00a0</td><td>0.235\u00a0</td><td>097.A-0909(A)\u00a0</td><td>2016-08-05\u00a0</td><td>8940\u00a0</td><td>322.42149\u00a0</td><td>0.09310\u00a0</td><td>0.5\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>2016-09-04\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>322.41189\u00a0</td><td>0.08682\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>MS\u20090451\u00a0</td><td>0.55\u00a0</td><td>096.A-0105(A)\u00a0</td><td>2016-01-10\u00a0</td><td>8682\u00a0</td><td>73.55165\u00a0</td><td>\u22123.01837\u00a0</td><td>0.8\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>2016-01-11\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>73.54106\u00a0</td><td>\u22123.00965\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>MACS\u2009J2129\u00a0</td><td>0.589\u00a0</td><td>095.A-0525(A)\u00a0</td><td>2015-06-17\u00a0</td><td>8772\u00a0</td><td>322.36602\u00a0</td><td>\u22127.69040\u00a0</td><td>0.9\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>322.35192\u00a0</td><td>\u22127.69040\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl1\" data-id=\"tbl1\"><span class=\"label\">Table 1.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Summary of MUSE observations for all three clusters. Columns\u00a01\u20133 indicate, respectively, the name of the cluster, its average redshift, and the ID of the ESO programme (PI: Kneib for all observations). For each pointing, we give the observation date in column\u00a04, the total exposure time in column\u00a05, the right ascension (R\u2009A), and declination (Decl.) of the centre of the field of view class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>Cluster<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>z</em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>ESO programme<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Observation date<span aria-hidden=\"true\" aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Decl.<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Seeing<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr><tr><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>(s)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>[J2000]<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>[J2000]<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>(arcsec)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>RX\u2009J2129\u00a0</td><td>0.235\u00a0</td><td>097.A-0909(A)\u00a0</td><td>2016-08-05\u00a0</td><td>8940\u00a0</td><td>322.42149\u00a0</td><td>0.09310\u00a0</td><td>0.5\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>2016-09-04\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>322.41189\u00a0</td><td>0.08682\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>MS\u20090451\u00a0</td><td>0.55\u00a0</td><td>096.A-0105(A)\u00a0</td><td>2016-01-10\u00a0</td><td>8682\u00a0</td><td>73.55165\u00a0</td><td>\u22123.01837\u00a0</td><td>0.8\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>2016-01-11\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>73.54106\u00a0</td><td>\u22123.00965\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>MACS\u2009J2129\u00a0</td><td>0.589\u00a0</td><td>095.A-0525(A)\u00a0</td><td>2015-06-17\u00a0</td><td>8772\u00a0</td><td>322.36602\u00a0</td><td>\u22127.69040\u00a0</td><td>0.9\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>322.35192\u00a0</td><td>\u22127.69040\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/304594319\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The data were reduced with version 1.6.4 of the standard MUSE pipeline (Weilbacher et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib100\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib100\" data-open=\"bib100\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib99\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib99\" data-open=\"bib99\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>). We use a set of standard calibration exposures taken daily to produce bias, arcs, and flat-field master calibration files. Dark current is neglected due to its very low value with MUSE (\u22481\u2009electron\u00a0h<sup>\u22121</sup>; Bacon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). We first subtract the master bias exposures from each data set, and perform an illumination correction using in combination the master flat-field, the twilight sky exposures taken at the beginning of the night, and the illumination calibration taken soon before/after the science observations. We carry out wavelength, geometrical and astrometric calibrations in order to assign the World Coordinate System (WCS) right ascension and declination, and the wavelength to each pixel of the datacube. The flux calibration is carried out using standard star observations taken at the beginning of the observing night. For each pointing, the three individual exposures are then combined into a full datacube using a single interpolation step.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We apply the <span class=\"small-caps\">Z\u00fcrich Atmosphere Purge</span> (<span class=\"small-caps\">zap</span>; Soto et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib91\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib91\" data-open=\"bib91\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) software version 1.0, which uses a principal components analysis to analyse objects-free regions in the datacube and subtract systematics due to sky subtraction residuals. To create the <span class=\"small-caps\">zap</span> objects mask, we use the segmentation map obtained by applying the <span class=\"small-caps\">Sextractor</span> software (Bertin &amp; Arnouts <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib12\" data-open=\"bib12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>) on a white-light image collapsing the datacube along its wavelength axis.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The wavelength range of the final datacube stretches from 4750 to 9350\u2009\u00c5 in steps of 1.25\u2009\u00c5, and the spaxel size is 0.2\u00a0arcsec.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=304594323 id=\"304594323\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-2>2.2 Spectrum extraction</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We combine MUSE observations with high-resolution images from <em>HST</em> to detect small and faint sources that remain invisible in the image obtained when the MUSE datacube is collapsed along the wavelength axis. This combination was notably used by Bacon et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) for the analysis of MUSE observations of the <em>Hubble</em> Deep Field South.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">For MACS\u2009J2129 and RX\u2009J2129, we use <em>HST</em> data obtained with the <em>Advanced Camera for Surveys</em> (ACS; Ford et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>) as part of the CLASH survey in the F475W, F625W, and F814W pass-bands. We also use imaging by the <em>Wide Field Camera 3</em> (WFC3) in the F110W and F160W pass-bands to cover a larger wavelength range for the source identification. For MS\u20090451, we use the <em>HST</em> data available in the MAST website.<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn5\" data-open=\"fn5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">5</a></sup> We present in Tables\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>\u2013<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>, a summary of the <em>HST</em> observations used for this work for RX\u2009J2129, MS\u20090451, and MACS\u2009J2129, respectively, including the observation ID, the PI, the exposure time, and the observational date. For all three clusters, we applied standard data-reduction procedures. We used <em>HST</em><span class=\"small-caps\">cal</span> and the most recent calibration files. The co-addition of individual frames was done using <span class=\"small-caps\">Astrodrizzle</span> after registration to a common reference image using <span class=\"small-caps\">Tweakreg</span>. After an iterative process, we achieve an alignment accuracy of 0.1\u2009pixel. Our final stacked images have a pixel size of 0.03\u00a0arcsec.</p>                        <a id=\"304594326\" scrollto-destination=\"304594326\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl2\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl2\" data-id=\"tbl2\"><span class=\"label\">Table 2.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Summary of the <em>HST</em> observations used in this analysis to carry out the source identifications for RX\u2009J2129. In the context of the CLASH survey (Proposal ID 12457), observations in the UV were also carried but we do not list them as they are not used in this analysis.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Band<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>PID<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/304594328\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We use the <span class=\"small-caps\">ifs-redex</span> software to align the datacubes with the corresponding <em>HST</em> high-resolution images (Rexroth et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib82\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib82\" data-open=\"bib82\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). We then run <span class=\"small-caps\">SExtractor</span> on the <em>HST/ACS</em> F814W pass-band image for each cluster to automatically measure the position and FWHM of the sources in the MUSE field of view. <span class=\"small-caps\">ifs-redex</span> uses the catalogue of detected sources to extract the signal in the datacube within a circle of radius 3\u20135\u2009pixels according to the FWHM measurement. Sources with FWHM &lt; 2\u2009pixels are considered spurious detections, and are rejected.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In order to maximize the number of extracted spectra, we carry out a blind search in the datacube using <span class=\"small-caps\">muselet</span>.<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn6\" data-open=\"fn6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">6</a></sup> This software is part of the MUSE <span class=\"small-caps\">Python Data Analysis Framework</span> (<span class=\"small-caps\">mpdaf</span>; Bacon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). It builds a new datacube, the narrow-band datacube, within which each wavelength plane is the mean of the 5 closest wavelength planes in the science datacube. <span class=\"small-caps\">muselet</span> then uses <span class=\"small-caps\">SExtractor</span> to extract a catalogue of sources at each wavelength in the narrow-band datacube. The latter are finally merged and sorted, providing a continuum and a single line emission catalogues.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Finally, all catalogues are merged to provide a master catalogue, which is then displayed on the high resolution image so that the user can determine whether <span class=\"small-caps\">muselet</span> and <span class=\"small-caps\">SExtractor</span> detections are matching the same source. This results in a set of spectra that we then analyse to measure the associated redshifts.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=304594332 id=\"304594332\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-3>2.3 Redshift measurements</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\"><span class=\"small-caps\">ifs-redex</span> has an interactive interface that displays each extracted spectrum and its corresponding source in <span class=\"small-caps\">saods9</span> (Joye &amp; Mandel <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib50\" data-open=\"bib50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>). It allows the user to modify the source redshift to match the position of an emission/absorption line template to its most likely position in the spectrum. (The template contains \u223c60 lines including notably Ly\u00a0\u03b1, [O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>], [O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>], and H\u00a0\u03b2 emission lines, and Ca\u2009H&amp;K, Mg, Fe, and Na absorption lines.) To simplify the redshift identification, it is possible to smooth the signal with a Gaussian filter, and then perform a wavelet-based spectrum cleaning (Rexroth et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib82\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib82\" data-open=\"bib82\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). The systematic error is calculated by quadratically adding the wavelength calibration error provided by the MUSE data reduction pipeline, and the error given by fitting a Gaussian to the most prominent line in the spectrum. For each redshift, we assign a quality flag (QF) of 3 if the redshift is secure, 2 if likely (e.g. only one characteristic line \u2013 for example the [O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] doublet or Ly\u00a0\u03b1 line with consistent photometric redshift), 1 if insecure, and 0 otherwise, i.e. in case of visually flat continuum or highly polluted spectrum.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We sequentially analyse all spectra extracted from the MUSE datacubes of the three clusters using the aforementioned method. The measured redshifts are sorted depending on whether they belong to a source located in the foreground of the cluster, in the cluster, or in the background.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=304594335 id=\"304594335\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-4>2.4 Results of the redshift extraction</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> shows the distribution of redshifts for the extracted sources for RX\u2009J2129, MS\u20090451, and MACS\u2009J2129. Lists of the extracted redshifts with QF larger than 2 are given in Appendix\u2009\u00a0<a class=\"js-jumplink\" href=\"#sec8\">A</a>, where Tables \u2009<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl11\" data-open=\"tbl11\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A1</a>\u2013<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl13\" data-open=\"tbl13\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A3</a> give the results for RX\u2009J2129, MS\u20090451, and MACS\u2009J2129, respectively. The redshift intervals to consider galaxies as cluster members are established using the definition given in Ma et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib69\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib69\" data-open=\"bib69\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>), combined with the criteria defined in Rexroth et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib82\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib82\" data-open=\"bib82\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). For each cluster, we include all galaxies with a redshift flagged as secure or likely (QF = 2, 3), and which present a continuum plus characteristic absorption lines. We here only summarize the redshift extraction.</p>                        <a id=\"304594337\" scrollto-destination=\"304594337\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/508/1/10.1093_mnras_stab2270/1/m_stab2270fig1.jpeg?Expires=1639262452&amp;Signature=vKBLxO8zB-Xg-ogsACz0DaMwWzYtDbSRpgRxZdseYqAcdM9eCCmuu5LRYgoTVPJKipDtyo0mJz1tOSjFmm6YsrQNHKP8~GLysWMh-5vztnpbKUYX8mh1cp9uJmad0YNZeOP-bGdq7CiRC06nfNIN9Gmlpz0d3Z4rpLl5mVU~NuDfCsQTh4uE7x~uSpc6wqCr~Y0iF4Zr28iVXv5dwS-OdPi6uMar6KbzvNdbDvMilC77I9Doqzg9qzofp7J3W6EQSExt-dKhnDGMlLf~LBPoe9YswKao5vMtNCyKZy~-5sJJjAp2qFyHQPB88VbosJfk0mJCivYtbWlpc-WOuWf8AQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\"
