no-formula-id\">|$55^{+35}_{-5}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td>294\u00a0\u00b1\u00a042\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>G1\u00a0</td><td>[\u22122.93]\u00a0</td><td>[0.81]\u00a0</td><td>[0.44]\u00a0</td><td>[70.0]\u00a0</td><td>[0.15]\u00a0</td><td>44\u00a0\u00b1\u00a029\u00a0</td><td>200\u00a0\u00b1\u00a033\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>G2\u00a0</td><td>[4.53]\u00a0</td><td>[\u22121.28]\u00a0</td><td>[0.27]\u00a0</td><td>[\u221231.6]\u00a0</td><td>[0.15]\u00a0</td><td>43\u00a0\u00b1\u00a029\u00a0</td><td>184\u00a0\u00b1\u00a036\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>G3\u00a0</td><td>[14.42]\u00a0</td><td>[7.24]\u00a0</td><td>[0.47]\u00a0</td><td>[4.6]\u00a0</td><td>[0.15]\u00a0</td><td>7\u00a0\u00b1\u00a02\u00a0</td><td>356\u00a0\u00b1\u00a048\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>G4\u00a0</td><td>[5.92]\u00a0</td><td>[6.84]\u00a0</td><td>[0.39]\u00a0</td><td>[88.5]\u00a0</td><td>[0.15]\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$85^{+25}_{-18}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td>201\u00a0\u00b1\u00a024\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td><em>L</em>* galaxy\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>[0.15]\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$50^{+25}_{-19}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td>164\u00a0\u00b1\u00a016\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/304594377\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=304594378 id=\"304594378\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-3-1>3.3.1 RX\u2009J2129</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Our model contains one large-scale halo described by a PIEMD mass component. We model individually the BCG and include an isolated cluster galaxy (G1 in Table \u2009<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl8\" data-open=\"tbl8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a>), which acts as the lens for System 2 as detailed in Desprez et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). The four multiple images of System 2 are attributed to galaxy\u2013galaxy lensing and are used as constraints in our model as shown in Table\u2009 <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl5\" data-open=\"tbl5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>. One can see a zoom in on this lensing configuration in Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"304594380\" scrollto-destination=\"304594380\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/508/1/10.1093_mnras_stab2270/1/m_stab2270fig3.jpeg?Expires=1639262452&amp;Signature=mGIiSKiLVM44UhzEuGrEWrUZ~f3bSEP0656ENJiTXhJ2N3XUTtH1lQUx8S-aWo~0kxoNLca72tmX-oYWxfki4fjV9wJ3iH12TPtjev~8ciUV3EhoMg1mpgO-MPITVGQYEKDNOdnhKhBikbFOrciaR4mBF~Q-Xyg7UcnXsIcQsSERrw-bBAl6Bp5qlYFiGE3JSayJ1XX7OLa1el5kInCBHKXRaWz2YwHmjEZeVgF3dHaca9eZm0MPwgKMAjtQLl4BEeAsb3PgPH8rwTUkV6sRZuqj9k3EjNoYnKgCCRs~iqyD332vBPIT995gihouugFMvn~wLCYyTMarb44HB6fzHQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"HST composite colour image of RX\u2009J2129 using F475W, F814W, and F160W pass-bands. Multiple images used as constraints are highlighted by white circles. Critical lines are displayed for a source at redshift z = 1.52 in red. Orange dashed squares show the MUSE fields of view. System 2 is outside the field of view, and can be seen in Fig 5.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab2270fig3.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/304594380/stab2270fig3.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab2270fig3.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"304594380\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/508/1/10.1093_mnras_stab2270/1/stab2270fig3.jpeg?Expires=1639262452&Signature=1-G6e~98lgnM80UgByPRqFpZksuoiT1NK97b6IfBoCtCPTGLICVMLFG6O~ZWZndxsAXy~ay4HWv8b5JAyW2hg97PNdnoXejnbQc5jEOr2gWtPWUIplcoxtJeKUgs~0U2g6kP26nNIuT~EU6jC6-NN4qwOAq~xwJII0xvSLJzAH~1jRDQd2BiBgRO~d7PbuWPwieFwjbgJ8-MhwI-UrhTk14Je05WHXDI6MmVLw11hU-GejB95BRNX~ddOeHxTu5dSo5lKJJqo52SW6xxN~3GtgC3YD5Da3RUhFaN50NCHdB-gUvopqPNL7GNcoII0mUN7QcQpdPCcfqGEqDxZZdB-g__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=304594380&ar=6350584&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab2270fig3.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>HST</em> composite colour image of RX\u2009J2129 using F475W, F814W, and F160W pass-bands. Multiple images used as constraints are highlighted by white circles. Critical lines are displayed for a source at redshift <em>z</em> = 1.52 in red. Orange dashed squares show the MUSE fields of view. System 2 is outside the field of view, and can be seen in Fig <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/508/1/10.1093_mnras_stab2270/1/m_stab2270fig3.jpeg?Expires=1639262452&amp;Signature=mGIiSKiLVM44UhzEuGrEWrUZ~f3bSEP0656ENJiTXhJ2N3XUTtH1lQUx8S-aWo~0kxoNLca72tmX-oYWxfki4fjV9wJ3iH12TPtjev~8ciUV3EhoMg1mpgO-MPITVGQYEKDNOdnhKhBikbFOrciaR4mBF~Q-Xyg7UcnXsIcQsSERrw-bBAl6Bp5qlYFiGE3JSayJ1XX7OLa1el5kInCBHKXRaWz2YwHmjEZeVgF3dHaca9eZm0MPwgKMAjtQLl4BEeAsb3PgPH8rwTUkV6sRZuqj9k3EjNoYnKgCCRs~iqyD332vBPIT995gihouugFMvn~wLCYyTMarb44HB6fzHQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"HST composite colour image of RX\u2009J2129 using F475W, F814W, and F160W pass-bands. Multiple images used as constraints are highlighted by white circles. Critical lines are displayed for a source at redshift z = 1.52 in red. Orange dashed squares show the MUSE fields of view. System 2 is outside the field of view, and can be seen in Fig 5.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab2270fig3.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/304594380/stab2270fig3.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab2270fig3.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"304594380\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/508/1/10.1093_mnras_stab2270/1/stab2270fig3.jpeg?Expires=1639262452&Signature=1-G6e~98lgnM80UgByPRqFpZksuoiT1NK97b6IfBoCtCPTGLICVMLFG6O~ZWZndxsAXy~ay4HWv8b5JAyW2hg97PNdnoXejnbQc5jEOr2gWtPWUIplcoxtJeKUgs~0U2g6kP26nNIuT~EU6jC6-NN4qwOAq~xwJII0xvSLJzAH~1jRDQd2BiBgRO~d7PbuWPwieFwjbgJ8-MhwI-UrhTk14Je05WHXDI6MmVLw11hU-GejB95BRNX~ddOeHxTu5dSo5lKJJqo52SW6xxN~3GtgC3YD5Da3RUhFaN50NCHdB-gUvopqPNL7GNcoII0mUN7QcQpdPCcfqGEqDxZZdB-g__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=304594380&ar=6350584&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab2270fig3.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>HST</em> composite colour image of RX\u2009J2129 using F475W, F814W, and F160W pass-bands. Multiple images used as constraints are highlighted by white circles. Critical lines are displayed for a source at redshift <em>z</em> = 1.52 in red. Orange dashed squares show the MUSE fields of view. System 2 is outside the field of view, and can be seen in Fig <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Our best-fitting mass model has an rms = 0.29\u00a0arcsec. The best-fitting parameters of the model are given in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl8\" data-open=\"tbl8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a>, and the center of the cluster is chosen as (R\u2009A = 322.41651, Decl. = 0.08923). In order to check the impact of the addition of free parameters by the inclusion of G1 as an individual potential, we run a model which treats G1 as a standard cluster member, i.e. following the Faber &amp; Jackson (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1976</a>) relation. While the rms (\u03c7<sup>2</sup>, <em>dof</em>) of this model is not significantly different from our best-fitting mass model, 0.28\u00a0arcsec (8, 22) versus 0.29\u00a0arcsec (9, 24), it has a local impact. Indeed, the rms of System\u20092 is 0.15\u00a0arcsec, while we obtain an rms of 0.09\u00a0arcsec when G1 is included. We therefore conclude that G1 improves the model and is necessary to precisely recover the geometry of System\u20092.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=304594382 id=\"304594382\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-3-2>3.3.2 MS\u20090451</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Our initial model only included one large-scale halo centred on the BCG of MS\u20090451. However, such model could not reproduce precisely the multiple images located in the north of the cluster, with an rms &gt; 1.0\u2033 for all systems. With a single cluster-scale halo model, the critical line at redshift <em>z</em> = 6.7, corresponding to the redshift of System H, would not pass between Images H.2 and H.3, nor Images H.3 and H.4. The same applies for System R which, in this context, has an rms &gt; 1\u00a0arcsec. We thus looked at the distribution of cluster members, and identified two groups of galaxies, at the cluster redshift, located north of the cluster BCG. We thus run a new model that included a second large-scale halo, also modelled with a PIEMD, centred between these two groups. We note that we also run a model including three large-scale haloes (one for the cluster and the other two for the galaxy groups); however, the best-fitting model was not statistically better than the 2-halo one. We therefore decided to consider the simplest of the two models.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The BCG was modeled separately using a PIEMD profile where \u03c3 and <em>r</em><sub>cut</sub> are being optimized independently. We also include four independent subhaloes to model galaxies located in the foreground of the cluster (<em>z</em> = 0.0623 \u2013 IDs G1, G2, G3, and G4 in Table \u2009<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl8\" data-open=\"tbl8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a>). As the multiplane optimization is not yet finalized in <span class=\"small-caps\">Lenstool</span>, the impact of a given foreground galaxy is being assessed by projecting its mass component in the cluster plane.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Moreover, the blind search in the <span class=\"small-caps\">muselet</span> narrow-band datacube revealed an unidentified cluster member (<em>z</em> = 0.531) located in the vicinity of Image R.1, and too faint to be seen in the <em>HST</em> images. We thus chose to include this cluster member as an individually optimized potential in our mass model as it acts as a local small-scale perturber for System R (potential G5 in Table \u2009<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl8\" data-open=\"tbl8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a>, O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> emitter, QF\u2009=\u20093). Finally, we add one more galaxy-scale halo, the cluster member identified as G6, located closely to Image K.1.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Our best-fitting mass model has an rms = 0.60\u00a0arcsec. The best-fitting parameters of the model are given in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl8\" data-open=\"tbl8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a>, and the centre of the cluster is chosen as (R\u2009A = 73.54520, Decl. = \u22123.01439). This mass model is used for the combined strong and weak-lensing analysis of MS\u20090451 presented in Tam et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib94\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib94\" data-open=\"bib94\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">As was done for RX\u2009J2129, a model was run excluding all individual galaxy-scale haloes, G1, G2, G3, G4, G5, and G6. The resulting model has an rms (\u03c7<sup>2</sup>, <em>dof</em>) of 1.59\u00a0arcsec (478,34), more than a factor of 2 from our best-fitting model which has an rms (\u03c7<sup>2</sup>, <em>dof</em>) of 0.6\u00a0arcsec (68, 18), demonstrating the need for these galaxies to be modelled individually. We also assess specifically the impact of including galaxies G1, G2, G3, and G4 that are known to be foreground objects as mentioned before. We thus run a model that excludes these four galaxy-scale haloes. The resulting best-fitting model has an rms (\u03c7<sup>2</sup>, <em>dof</em>) of 0.92\u00a0arcsec (159, 26). This again shows the necessity to include those as individual potentials, ignoring their results in a degradation of the goodness of the fit. To go even further, with this one model the rms of System\u2009H, the quadruply imaged galaxy at <em>z</em> = 6.7, is degraded to 0.5\u00a0arcsec, to be compared with 0.16\u00a0arcsec with our best-fitting mass model, and the model cannot reproduce properly the lensing configuration. We then assess the impact of G6 in our mass model. We run a model which excludes this one individual galaxy-scale halo. The resulting model gives an rms of 0.59\u00a0arcsec. Compared to our best-fitting model presented before which has an rms of 0.6\u00a0arcsec, the improvement is not significant. However, the presence of G6 impacts the rms of several systems, with the most significant one being System\u2009H with an rms degraded to 0.48\u00a0arcsec. This system being a stringent constraints to our model, we also consider G6 as necessary to our model.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=304594388 id=\"304594388\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-3-3>3.3.3 MACS\u2009J2129</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We use a similar approach to MS\u20090451 by starting with a model as simple as possible, and, thus, including only one large-scale halo. However, the two most Easterly systems, Systems 3 and 6, were poorly reproduced with this model, with an rms greater than 1\u00a0arcsec. We thus decided to add a second large-scale halo centred on a galaxy group located north-east of the BCG. All large-scale haloes are modelled using PIEMDs, and all their parameters are being optimized except for the truncation radius which is set to 1000\u2009kpc.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We individually optimize the BCG of the cluster. We then add two galaxy-scale haloes to model galaxies identified as small-scale perturbers by Monna et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), due to their proximity to the sextuply imaged System 1 (G1 and G2 in Table\u2009 <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl8\" data-open=\"tbl8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a>). Moreover, Images 10.2 and 8.1 are both located near cluster galaxies, encouraging us to include those as individual potentials in our mass model (G3 and G4 in Table\u2009 <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl8\" data-open=\"tbl8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Our best-fitting mass model has an rms = 0.74\u00a0arcsec. The best-fitting parameters of the model are given in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl8\" data-open=\"tbl8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a>, and the centre of the cluster is chosen as (R\u2009A = 322.35878, Decl. = \u22127.69100). As for RX\u2009J2129 and MS\u20090451, we test the necessity of the individual galaxy-scale potentials in our best model. When excluding all individual galaxy-scale haloes, we obtain an rms (\u03c7<sup>2</sup>, <em>dof</em>) of 1.05\u00a0arcsec (184, 41), to be compared to 0.74\u00a0arcsec (90, 31) with our best-fitting model. Such a difference comforts us in our choice of modelling G1, G2, G3, and G4 individually due to their proximity to some of the multiple images in the cluster.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=304594392 id=\"304594392\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4>4 RESULTS AND DISCUSSIONS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">As presented in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">3</a>, the optimization of RX\u2009J2129, MS\u20090451, and MACS\u2009J2129 mass models were done using <span class=\"small-caps\">Lenstool</span> (Jullo et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>), and the best-fitting parameters for each model are given in Table\u2009 <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl8\" data-open=\"tbl8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a>. The list of multiple images used as constraints, together with their spectroscopic redshift or the optimized one from the models when included as a free parameter, and the rms obtained for each multiple image are provided in Tables\u2009 <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl5\" data-open=\"tbl5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>\u2013<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl7\" data-open=\"tbl7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>. In this section, we discuss the improvements on the mass models brought by the MUSE data for each cluster, considering their mass distributions, density profiles, rms, and compare our results with previously published works.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=304594394 id=\"304594394\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-1>4.1 RX\u2009J2129</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Our best mass model is constrained by 8 multiple image systems, 7 of them spectroscopically confirmed, and is composed of 71 potentials including one large-scale halo and 2 galaxy-scale haloes independently optimized. The best-fitting model has an rms of 0.29\u00a0arcsec. The left-hand panel of Fig.\u2009 <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig8\" data-open=\"fig8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a> shows the density profiles for both the <em>fiducial</em> and our best models. One can see that the new model predicts a significantly higher density in the very inner core of RX\u2009J2129, <em>R</em> &gt;10\u2009kpc, compare to the <em>fiducial model</em>, which then takes over at larger radii. In terms of total mass within the multiple image region, <em>R</em> &lt; 70\u2009kpc, we measure <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M({\\rm R}\\lt 70\\, \\rm {kpc})=(0.30\\pm 0.01)\\times 10^{14}\\, {\\rm M}_{\\odot }$|\u2060</span>, in perfect agreement with <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M_{\\rm {fiducial}}({\\it R}\\lt 70\\, \\rm {kpc})=(0.30\\pm 0.01)\\times 10^{14}\\, {\\rm M}_{\\odot }$|\u2060</span>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We measure an Einstein radius of \u03b8<sub>E</sub> = (19\u00a0\u00b1\u00a02)\u00a0arcsec for a source redshift <em>z</em> = 2.0. This is higher than previous measurements presented by Richard et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib83\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib83\" data-open=\"bib83\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) and Zitrin et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib105\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib105\" data-open=\"bib105\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>), <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\theta _{\\rm {E,\\, Richard+10}}=(9.0\\pm 1.4)$|</span>\u00a0arcsec and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\theta _{\\rm {E,\\, Zitrin+15}}=13$|</span>\u00a0arcsec. In terms of total mass, we measure <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M({\\it R}\\lt 250\\, \\rm {kpc})=(1.49\\pm 0.04)\\times 10^{14}\\, {\\rm M}_{\\odot }$|\u2060</span>, which is in good agreement with the measurement given by Richard et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib83\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib83\" data-open=\"bib83\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M_{\\rm {Richard+10}}({\\it R}\\lt 250\\, \\rm {kpc})=(1.37\\pm 0.37)\\times 10^{14}\\, {\\rm M}_{\\odot }$|\u2060</span>. Zitrin et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib105\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib105\" data-open=\"bib105\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) quote a mass within 13\u00a0arcsec, which corresponds to \u223c50\u2009kpc at the cluster redshift, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M_{\\rm {Zitrin+15}}({\\rm R}\\lt 50\\, \\rm {kpc})=0.19\\times 10^{14}\\, {\\rm M}_{\\odot }$|\u2060</span>, which is of the same order as what we obtain with our model, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M({\\rm R}\\lt 50\\, \\rm {kpc})=(0.17\\pm 0.01)\\times 10^{14}\\, {\\rm M}_{\\odot }$|\u2060</span>. Caminha et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>) quote an integrated mass of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M_{\\rm {Caminha+19}}({\\it R}\\lt 200\\, \\rm {kpc})=(1.19\\pm 0.01)\\times 10^{14}\\, {\\rm M}_{\\odot }$|\u2060</span>, in excellent agreement with our value of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M({\\rm R}\\lt 200\\, \\rm {kpc})=(1.16\\pm 0.03)\\times 10^{14}\\, {\\rm M}_{\\odot }$|\u2060</span>. Thanks to discussions with Desprez et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), we could get the integrated total mass measured with their model within the multiple image region, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M_{\\rm {Desprez+18}}({\\rm R}\\lt 70\\, \\rm {kpc})=(0.29\\pm 0.01)\\times 10^{14}\\, {\\rm M}_{\\odot }$|\u2060</span>, value which is in good agreement with our measurement presented before. It is important to note that at the time Richard et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib83\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib83\" data-open=\"bib83\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) and Zitrin et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib105\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib105\" data-open=\"bib105\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) published their strong-lensing mass models, the spectroscopic coverage of RX\u2009J2129 was poor. Indeed, only one system, System 1 in this work, had a spectroscopic measurement. Richard et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib83\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib83\" data-open=\"bib83\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) model was only constrained using that system (3 multiple images in total), and Zitrin et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib105\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib105\" data-open=\"bib105\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) model included 6 systems (18 multiple images total) as constraints. In our case, we have 8 systems, 23 multiple images in total as can be seen in Table\u2009 <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl5\" data-open=\"tbl5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>, all spectroscopically confirmed (except System 2 for which we assume the photometric redshift measured by Desprez et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). This could explain the discrepancies in the measured Einstein radii between these analyses and our model.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=304594397 id=\"304594397\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-2>4.2 MS\u20090451</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Our best model is constrained by 16 multiple image systems, 5 spectroscopically confirmed, and is composed of 146 haloes including 2 large-scale haloes, and 7 galaxy-scale haloes independently optimized. The best-fitting model has an rms of 0.6\u00a0arcsec. In the middle panel of Fig.\u2009 <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig8\" data-open=\"fig8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a>, we compare the density profiles obtained with the <em>fiducial model</em> and the new model presented here. The two profiles are in excellent agreement, with a slightly higher density predicted in the core now, but still within the error bars of the <em>fiducial model</em>, which we attribute to the stronger constraints used to optimize our model thanks to the identification of new systems in the north of MS\u20090451. We measure a total mass within the multiple image region that extends up to \u223c350\u2009kpc, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M({\\it R}\\lt 350\\, \\rm {kpc})=(3.75\\pm 0.11)\\times 10^{14}\\, {\\rm M}_{\\odot }$|\u2060</span>, in good agreement with the value obtained with the <em>fiducial model</em>, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M_{\\rm fiducial}({\\it R}\\lt 350\\, \\rm {kpc})=(3.72\\pm 0.03)\\times 10^{14}\\, {\\rm M}_{\\odot }$|\u2060</span>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We measure an Einstein radius, \u03b8<sub>E</sub> = (19\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01)\u00a0arcsec, for a source redshift of <em>z</em> = 2.9 (i.e. redshift of System A). This value is consistent with the one reported in Zitrin et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib104\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib104\" data-open=\"bib104\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011b</a>), <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\theta _{\\rm {E,\\, Zitrin+11}} = (19\\pm 2)$|</span>\u2033. We measure an integrated mass within <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\theta _{\\rm {E}}=120\\, \\rm {kpc}$|</span> of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M(\\lt \\theta _{\\rm {E}})=(9.15\\pm 0.08)\\times 10^{13}\\, {\\rm M}_{\\odot }$|\u2060</span>. This is slightly higher than what was measured by Zitrin et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib104\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib104\" data-open=\"bib104\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011b</a>), <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M_{\\rm {Zitrin+11}}(\\lt \\theta _{\\rm {E}})=8.82^{+0.3}_{0.1}\\times 10^{13}\\, {\\rm M}_{\\odot }$|\u2060</span>; however, their mass model only includes 4 systems of multiple images, compared to our analysis which has 16 systems as constraints. Berciano Alba et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib11\" data-open=\"bib11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) measured an integrated mass within a radius of 30\u00a0arcsec, 188\u2009kpc at the redshift of MS\u20090451, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M_{\\rm {BA+09}}({\\rm R}\\lt 188\\, \\rm {kpc})=1.73\\times 10^{14}\\, {\\rm M}_{\\odot }$|\u2060</span>, which is in excellent agreement with both our measurement, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M({\\rm R}\\lt 188\\, \\rm {kpc})=(1.73\\pm 0.02)\\times 10^{14}\\, {\\rm M}_{\\odot }$|\u2060</span>, and the one from Zitrin et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib104\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib104\" data-open=\"bib104\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011b</a>) at the same radius, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M_{\\rm {Zitrin+11}}({\\rm R}\\lt 188\\, \\rm {kpc})=1.80\\times 10^{14}\\, {\\rm M}_{\\odot }$|\u2060</span>. This strengthens our argument that the difference of mass values between Zitrin et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib104\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib104\" data-open=\"bib104\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011b</a>) and our work at smaller radii might be due to the improvement of the mass model due to both an increased number of multiple images to constrain the inner mass distribution of MS\u20090451, and the spectroscopic information.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The mass obtained for galaxy G5 appears relatively high (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a> and Table\u2009 <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl8\" data-open=\"tbl8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a>), considering it is not visible in any of the <em>HST</em> images and only detected in the MUSE datacube. It is thus likely to be a low-mass galaxy with a velocity dispersion lower than the best-fitting value measured by our mass model, \u03c3 = 132\u2009km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>. Moreover, as it is not detected in the <em>HST</em> imaging, we do not have any shape measurements for G5. The model thus optimizes all its parameters apart from its core radius, <em>r<sub>c</sub></em>. The best-fitting parameters for this galaxy might be strongly degenerated. It is thus difficult to conclude.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Oppositely, the cluster galaxy G4 is predicted with a velocity dispersion \u03c3 = 45\u2009km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>, which is likely underestimated given the size of the galaxy (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>). This can be explained by the addition of the second large-scale halo in its vicinity, which might induce a non-physical \u2018mass transfer\u2019 between the two haloes. However, as explained in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">3</a>, this second large-scale halo is necessary to account for the impact of the two galaxy groups in this region, and without which we cannot recover the quintuply imaged system at <em>z</em> = 6.7 (Knudsen et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Richard et\u00a0al. in preparation).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The rms of each multiple image is given in Table\u2009 <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl6\" data-open=\"tbl6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>, and the predicted position together with their magnification, \u03bc, of the unidentified counter-images of the systems used as constraints are given in Table \u2009<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl9\" data-open=\"tbl9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a>, namely System J and System S. Images J.3, S.3, and S.4 are highlighted as cyan circles in Fig. \u2009<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>. The two systems in the north of the cluster, Systems H and R, are well reproduced, with an rms of 0.16\u00a0 and 0.51\u00a0arcsec, respectively. The same goes for the group of systems located in the vicinity of the giant arc A, south of the cluster, i.e. Systems A, B, C, D, E, F, G, and K). Systems I and O are not as well reproduced as the others, with an rms of 1.0 and 1.18\u00a0arcsec, respectively. We explain this by the location of one of their multiple images, Images I.2 and O.2. Image I.2 is located close to a faint cluster galaxy which is not individually optimized, but might act as a small-scale perturber. A mass model that includes the cluster galaxy close to Image I.2 does not show any significant improvements compare to our best model when considering the number of added free parameters. Image O.2 is located in a region which is highly contaminated by the light of the BCG, meaning we could be missing local perturbers.</p>                        <a id=\"304594403\" scrollto-destination=\"304594403\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/508/1/10.1093_mnras_stab2270/1/m_stab2270fig4.jpeg?Expires=1639262452&amp;Signature=3LKq5BKbZ3dyNOO9nwLa6gcoxzkDWc2kmSv2z962EEg8SpjOtf58GPht8Qvw55PqRBHepdDCGpgqpEyEt7QFUipTrkFzIC6zWGI--6hrUDNJFPYQnNx26~xnw6A6aNC3Oxw~IjBOjrKa1HeERhRR8z1cmAW7HYw6x8x~3depiy6CqyJtBgeHuCl0WMBay11qlYLjUOSWzpFp58O7QfRcA4tUU3i4bgm52j9-Xbj44E7f8OVtcYRB-KwfFJV2TDEIa1WTvsE6SbeUFNNOW0EamTRHbtLdd1LaJadDu12CRg-izV77bJGvZHWrB66ZXqOTYxLspA6sRDYQxVigu-L2MQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"HST composite colour image of MS\u20090451 using F814W, F110W, and F160W pass-bands. Critical lines for a source at redshift z = 2.9 (redshift of System A) are shown as red lines. Orange dashed squares show the MUSE fields of view.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab2270fig4.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/304594403/stab2270fig4.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab2270fig4.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"304594403\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/508/1/10.1093_mnras_stab2270/1/stab2270fig4.jpeg?Expires=1639262452&Signature=G7vvrBNv~seJfow-iHgnNEfGo33uLA8b2gbgJVDNmmVk~zkLUpwWvck0nX9sFYmepaHlif-QG3zIa6s9zPnMFTvxOkXyRuO739bVk6VnVNH1aRoCN2mj5ymVro8WOSYDKsvDK0qMyVIPq-yDCUO4rv-NfVrMzT3CaFobrQKMKvcyYmgkUyuszMQhToDRylMaaMRZOoPZsxMDpnAqegOmbMLdN6MV2Lrud4kT2RsAvh3GMDjCVVpYvNp~7Y0q4JVid3aG~do038r9jFWq1qFnHwpto8Slp-uiigQIvZzj6ALzSQeGQB5SjADeOU-oL0eblpENzONVBkcOKHheMqZAjw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=304594403&ar=6350584&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab2270fig4.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>HST</em> composite colour image of MS\u20090451 using F814W, F110W, and F160W pass-bands. Critical lines for a source at redshift <em>z</em> = 2.9 (redshift of System A) are shown as red lines. Orange dashed squares show the MUSE fields of view.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/508/1/10.1093_mnras_stab2270/1/m_stab2270fig4.jpeg?Expires=1639262452&amp;Signature=3LKq5BKbZ3dyNOO9nwLa6gcoxzkDWc2kmSv2z962EEg8SpjOtf58GPht8Qvw55PqRBHepdDCGpgqpEyEt7QFUipTrkFzIC6zWGI--6hrUDNJFPYQnNx26~xnw6A6aNC3Oxw~IjBOjrKa1HeERhRR8z1cmAW7HYw6x8x~3depiy6CqyJtBgeHuCl0WMBay11qlYLjUOSWzpFp58O7QfRcA4tUU3i4bgm52j9-Xbj44E7f8OVtcYRB-KwfFJV2TDEIa1WTvsE6SbeUFNNOW0EamTRHbtLdd1LaJadDu12CRg-izV77bJGvZHWrB66ZXqOTYxLspA6sRDYQxVigu-L2MQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"HST composite colour image of MS\u20090451 using F814W, F110W, and F160W pass-bands. Orange dashed squares show the MUSE fields of view.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab2270fig4.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/304594403/stab2270fig4.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab2270fig4.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"304594403\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/508/1/10.1093_mnras_stab2270/1/stab2270fig4.jpeg?Expires=1639262452&Signature=G7vvrBNv~seJfow-iHgnNEfGo33uLA8b2gbgJVDNmmVk~zkLUpwWvck0nX9sFYmepaHlif-QG3zIa6s9zPnMFTvxOkXyRuO739bVk6VnVNH1aRoCN2mj5ymVro8WOSYDKsvDK0qMyVIPq-yDCUO4rv-NfVrMzT3CaFobrQKMKvcyYmgkUyuszMQhToDRylMaaMRZOoPZsxMDpnAqegOmbMLdN6MV2Lrud4kT2RsAvh3GMDjCVVpYvNp~7Y0q4JVid3aG~do038r9jFWq1qFnHwpto8Slp-uiigQIvZzj6ALzSQeGQB5SjADeOU-oL0eblpENzONVBkcOKHheMqZAjw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=304594403&ar=6350584&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab2270fig4.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>HST</em> composite colour image of MS\u20090451 using F814W, F110W, and F160W pass-bands. Critical lines for a source at redshift <em>z</em> = 2.9 (redshift of System A) are shown as red lines. Orange dashed squares show the MUSE fields of view.</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"304594404\" scrollto-destination=\"304594404\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl9\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl9\" data-id=\"tbl9\"><span class=\"label\">Table 9.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Predicted positions of the unidentified counter images from the best model of MS\u20090451. Column (1) stands for the identifier of the image with respect to the system it belongs to. Columns (2) and (3) are, respectively, the R\u2009A and Decl. in degrees (J2000) of the images. Column (4) gives the measured magnification of the images at their predicted positions. The images are highlighted as cyan circles in Fig.\u2009 <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>J.3\u00a0</td><td>73.55100\u00a0</td><td>\u22123.01006\u00a0</td><td>3.5\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.3\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>S.3\u00a0</td><td>73.54862\u00a0</td><td>\u22123.01063\u00a0</td><td>13.0\u00a0\u00b1\u00a03.0\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>S.4\u00a0</td><td>73.54093\u00a0</td><td>\u22123.02420\u00a0</td><td>2.2\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.2\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>Image ID<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>R\u2009A<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>J.3\u00a0</td><td>73.55100\u00a0</td><td>\u22123.01006\u00a0</td><td>3.5\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.3\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>S.3\u00a0</td><td>73.54862\u00a0</td><td>\u22123.01063\u00a0</td><td>13.0\u00a0\u00b1\u00a03.0\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>S.4\u00a0</td><td>73.54093\u00a0</td><td>\u22123.02420\u00a0</td><td>2.2\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.2\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/304594404\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl9\" data-id=\"tbl9\"><span class=\"label\">Table class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>Image ID<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>R\u2009A<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>J.3\u00a0</td><td>73.55100\u00a0</td><td>\u22123.01006\u00a0</td><td>3.5\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.3\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>S.3\u00a0</td><td>73.54862\u00a0</td><td>\u22123.01063\u00a0</td><td>13.0\u00a0\u00b1\u00a03.0\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>S.4\u00a0</td><td>73.54093\u00a0</td><td>\u22123.02420\u00a0</td><td>2.2\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.2\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/304594404\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Moreover, MacKenzie et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) discussed the group of multiply lensed submilimetric galaxies at <em>z</em> = 2.9, corresponding to Systems A, B, C, D, E, F, and G in this work. They provide magnification estimates for each image, in excellent agreement with the magnifications measured with our best model. Table\u2009 <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl10\" data-open=\"tbl10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a> gives the measured magnifications by this analysis as well as the ones measured in MacKenzie et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). The largest differences are seen for highly magnified images such as Images A.1, A.2, G.2, and G.3. This was to be expected as in high magnification regions such measurements have large uncertainties. Indeed magnification is supposedly infinite on critical lines, making these measurements difficult to believe, apart from the fact that lensed galaxies located in these regions are highly magnified. One more thing to consider is the unambiguous measurement of the redshift of System G with MUSE of <em>z</em> = 2.93. Indeed this value differs from the one used in MacKenzie et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>), <em>z</em> = 3.11\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.03, which was initially measured by Takata et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib93\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib93\" data-open=\"bib93\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>).</p>                        <a id=\"304594406\" scrollto-destination=\"304594406\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl10\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl10\" data-id=\"tbl10\"><span class=\"label\">Table 10.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Measured magnification for the lensed submillimetric galaxies identified in Borys et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>) and MacKenzie et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). We list the IDs of the multiple images following Table\u2009 <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl6\" data-open=\"tbl6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>, and add the ID from MacKenzie et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) in brackets. We here give the magnifications measured from our best model, as well as the ones reported in MacKenzie et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>).</p></div> </div><div </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl10\" data-id=\"tbl10\"><span class=\"label\">Table 10.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Measured magnification for the lensed submillimetric galaxies identified in Borys et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>) and MacKenzie et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). We list the IDs of the multiple images following Table\u2009 <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl6\" data-open=\"tbl6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>, and add the ID from MacKenzie et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) in brackets. We here give the magnifications measured from our best model, as well as the ones reported in MacKenzie et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>).</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>ID<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>RA<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>ID<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>RA<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n (3c)\u00a0</td><td>73.54775\u00a0</td><td>\u22123.02268\u00a0</td><td>3.3\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.3\u00a0</td><td>4.3\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.1\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>G.1 (1a)\u00a0</td><td>73.55593\u00a0</td><td>\u22123.01193\u00a0</td><td>3.8\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.3\u00a0</td><td>3.8\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.1\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>G.2 (1b)\u00a0</td><td>73.55271\u00a0</td><td>\u22123.02124\u00a0</td><td>10.9\u00a0\u00b1\u00a02.1\u00a0</td><td>20\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>G.3 (1c)\u00a0</td><td>73.55071\u00a0</td><td>\u22123.02261\u00a0</td><td>6.1\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.6\u00a0</td><td>7.3\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.1\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/304594406\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=304594407 id=\"304594407\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-2-1>4.2.1 System S</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Although spectroscopically confirmed, System S is not well reproduced by the model, with an rms of 1.3\u00a0arcsec. Both Images S.1 and S.2 are in the high magnification region of the cluster, close to the radial critical line at the redshift of the source, <em>z</em> = 4.45, with a measured magnification for S.1 of \u03bc &gt; 300. System S is predicted to be quadruply imaged. Images S.1 and S.2 are only detected in the MUSE datacube, as their proximity to the BCG makes them undetectable in the <em>HST</em> images. Counter-images are predicted further away from the BCG, with relatively low magnifications as quoted in Table\u2009 <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl9\" data-open=\"tbl9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a>. That could explain why Image S.3 is not detected in the MUSE datacube, while Image S.4 is predicted outside the MUSE field of view as can be seen in Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a> (cyan circles). However, the lack of photometric identification of Images S.1 and S.2 in the <em>HST</em> images makes them impossible to identify as we have no idea of their colour nor morphology.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=304594409 id=\"304594409\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-3>4.3 MACS\u2009J2129</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Our best model is constrained by 13 multiple image systems, 12 spectroscopically confirmed, and is composed of 151 haloes including 2 large-scale haloes and 4 galaxy-scale haloes independently optimized. The constraints used in this model are the same as the ones presented in Caminha et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>), except for a newly identified system, System 10, and the removal of System 14, as discussed in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">3</a>. The best-fitting model has an rms of 0.74\u00a0arcsec. The right-hand panel of Fig. \u2009<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig8\" data-open=\"fig8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a> shows the density profiles obtained with this work and our <em>fiducial model</em>. One can notice differences between the two density profiles in the very inner region of the cluster, <em>R</em> &lt; 10\u2009kpc; however, this discrepancy is difficult to interpret as within this region the density is dominated by the stellar content of the BCG, and thus we lack constraints from strong lensing. At <em>R</em> &gt; 10\u2009kpc, the new model exhibits overdensity peaks not visible in the <em>fiducial model</em> density profile. This is explained by the inclusion of new constraints in this region, both multiple images and cluster galaxies up to <em>R</em> \u223c 100\u2009kpc. In terms of total mass within the multiple image region, which extends up to \u223c300\u2009kpc, we measure <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M({\\it R}\\lt 300\\, \\rm {kpc})=(2.94\\pm 0.02)\\times 10^{14}\\, {\\rm M}_{\\odot }$|\u2060</span>, in good agreement with the value from the <em>fiducial model</em>, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M_{\\rm {fiducial}}({\\it R}\\lt 300\\, \\rm {kpc})=(2.97\\pm 0.02)\\times 10^{14}\\, {\\rm M}_{\\odot }$|\u2060</span>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The properties of the main dark matter halo (namely, C1 in Table\u2009 <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl8\" data-open=\"tbl8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a>) are consistent with those reported in Monna et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) and Caminha et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>). Our best-fitting model also favours a relatively large core radius, <em>r<sub>c</sub></em> = (96\u00a0\u00b1\u00a05)\u2009kpc, in excellent agreement with Monna et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) measurement of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$r_{c,\\, \\rm {Monna+17}}=(101\\pm 13)$|</span>\u2009kpc. Caminha et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>), who are also using the <span class=\"small-caps\">Lenstool</span> software, quote a core radius for the main cluster-scale halo of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$r_{c,\\, \\rm {Caminha+19}}=(74\\pm 4)$|</span>\u2009kpc. This is slightly lower than what we obtain. The second cluster-scale halo they include has similar properties to this work (C2 in Table\u2009 <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl8\" data-open=\"tbl8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a>); however, their model favours it closer to the BCG, \u223c250\u2009kpc <em>versus</em> \u223c320\u2009kpc in this work. This might explain the lower value of <em>r<sub>c</sub></em> for C1 obtained by Caminha et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>) compared to our work. We find that velocity dispersions of the galaxy-scale haloes, BCG, G1, and G2, are overestimated compared to their luminous counterparts. This is explained by the correlation between the baryonic mass distribution within central galaxies, and the size of the core of the dark matter halo (Newman et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib75\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib75\" data-open=\"bib75\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013a</a>,<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib76\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib76\" data-open=\"bib76\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">b</a>), which was already evidenced by Monna et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We measure an Einstein radius for a source redshift <em>z</em> = 2.0 of \u03b8<sub>E</sub> = (23\u00a0\u00b1\u00a02)\u00a0arcsec, which is within the error bars of what Zitrin et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib104\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib104\" data-open=\"bib104\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011b</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib105\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib105\" data-open=\"bib105\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) measured for a similar source redshift, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\theta _{\\rm {E,\\, Zitrin+11,15}}=(19\\pm 2)$|</span>\u00a0arcsec. Monna et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) quote an Einstein radius for a source redshift <em>z</em> = 1.36, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\theta _{\\rm {E,\\, Monna+17}}=(14\\pm 2)$|</span>\u00a0arcsec, of similar order to what we measure at the same source redshift, \u03b8<sub>E</sub> = (18\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01)\u00a0arcsec. In order to compare our model with Monna et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), Zitrin et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib104\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib104\" data-open=\"bib104\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011b</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib105\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib105\" data-open=\"bib105\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>), we now quote masses within a radius of 19\u00a0arcsec, which corresponds to \u223c130\u2009kpc at the redshift of MACS\u2009J2129. We measure a total mass of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M({\\rm R}\\lt 130\\, \\rm {kpc})=(1.04\\pm 0.01)\\times 10^{14}\\, {\\rm M}_{\\odot }$|\u2060</span>, slightly higher than what is measured by Monna et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M_{\\rm {Monna+17}}({\\rm R}\\lt 130\\, \\rm {kpc})=(0.89\\pm 0.01)\\times 10^{14}\\, {\\rm M}_{\\odot }$|\u2060</span>, but within the error bars of the measurements given by Zitrin et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib104\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib104\" data-open=\"bib104\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011b</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib105\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib105\" data-open=\"bib105\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>), <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M_{\\rm {Zitrin+11,15}}({\\rm R}\\lt 130\\, \\rm {kpc})=0.92\\pm 0.09)\\times 10^{14}\\, {\\rm M}_{\\odot }$|\u2060</span>. Caminha et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>) quote a mass of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M_{\\rm {Caminha+19}}({\\rm R}\\lt 200\\, \\rm {kpc})=(1.84\\pm 0.01)\\times 10^{14}\\, {\\rm M}_{\\odot }$|\u2060</span>, in excellent agreement with our measurement of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M({\\rm R}\\lt 200\\, \\rm {kpc})=(1.81\\pm 0.02)\\times 10^{14}\\, {\\rm M}_{\\odot }$|\u2060</span>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Globally, multiple images are well recovered by our model, except for System 8 which has an rms = 1.37\u00a0arcsec. The new multiple image system reported in this work, i.e. Systems 10, is well-recovered, with an rms = 0.61\u00a0arcsec. In particular, we note that the inclusion of the cluster galaxy G3 (see Table\u2009 <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl8\" data-open=\"tbl8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a>) is critical for the recovery of this system. The addition of the second cluster-scale halo in the north-east of the cluster significantly improves the recovery of Systems 3 and 6 compared to the model presented by Monna et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). We measure an rms of 0.40\u00a0arcsec, to be compared to \u223c0.8\u00a0arcsec for System 3 when G3 is not included, and 0.79\u00a0arcsec to be compared to 1.7\u00a0arcsec for System 6. While four over the five multiple images of System 8 are spectroscopically confirmed, it has an rms of 1.37\u00a0arcsec. We note that the inclusion of galaxy G4 in the model seems to be responsible for that, as it degrades the accuracy of the reconstruction of System 8 (Image 8.3 is poorly reproduced). However, G4 is necessary to recover precisely Systems 1 and 7, decreasing the rms of the overall model from 0.95 to 0.73\u00a0arcsec.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Finally, MACS\u2009J2129 also hosts a particularly red and bright single strongly lensed galaxy, West of the cluster centre as shown in Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a> (\u03b1 = 322.34311, \u03b4 = \u22127.69203). Toft et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib95\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib95\" data-open=\"bib95\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) presented a detailed analysis of this <em>z</em> = 2.1472 compact galaxy, spectroscopically confirmed thanks to VLT/X-Shooter observations, and which revealed to be a fast-spinning, rotationally supported disc galaxy. Thanks to their lensing mass model, Toft et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib95\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib95\" data-open=\"bib95\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) measured a magnification of \u03bc<sub>Toft + 17</sub> = 4.2\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.6. While this galaxy is not used in the mass model presented here as it is singly imaged, we can measure its predicted magnification. We measure \u03bc = 3.7\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.2, a slightly lower value than the one from Toft et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib95\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib95\" data-open=\"bib95\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), but in good agreement within error bars. One should note that their strong-lensing mass model was only constrained by two multiple image systems, namely Systems 1 and 3 in Table\u2009 <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl7\" data-open=\"tbl7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"304594415\" scrollto-destination=\"304594415\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig5\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/508/1/10.1093_mnras_stab2270/1/m_stab2270fig5.jpeg?Expires=1639262452&amp;Signature=LtXbk3TWqg9E-v7pHOPU~42N1uwg46-TNLG8jJLaQu4e~WOKPG3Z1HsrGtKqMFzlLpnpr9NDhrgqFS65kbG1OAH9~i5GbO53bWbSvNri1e~o97ElIGESEm4MOp6IYZj9YfTRc09OHUJtw9AkElB661S3XG98t9DIrwC4nhew0yhRZdQSR2yTwWcnKP3vopuFFAipkOpMkupJ~0B02fqrsnlxmQgx6YNE5L1Ab-pk8U4QapC1xfFyy2xKaAHKY4IxidmN5A3c0LbTaUfsNQACNpnVRP8n2N8AmDpjjkV8A-P~ft2L5imfNLTq3SVWRYCIY0ZGjjNhS8YKazEcze5ZVw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"HST composite colour image of MACS\u2009J2129 using F475W, F814W, and F160W pass-bands.
