The contours are displayed in magenta for 2, 3, and 4\u2009\u00d7 10<sup>\u221220</sup>\u2009erg\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u2009arcsec<sup>\u22122</sup>. <em>Bottom:</em> Extracted spectra from the MUSE datacube centred on the most prominent lines for images of System 8 (left) and System 10 (right).</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"304594417\" scrollto-destination=\"304594417\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig7\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 7.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/508/1/10.1093_mnras_stab2270/1/m_stab2270fig7.jpeg?Expires=1639262452&amp;Signature=SaLndIW-EHh9x73a77~ZIt3TMxs3O4Tl8xHbA8n5tPTE874hnvhMrTHaLKnE7PSe1zQ~zhRweSfzUSfRFul6P2ABLJ7koURiNFz~3CucL-7vYbiwGaw2TjVK6j-Nw6PB-BTScSE6DK6k1R0sJG1vc-x2~u4142~F-2~RVl7TWhyO3lsMBIflP0~p3qdSh6zPDiyajWD58gc5oEnYSyj0CDliV2WvM7-vxrdRUrEnCbwjCtVZ45w1YNTetQj9KG~IbXHhDc-SQNOVjnRgl8tfTHCpRmsGPRPGsCqCZLRwguCCn8~tE4VMX1ZkTOvNrbVQTWBGEv0nkzXpzkjnT0rPSw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Left: RMS for each multiple image system in RX\u2009J2129 (top), MS\u20090451 (middle), and MACS\u2009J2129 (bottom). The red dashed line shows the rms of the best-fitting mass model. Right: Optimized potentials displayed on a composite colour image using HST images in the F475W, F814W, F160W pass-bands for RX\u2009J2129 (top) and MACS\u2009J2129 (bottom), and in the F814W, F110W, F160W pass-bands for MS\u20090451 (middle).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab2270fig7.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/304594417/stab2270fig7.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab2270fig7.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"304594417\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/508/1/10.1093_mnras_stab2270/1/stab2270fig7.jpeg?Expires=1639262452&Signature=x2qfdqs62tA~gPwLAqBxSdWufyrpVbASiBXfyT72X8STbUHeGAAZ3J3tKUv-RXr3xgIB1~H5oe9AMt8xUEJ-QNdJv1UM~OHJrZAQYHxrqOQtpR~3AOZmLPoVUTp8uwJYlNCW7BZ3Xll5ZkupTLG3vEe-UApXoRBL4-HRN6u1qqroAB9MfUQeXzP1eIyLkxHUrRHBGv9QOQ8IN~PGZyACcSjo2HQbwwLSOfLCeNaM1z3~ZZCAXSt-VOLP8okoNuWPAZTXQ6BdQ5Ls~v~OJWB3Zg5KKglbDBzltu5yOIBKL522LSXVVU5IujAB~8B~w-d62GDa5vH3N4Ag19FUvJn-7w__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=304594417&ar=6350584&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab2270fig7.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Left:</em> RMS for each multiple image system in RX\u2009J2129 (top), MS\u20090451 (middle), and MACS\u2009J2129 (bottom). The red dashed line shows the rms of the best-fitting mass model. <em>Right:</em> Optimized potentials displayed on a composite colour image using <em>HST</em> images in the F475W, F814W, F160W pass-bands for RX\u2009J2129 (top) and MACS\u2009J2129 (bottom), and in the F814W, F110W, F160W pass-bands for MS\u20090451 (middle).</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig7\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 7.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/508/1/10.1093_mnras_stab2270/1/m_stab2270fig7.jpeg?Expires=1639262452&amp;Signature=SaLndIW-EHh9x73a77~ZIt3TMxs3O4Tl8xHbA8n5tPTE874hnvhMrTHaLKnE7PSe1zQ~zhRweSfzUSfRFul6P2ABLJ7koURiNFz~3CucL-7vYbiwGaw2TjVK6j-Nw6PB-BTScSE6DK6k1R0sJG1vc-x2~u4142~F-2~RVl7TWhyO3lsMBIflP0~p3qdSh6zPDiyajWD58gc5oEnYSyj0CDliV2WvM7-vxrdRUrEnCbwjCtVZ45w1YNTetQj9KG~IbXHhDc-SQNOVjnRgl8tfTHCpRmsGPRPGsCqCZLRwguCCn8~tE4VMX1ZkTOvNrbVQTWBGEv0nkzXpzkjnT0rPSw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Left: RMS for each multiple image system in RX\u2009J2129 (top), MS\u20090451 (middle), and MACS\u2009J2129 (bottom). The red dashed line shows the rms of the best-fitting mass model. Right: Optimized potentials displayed on a composite colour image using HST images in the F475W, F814W, F160W pass-bands for RX\u2009J2129 (top) and MACS\u2009J2129 (bottom), and in the F814W, F110W, F160W pass-bands for MS\u20090451 (middle).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab2270fig7.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/304594417/stab2270fig7.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab2270fig7.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"304594417\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/508/1/10.1093_mnras_stab2270/1/stab2270fig7.jpeg?Expires=1639262452&Signature=x2qfdqs62tA~gPwLAqBxSdWufyrpVbASiBXfyT72X8STbUHeGAAZ3J3tKUv-RXr3xgIB1~H5oe9AMt8xUEJ-QNdJv1UM~OHJrZAQYHxrqOQtpR~3AOZmLPoVUTp8uwJYlNCW7BZ3Xll5ZkupTLG3vEe-UApXoRBL4-HRN6u1qqroAB9MfUQeXzP1eIyLkxHUrRHBGv9QOQ8IN~PGZyACcSjo2HQbwwLSOfLCeNaM1z3~ZZCAXSt-VOLP8okoNuWPAZTXQ6BdQ5Ls~v~OJWB3Zg5KKglbDBzltu5yOIBKL522LSXVVU5IujAB~8B~w-d62GDa5vH3N4Ag19FUvJn-7w__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=304594417&ar=6350584&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab2270fig7.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Left:</em> RMS for each multiple image system in RX\u2009J2129 (top), MS\u20090451 (middle), and MACS\u2009J2129 (bottom). The red dashed line shows the rms of the best-fitting mass model. <em>Right:</em> Optimized potentials displayed on a composite colour image using <em>HST</em> images in the F475W, F814W, F160W pass-bands for RX\u2009J2129 (top) and MACS\u2009J2129 (bottom), and in the F814W, F110W, F160W pass-bands for MS\u20090451 (middle).</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"304594418\" scrollto-destination=\"304594418\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig8\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 8.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/508/1/10.1093_mnras_stab2270/1/m_stab2270fig8.jpeg?Expires=1639262452&amp;Signature=pJ6wyGbHihQflqlAX2J46eRDuu0HGYlzBC2FW55Vrdlmoom8~7hlDrbsk7ML83C9FY3C7xmLnQsB-ORSKkq6MFTCkv65qXe5kiA-0~pHxcPQtrIjTmlHnFH~INPkAUcdKn79hTmLC7qXJxR4pepvIePmgzSY76VKH1Xd5eV1uwy5x6yWRo7zEifB~8EoD--KDysSnPoyA9WkcHG01W5FvU3eC20UW0VxvePLjC3S69yvgXvQh9ig81RrrVfnTU2M72x57J~0~kVJNp4bzsrmHsnraOg2XsRk7dkcB7TqWgIzRIeJ-fVhVlWQUMG1BS4NIPBHRzTK9pQbx2Eht5er6g__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Radial surface density profiles for RX\u2009J2129 (left), MS\u20090451 (middle), and MACS\u2009J2129 (right) derived from the strong-lensing mass models described in this work. Measurements from the fiducial model are shown in grey, and measurements with our new mass models are shown in green. Fiducial models were built based on the analyses of Caminha et\u00a0al. (2019) and Monna et\u00a0al. (2017) for RX\u2009J2129 and MACS\u2009J2129. In each plot, the dashed line stands for the mean surface density, and the shaded areas indicate the 1\u03c3 error bars. The two magenta dashed lines highlight the positions, from the cluster centre, of the closest and most distant multiple image used as constraints for each model.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab2270fig8.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/304594418/stab2270fig8.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab2270fig8.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"304594418\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/508/1/10.1093_mnras_stab2270/1/stab2270fig8.jpeg?Expires=1639262452&Signature=LYMX~gIko6V5WC4wjEcpHVL2ATNPUaqaxwjbLqows9~khHSnj2J5Ug-qAK3qpdnsRu7Zb01tyUa90XgRH1OCj4rTpQ2SGk17TmnAzOlHnfibUlIxldK~AtcGd3B0TrYOXyIeWhuFgKi3oNLecemXW59xPQYapE04CTSt1j265zPjp-J817kXYM3SiC-zZEa-UNZYDVQ16UGWKSwrtK9L0nnXEabEZLNq8k-m9IUQQmeFqCjpRbjutuTv~3kvKlLXk1eXILD1hBL1cjre89vm5J5zLXG~Hf4V9DlpQWuuD1XyVRHHHfJCJU9GRJT8RhU9Y1IyAg6X7jsAGunzPMPQGA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=304594418&ar=6350584&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab2270fig8.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Radial surface density profiles for RX\u2009J2129 (left), MS\u20090451 (middle), and MACS\u2009J2129 (right) derived from the strong-lensing mass models described in this work. Measurements from the <em>fiducial model</em> are shown in grey, and measurements with our new mass models are shown in green. Fiducial models were built based on the analyses of Caminha et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>) and Monna et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) for RX\u2009J2129 and MACS\u2009J2129. In each plot, the dashed line stands for the mean surface density, and the shaded areas indicate the 1\u03c3 error bars. The two magenta dashed lines highlight the positions, from the cluster centre, of the closest and most distant multiple image used as constraints for each model.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig8\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 8.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/508/1/10.1093_mnras_stab2270/1/m_stab2270fig8.jpeg?Expires=1639262452&amp;Signature=pJ6wyGbHihQflqlAX2J46eRDuu0HGYlzBC2FW55Vrdlmoom8~7hlDrbsk7ML83C9FY3C7xmLnQsB-ORSKkq6MFTCkv65qXe5kiA-0~pHxcPQtrIjTmlHnFH~INPkAUcdKn79hTmLC7qXJxR4pepvIePmgzSY76VKH1Xd5eV1uwy5x6yWRo7zEifB~8EoD--KDysSnPoyA9WkcHG01W5FvU3eC20UW0VxvePLjC3S69yvgXvQh9ig81RrrVfnTU2M72x57J~0~kVJNp4bzsrmHsnraOg2XsRk7dkcB7TqWgIzRIeJ-fVhVlWQUMG1BS4NIPBHRzTK9pQbx2Eht5er6g__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Radial surface density profiles for RX\u2009J2129 (left), MS\u20090451 (middle), and MACS\u2009J2129 (right) derived from the strong-lensing mass models described in this work. Measurements from the fiducial model are shown in grey, and measurements with our new mass models are shown in green. Fiducial models were built based on the analyses of Caminha et\u00a0al. (2019) and Monna et\u00a0al. (2017) for RX\u2009J2129 and MACS\u2009J2129. In each plot, the dashed line stands for the mean surface density, and the shaded areas indicate the 1\u03c3 error bars. The two magenta dashed lines highlight the positions, from the cluster centre, of the closest and most distant multiple image used as constraints for each model.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab2270fig8.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/304594418/stab2270fig8.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab2270fig8.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"304594418\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/508/1/10.1093_mnras_stab2270/1/stab2270fig8.jpeg?Expires=1639262452&Signature=LYMX~gIko6V5WC4wjEcpHVL2ATNPUaqaxwjbLqows9~khHSnj2J5Ug-qAK3qpdnsRu7Zb01tyUa90XgRH1OCj4rTpQ2SGk17TmnAzOlHnfibUlIxldK~AtcGd3B0TrYOXyIeWhuFgKi3oNLecemXW59xPQYapE04CTSt1j265zPjp-J817kXYM3SiC-zZEa-UNZYDVQ16UGWKSwrtK9L0nnXEabEZLNq8k-m9IUQQmeFqCjpRbjutuTv~3kvKlLXk1eXILD1hBL1cjre89vm5J5zLXG~Hf4V9DlpQWuuD1XyVRHHHfJCJU9GRJT8RhU9Y1IyAg6X7jsAGunzPMPQGA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=304594418&ar=6350584&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab2270fig8.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Radial surface density profiles for RX\u2009J2129 (left), MS\u20090451 (middle), and MACS\u2009J2129 (right) derived from the strong-lensing mass models described in this work. Measurements from the <em>fiducial model</em> are shown in grey, and measurements with our new mass models are shown in green. Fiducial models were built based on the analyses of Caminha et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>) and Monna et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) for RX\u2009J2129 and MACS\u2009J2129. In each plot, the dashed line stands for the mean surface density, and the shaded areas indicate the 1\u03c3 error bars. The two magenta dashed lines highlight the positions, from the cluster centre, of the closest and most distant multiple image used as constraints for each model.</p></div></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=304594419 id=\"304594419\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5>5 SUMMARY AND CONCLUSIONS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In this paper, we present new strong-lensing mass models for three galaxy clusters, MS\u20090451, MACS\u2009J2129, and RX\u2009J2129, which include new VLT/MUSE observations. We combine the MUSE datacubes with high-resolution imaging from <em>HST</em> available for each cluster to maximize the number of extracted spectra. We measure the redshift of each source with a dedicated software, <span class=\"small-caps\">ifs-redex</span> (Rexroth et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib82\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib82\" data-open=\"bib82\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), allowing for a wavelet-based filtration of the spectra. Our conclusions are as follows:</p><ul class=\"roman-lower\"><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">We measure 158, 171, and 189 secured or likely spectroscopic redshifts in the RX\u2009J2129, MS\u20090451, and MACS\u2009J2129 MUSE datacubes, respectively. For MS\u20090451, we identify two new systems of multiple images located in the north of the cluster core, the least constrained region, confirm the redshift of System A measured by Borys et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>), and measure the redshift of the three multiple images of System G. For RX\u2009J2129 and MACS\u2009J2129, we obtain measurements in excellent agreement with Caminha et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>). We report a new multiple image system detection, System 10 at <em>z</em> = 4.41, in MACS\u2009J2129. Finally, the MUSE datacubes allowed us to spectroscopically confirm 43, 112, and 89 cluster members in RX\u2009J2129, MS\u20090451, and MACS\u2009J2129, respectively. Among those, in RX\u2009J2129 and MACS\u2009J2129, 15 and 4 cluster members, respectively, are new identifications, i.e. not reported by Caminha et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>).</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">We carried out a fruitful blind search while combining <em>HST</em> imaging with MUSE datacubes using <span class=\"small-caps\">muselet</span>. It played a decisive role in the identification of multiple image systems, since it highlighted strong emission lines invisible in the <em>HST</em> images due to either the faintness of the sources at wavelengths not corresponding to maximum emissions, or their proximity to luminous emitters in the foreground. This was particularly interesting for MS\u20090451 where the blind search revealed Systems R and S, both located in the north of the cluster, which before this analysis was lacking strong-lensing constraints.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">Our models are optimized using the parametric version of the <span class=\"small-caps\">Lenstool</span> algorithm (Jullo et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>). The multiple image systems in the three clusters were reproduced with an rms of 0.28, 0.6, and 0.74\u00a0arcsec in RX\u2009J2129, MS\u20090451, and MACS\u2009J2129, respectively. We measure integrated aperture masses in good agreement or within the error bars of the ones published in previous analyses (Berciano Alba et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib11\" data-open=\"bib11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Richard et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib83\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib83\" data-open=\"bib83\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Zitrin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib104\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib104\" data-open=\"bib104\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011b</a>; Zitrin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib105\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib105\" data-open=\"bib105\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Monna et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Desprez et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Caminha et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>).</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">The addition of a second cluster-scale halo in MS\u20090451 and MACS\u2009J2129 mass models are necessary to minimize the rms of the two models, and to recover the multiple image systems geometry in the north and north-east of the two clusters, respectively. Caminha et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>) presented a similar mass model for MACS\u2009J2129, with their second cluster-scale halo located in the same region as us, slightly closer to the BCG than in our case, \u223c250\u2009kpc away from the BCG compared to \u223c320\u2009kpc in our case. Similarly, the addition of some cluster galaxies located in the vicinity of multiple images played a decisive role in the reconstruction of the mass distribution, e.g. the rms of MACS\u2009J2129 improved from 0.95 to 0.74\u00a0arcsec just by the addition of G4.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">We compare our magnification measurements of the submillimetric galaxy group multiply lensed by MS\u20090451, at <em>z</em> = 2.91, with the results published by MacKenzie et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). The two analyses show excellent agreement, with some differences for the most highly magnified images. This was to be expected as magnification measurements close to the critical line, mathematically a region where magnification is supposed to be infinite, have high uncertainties.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">Our mass model of MACS\u2009J2129 allowed us to measure the magnification of the singly imaged <em>z</em> = 2.1472 galaxy identified by Toft et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib95\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib95\" data-open=\"bib95\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), \u03bc = 3.7\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.2. This values is within the error bars of the initial measurement from Toft et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib95\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib95\" data-open=\"bib95\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), \u03bc<sub>Toft + 17</sub> = 4.2\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.6, which was derived using a mass model only constrained by two systems of multiple images, namely Systems 1 and 3 from our analysis.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">Further investigations have to be carried out to identify the missing counter-images presented in Table\u2009 <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl9\" data-open=\"tbl9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a>, and confirm System P in MS\u20090451. Moreover, we identify a group of galaxies at <em>z</em> = 0.06 in MS\u20090451 that impacts the multiple image geometry, strengthening the need to properly implement multiplane optimization in <span class=\"small-caps\">Lenstool</span>.</p></li></ul><p class=\"chapter-para\">More generally, our analysis highlights again the power of MUSE to secure and identify strong-lensing features in cluster cores. Such observations are mandatory to recover precisely and accurately the mass distribution in cluster cores. Without such lensing mass models, cluster lenses cannot be used efficiently as gravitational telescopes, as the mass distribution needs to be known in order to recover the intrinsic physical properties of the lensed galaxies (Vanzella et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib98\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib98\" data-open=\"bib98\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Patr\u00edcio et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib78\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib78\" data-open=\"bib78\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Toft et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib95\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib95\" data-open=\"bib95\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Johnson et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Claeyssens et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>). Moreover, the physics in place in clusters themselves is highly dependent on how well we can recover their mass distribution. Indeed, while a multiwavelength analysis is needed to observe all their components (stars and gas), only gravitational lensing gives us an estimate of their total mass, and thus indirectly of their dark matter content and distribution. With such knowledge, we can hope to use galaxy clusters as probes of the nature of dark matter (Jauzac et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016b</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Robertson et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib87\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib87\" data-open=\"bib87\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>).</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=304594423 id=\"304594423\" class=\"backsection-title js-splitscreen-backsection-title\" data-legacy-id=sec7>SUPPORTING INFORMATION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\"><strong>Table A1</strong>. List of redshifts measured with a quality flag larger than 2 in RX\u2009J2129.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><strong>Table A2</strong>. List of spectroscopically confirmed redshifts in MS\u20090451.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><strong>Table A3</strong>. List of measured redshifts in MACS\u2009J2129.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Please note: Oxford University Press is not responsible for the content or functionality of any supporting materials supplied by the authors. Any queries (other than missing material) should be directed to the corresponding author for the article.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=304594428 id=\"304594428\" class=\"backacknowledgements-title js-splitscreen-backacknowledgements-title\" data-legacy-id=ack1>ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">MJ is supported by the United Kingdom Research and Innovation.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=304594430 id=\"304594430\" class=\"backsection-title js-splitscreen-backsection-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6>DATA AVAILABILITY</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The data underlying this article will be shared on reasonable request to the corresponding author.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=304594432 id=\"304594432\" data-id=\"bib9\"><div class=\"mixed-citation citation\"><p class=\"mixed-citation-compatibility\"><span class=\"person-group\"><span class=\"name string-name\"><div class=\"surname\">Belli</div>  <div    <h3 scrollto-destination=304594442 id=\"304594442\" class=\"appendix-title js-splitscreen-appendix-title\" data-legacy-id=sec8>APPENDIX A: LIST OF SECURE AND LIKELY REDSHIFTS EXTRACTED FROM THE MUSE DATACUBES</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We here give the redshifts extracted with a quality flag greater than 2 (i.e. secure or likely) from the MUSE datacubes in Tables <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl11\" data-open=\"tbl11\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A1</a>\u2013<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl13\" data-open=\"tbl13\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A3</a> for RX\u2009J2129, MS\u20090451, and MACS\u2009J2129, respectively.</p>                        <a id=\"304594444\" scrollto-destination=\"304594444\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl11\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl11\" data-id=\"tbl11\"><span class=\"label\">Table A1.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">List of redshifts measured with a quality flag larger than 2 in RX\u2009J2129. Column (1) is the ID of the source (\u2018sing\u2019 and \u2018cont\u2019 stand for singular and continuum emission line in the <span class=\"small-caps\">muselet</span> catalogue). If it exists, the index stands for the pointing\u2019s number. Columns (2) and (3) are the RA and the Dec. in degrees (J2000). Column (4) is the redshift of the source, and column (5) is the systematic error on the redshift. Column (6) is the QF of the determination. Full table is available as online material.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>ID<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=304594447 id=\"304594447\" class=\"appendix-title js-splitscreen-appendix-title\" data-legacy-id=sec9>APPENDIX B: MULTIPLE IMAGE SYSTEMS WITH MUSE SPECTROSCOPY</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We here provide the MUSE spectra of the newly identified multiple image systems in MS\u20090451, System R and S, and display each system on a composite colour <em>HST</em> stamp in Fig.\u2009<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-figB1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"figB1\" data-open=\"figB1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">B1</a>. We provide similar information for System G in Fig.\u2009<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-figB2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"figB2\" data-open=\"figB2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">B2</a>. We refer the reader to Caminha et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>) for RX\u2009J2129 and MACS\u2009J2129.</p>                        <a id=\"304594449\" scrollto-destination=\"304594449\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"figB1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure B1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/508/1/10.1093_mnras_stab2270/1/m_stab2270figb1.jpeg?Expires=1639262452&amp;Signature=YsODyUO9FRqf9lkVqV3kwErirQVHSPvHtH~ffeZxYlyMItiOxtH1LpxarriuHuavQtfqBuWCwTwYh-KerCLHt2FguAm7qVOMbZ4yY8ieqOZvtDP5Lt3w83Bqvad8G0wOQDA-jgjz2AlDSNj7qEH8yUpH50dD8FlGzVxWihtn~AJQBuSjQ8p-AytdubDUJG76lmmefZ8SyUqmOgURrm8X1TEKe~kj8QRdk7R0LtmroMiLCQrR9jRhaNpWW84oBYF8YmXrrm4Z82lpYn-KPWKvZihFmGZ7ZdnNcnFFIlQMwr5ePC70O-6nRkjvYNg95eFJY~wncqAWoNyRnRL7SMTSCg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"MS\u20090451 \u2013 Newly identified multiple image systems with MUSE. Top: Systems R (left, z = 3.7645) and S (right, z = 4.4514) on a composite colour HST image. Middle:muselet narrow-band datacube at the wavelength corresponding to the maximum emission of the source, i.e. \u03bb = 5793\u2009\u00c5 for System R (left) and \u03bb = 6628\u2009\u00c5 for System S (right). Magenta contours are computed at intensities of 2.0, 3.0, and 4.0\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010\u221220\u2009erg\u00a0s\u22121\u00a0cm\u22122 for both systems, except for image R.3, where the contours are computed for an intensity of 1.0\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010\u221220\u2009erg\u00a0s\u22121\u00a0arcsec\u22122. Magenta contours are computed at intensities of 2.0, 3.0, and 4.0\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>\u221220</sup>\u2009erg\u00a0s<sup>\u2212</sup><sup>1</sup>\u00a0cm<sup>\u2212</sup><sup>2</sup> for both systems, except for image R.3, where the contours are computed for an intensity of 1.0\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>\u221220</sup>\u2009erg\u00a0s<sup>\u2212</sup><sup>1</sup>\u00a0arcsec<sup>\u22122</sup>. <em>Bottom</em>: MUSE spectra of the multiple images centred on the most prominent line.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"figB1\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure B1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/508/1/10.1093_mnras_stab2270/1/m_stab2270figb1.jpeg?Expires=1639262452&amp;Signature=YsODyUO9FRqf9lkVqV3kwErirQVHSPvHtH~ffeZxYlyMItiOxtH1LpxarriuHuavQtfqBuWCwTwYh-KerCLHt2FguAm7qVOMbZ4yY8ieqOZvtDP5Lt3w83Bqvad8G0wOQDA-jgjz2AlDSNj7qEH8yUpH50dD8FlGzVxWihtn~AJQBuSjQ8p-AytdubDUJG76lmmefZ8SyUqmOgURrm8X1TEKe~kj8QRdk7R0LtmroMiLCQrR9jRhaNpWW84oBYF8YmXrrm4Z82lpYn-KPWKvZihFmGZ7ZdnNcnFFIlQMwr5ePC70O-6nRkjvYNg95eFJY~wncqAWoNyRnRL7SMTSCg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"MS\u20090451 \u2013 Newly identified multiple image systems with MUSE. Top: Systems R (left, z = 3.7645) and S (right, z = 4.4514) on a composite colour HST image. Middle:muselet narrow-band datacube at the wavelength corresponding to the maximum emission of the source, i.e. \u03bb = 5793\u2009\u00c5 for System R (left) and \u03bb = 6628\u2009\u00c5 for System S (right). Magenta contours are computed at intensities of 2.0, 3.0, and 4.0\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010\u221220\u2009erg\u00a0s\u22121\u00a0cm\u22122 for both systems, except for image R.3, where the contours are computed for an intensity of 1.0\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010\u221220\u2009erg\u00a0s\u22121\u00a0arcsec\u22122. Bottom: MUSE spectra of the multiple images centred on the most prominent line.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab2270figb1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/304594449/stab2270figb1.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab2270figb1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"304594449\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/508/1/10.1093_mnras_stab2270/1/stab2270figb1.jpeg?Expires=1639262452&Signature=1L62jAhiQW4HYHqSe6S~tk3anS65Rv24WSlqkgo7-Er1d4btWLFZiFbLB6H0KHM3ZS8dtEIsckAiU8DT9I8CGEdogc5MUBbxFcqGs9KbpLEfq0pU9rLsPwo85fXKBWzUCPMPXXdIbctoFiDADCoHc5yc-znBpaSChlD0AI2xbl~VuFFfZLn6A2htj4eUgLY871yAbALPFsgKoNqNwWNDElyfjoi9T87xSEnQjMZnerUAkFMyTR1GFE49HnszpDkuSBlKd9UllKjbFXvPyMcK-Pyf-Sxl1Jfb5ngmB-cAwBeRCeU~U-CzHLWdVDcaCQkDAVidBp2e9UBjldHuZywtTA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=304594449&ar=6350584&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab2270figb1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><strong>MS\u20090451 \u2013</strong> Newly identified multiple image systems with MUSE. <em>Top:</em> Systems R (left, <em>z</em> = 3.7645) and S (right, <em>z</em> = 4.4514) on a composite colour <em>HST</em> image. <em>Middle:</em><span class=\"small-caps\">muselet</span> narrow-band datacube at the wavelength corresponding to the maximum emission of the source, i.e. \u03bb = 5793\u2009\u00c5 for System R (left) and \u03bb = 6628\u2009\u00c5 for System S (right). Magenta contours are computed at intensities of 2.0, 3.0, and 4.0\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>\u221220</sup>\u2009erg\u00a0s<sup>\u2212</sup><sup>1</sup>\u00a0cm<sup>\u2212</sup><sup>2</sup> for both systems, except for image R.3, where the contours are computed for an intensity of 1.0\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>\u221220</sup>\u2009erg\u00a0s<sup>\u2212</sup><sup>1</sup>\u00a0arcsec<sup>\u22122</sup>. <em>Bottom</em>: MUSE spectra of the multiple images centred on the most prominent line.</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"304594450\" scrollto-destination=\"304594450\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"figB2\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure B2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/508/1/10.1093_mnras_stab2270/1/m_stab2270figb2.jpeg?Expires=1639262452&amp;Signature=u8uS7ACKnw6rwZ-Lh~~CfUS879g~7R8wAozA~k6kpd0q5gboQwAJJk6tnEjUNp2IFhoHX-vwnncScyVfpd29UWjWBwyrCGzrFXOO3iLA1SPS1ukGFrAHCiz3UY1WA6klQYytLbxn~CwGPn1PuI5B8xh36JpUnukPMUI8l8mjEfEnC6t-S6FsCsZkrtmR0ECLDkz3FlIv5QyTv~ySbxFHAjRK4AYqWjyP5RWB-YlxSZmHCEPwbKzDlC-AW9CVPLQFaGp3JxA01MjvWB4A2J2inkI8cXYJgS4f66VXQEwDMiP1U8Si0gq6aWGrsLHX6~fOg179-YOI46jqeHY-8DfwBg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"MS\u20090451 \u2013 System G (z = 2.93) identified by Takata et\u00a0al. (2003), and spectroscopically confirmed with MUSE. Top: Composite colour HST images. Middle: muselet narrow-band datacube stamp at the wavelength of the maximum emission of the source, i.e. \u03bb = 4780\u2009\u00c5. The contours are displayed in magenta for 2, 3, and 4\u2009\u00d7 10\u221220\u2009erg\u00a0s\u22121\u00a0arcsec\u22122. Bottom: MUSE extracted spectra of the multiple images.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab2270figb2.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/304594450/stab2270figb2.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab2270figb2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"304594450\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/508/1/10.1093_mnras_stab2270/1/stab2270figb2.jpeg?Expires=1639262452&Signature=q9gC-WSWCNw8P8mdpAFmPPtlzWOPY6YUdGUw6WL1FpSlG~a-CehjVTrNtWQXyw26g9dcxx0K2MXpfrH1r1aXMkCU8M1BEygqfJ1HsoyG8rQZfgUDcRmJKPpVBl2NjJZm9vsvA4VspFaEqOYgZ1MY19hhhlJ4u~-YnIQX12izzN7zlwDMo8Z~p4KvReBbaz6vsJCsAgK8hy4x0owFGzXtoiRJMb127caheZc1vrC~NzV9KKA~6D8Yscs0mcHQLvKE1AJy9kOaGo7n7qe5t~E2webjm0JAqzQ3UXT84LbTJAtb4UdmCfqrNkNwyLzQFaXYCBzwxFLBghmvx9p~~KZ-wQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=304594450&ar=6350584&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab2270figb2.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><strong>MS\u20090451 \u2013</strong> System G (<em>z</em> = 2.93) identified by Takata et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib93\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib93\" data-open=\"bib93\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>), and spectroscopically confirmed with MUSE. <em>Top:</em> Composite colour <em>HST</em> images. <em>Middle</em>: <span class=\"small-caps\">muselet</span> narrow-band datacube stamp at the wavelength of the maximum emission of the source, i.e. \u03bb = 4780\u2009\u00c5. The contours are displayed in magenta for 2, 3, and 4\u2009\u00d7 10<sup>\u221220</sup>\u2009erg\u00a0s<sup>\u2212</sup><sup>1</sup>\u00a0arcsec<sup>\u22122</sup>. <em>Bottom</em>: MUSE extracted spectra of the multiple images.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"figB2\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure B2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/508/1/10.1093_mnras_stab2270/1/m_stab2270figb2.jpeg?Expires=1639262452&amp;Signature=u8uS7ACKnw6rwZ-Lh~~CfUS879g~7R8wAozA~k6kpd0q5gboQwAJJk6tnEjUNp2IFhoHX-vwnncScyVfpd29UWjWBwyrCGzrFXOO3iLA1SPS1ukGFrAHCiz3UY1WA6klQYytLbxn~CwGPn1PuI5B8xh36JpUnukPMUI8l8mjEfEnC6t-S6FsCsZkrtmR0ECLDkz3FlIv5QyTv~ySbxFHAjRK4AYqWjyP5RWB-YlxSZmHCEPwbKzDlC-AW9CVPLQFaGp3JxA01MjvWB4A2J2inkI8cXYJgS4f66VXQEwDMiP1U8Si0gq6aWGrsLHX6~fOg179-YOI46jqeHY-8DfwBg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"MS\u20090451 \u2013 System G (z = 2.93) identified by Takata et\u00a0al. (function () {\r\n            var hfSiteUrl = document.getElementById('hfSiteURL');\r\n            var siteUrl = hfSiteUrl.value;\r\n            var subdomainIndex = siteUrl.indexOf('/');\r\n\r\n href=\"/mnras/search-results?f_Authors=Christoph+Sch%c3%a4fer\">Oxford Academic</a>\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n    <div class=\"info-card-search info-card-search-google\">\r\n        <a href=\"http://scholar.google.com/scholar?q=author:%22Sch&#228;fer Christoph%22\">Google Scholar</a>\r\n    </div>\r\n    <div class=\"info-card-search info-card-search-ads\">\r\n        <a                </span>\r\n                                <span class=\"al-author-name-more js-flyout-wrap\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                                    <a class=\"linked-name </div>\r\n\r\n    <div class=\"info-card-affilitation\">\r\n        <div class=\"aff\"><div class=\"institution\">Institute of Physics, Laboratory of Astrophysics, Ecole Polytechnique           </span>\r\n\r\n                    </div>\r\n                </div>\r\n<div class=\"pub-history-wrap clearfix js-history-dropdown-wrap\">\r\n\r\n        <div class=\"pub-history-row class=\"toolbar-wrap js-toolbar-wrap\">\r\n                <div class=\"toolbar-inner-wrap\">\r\n                    <ul id=\"Toolbar\" role=\"navigation\">\r\n    <li class=\"toolbar-item item-pdf </div>\r\n</div>\r\n<input id=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" name=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"False\" />\r\n\r\n<input id=\"routename\" name=\"RouteName\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"mnras\" /> \r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n                    </div>\r\n                </div>\r\n            </div>\r\n            <div id=\"ContentTab\" class=\"content active\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleFulltext widget-instance-OUP_Article_FullText_Widget\">\r\n        <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\" data-widgetname=\"ArticleFulltext\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                    <h2 scrollto-destination=304594307 id=\"304594307\" class=\"abstract-title js-splitscreen-abstract-title\" >ABSTRACT</h2>\r\n<section class=\"abstract\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">We present strong-lensing analyses of three galaxy clusters, RX\u2009J2129.4\u00a0+\u00a00009 (<em>z</em> = 0.235), MS\u20090451.6\u00a0\u2212\u00a00305 (<em>z</em> = 0.55), and MACS\u2009J2129.4\u00a0\u2212\u00a00741 (<em>z</em> = 0.589), using the powerful combination of <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> (<em>HST</em>) multiband observations, and Multi-Unit Spectroscopic Explorer (MUSE) spectroscopy. In RX\u2009J2129, we newly spectroscopically confirm 15 cluster members. Our resulting mass model uses 8 multiple image systems as we include a galaxy\u2013galaxy lensing system north-east of the cluster, and is composed of 71 haloes including one dark matter cluster-scale halo and two galaxy-scale haloes optimized individually. For MS\u20090451, we report the spectroscopic identification of two new systems of multiple images in the northern region and 112 cluster members. Our mass model uses 16 multiple image systems and 146 haloes, including 2 large-scale haloes and 7 galaxy-scale haloes independently optimized. For MACS\u2009J2129, we report the spectroscopic identification of one new multiple image system at <em>z</em> = 4.41, and newly measure spectroscopic redshifts for four cluster members. Our mass model uses 14 multiple image systems, and is composed of 151 haloes, including 2 large-scale haloes and 4 galaxy-scale haloes independently optimized. Our best models have rms of 0.29, 0.6, 0.74\u00a0arcsec in the image plane for RX\u2009J2129, MS\u20090451, and MACS\u2009J2129, respectively. This analysis presents a detailed comparison with the existing literature showing excellent agreements, and discuss specific studies of lensed galaxies, e.g. a group of submillimetre galaxies at <em>z</em> = 2.9 in MS\u20090451, and a bright <em>z</em> = 2.1472 red singly imaged galaxy in MACS\u2009J2129.</p></section>                        <div class=\"article-metadata-panel clearfix at-ArticleMetadata\"></div>\r\n<div class=\"kwd-group\"><a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;gravitational lensing: strong&quot;\">gravitational lensing: strong</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;Techniques: imaging spectroscopy&quot;\">Techniques: imaging spectroscopy</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;Galaxies: clusters: general&quot;\">Galaxies: clusters: general</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;Galaxies: clusters: individual (RX\u2009J2129.4\u00a0+\u00a00009, MS\u20090451.6\u00a0\u2212\u00a00305, MACS\u2009J2129.4\u00a0\u2212\u00a00741)&quot;\">Galaxies: clusters: individual (RX\u2009J2129.4\u00a0+\u00a00009, MS\u20090451.6\u00a0\u2212\u00a00305, MACS\u2009J2129.4\u00a0\u2212\u00a00741)</a></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=304594309 id=\"304594309\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec1>1 INTRODUCTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Clusters of galaxies are the most spectacular strong lenses in the Universe. Due to the high-mass density in their cores, it is not uncommon to observe giant arcs and multiple images of sources located behind them. This gravitational lensing effect distorts, and magnifies the light emitted by background galaxies, transforming these clusters into cosmic telescopes (for a review, see e.g. Massey, Kitching &amp; Richard <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib70\" data-open=\"bib70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Kneib &amp; Natarajan <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Hoekstra et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Treu &amp; Ellis <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib96\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib96\" data-open=\"bib96\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Kilbinger <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Bartelmann &amp; Maturi <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). Such strong-lensing features are extremely useful to map the total mass distribution within the central regions of clusters (e.g. Richard et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib84\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib84\" data-open=\"bib84\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Jauzac et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib41\" data-open=\"bib41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Johnson et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Coe, Bradley &amp; Zitrin <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Caminha et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017b</a>; Williams et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib101\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib101\" data-open=\"bib101\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Diego et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib25\" data-open=\"bib25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Mahler et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib67\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib67\" data-open=\"bib67\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Lagattuta et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>; Sharon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib90\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib90\" data-open=\"bib90\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>). These mass models can then be used to constrain the physics of Dark Matter, such as its self-interaction cross-section (see Harvey et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Wittman, Golovich &amp; Dawson <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib102\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib102\" data-open=\"bib102\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), or test the cosmological paradigm (e.g. Jullo et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib52\" data-open=\"bib52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010a</a>; Acebron et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1\" data-open=\"bib1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Natarajan et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib74\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib74\" data-open=\"bib74\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Jauzac et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), but also to probe the early Universe and thus the epoch of reionization (e.g. Atek et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2\" data-open=\"bib2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Bouwens et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Livermore, Finkelstein &amp; Lotz <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib64\" data-open=\"bib64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Atek et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Ishigaki et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). Hence, the need to have accurate and precise mass models for a large number of galaxy clusters.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Over the past two decades, the precision of strong-lensing mass modeling of galaxy clusters has dramatically increased. This is mainly due to the combination of powerful post-processing algorithms and high resolution imaging. On the one hand, the use of the Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) sampling of the parameter space in the Bayesian framework allowed for robust estimations of the most likely mass models for a given set of constraints (e.g. our team uses <span class=\"small-caps\">Lenstool</span> which is presented in Kneib et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib57\" data-open=\"bib57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>; Jullo et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010b</a>; Niemiec et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib77\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib77\" data-open=\"bib77\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>). On the other hand, the quality of observations with the <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> (<em>HST</em>) provided astronomers with the deepest and highest resolution images of strong-lensing clusters (e.g. Postman et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib79\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib79\" data-open=\"bib79\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Schmidt et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib89\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib89\" data-open=\"bib89\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Treu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib97\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib97\" data-open=\"bib97\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Lotz et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib65\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib65\" data-open=\"bib65\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Steinhardt et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib92\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib92\" data-open=\"bib92\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>, see also the webpages of <em>Hubble</em> Frontier Fields,<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn1\" data-open=\"fn1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">1</a></sup> GLASS,<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn2\" data-open=\"fn2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">2</a></sup> RELICS<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn3\" data-open=\"fn3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">3</a></sup>, and BUFFALO<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn4\" data-open=\"fn4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">4</a></sup> surveys). This resulted in mass models with an unrivalled precision for numerous galaxy clusters (e.g. Zitrin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib104\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib104\" data-open=\"bib104\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011b</a>; Richard et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib84\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib84\" data-open=\"bib84\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Johnson et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Jauzac et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Diego et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). High-resolution imaging allows precise measurements of the location of multiple images. However, if their exact distance, i.e. their redshift, is not measured, then mass models are highly degenerate, and the resulting mass distribution is biased, hence the strong need for measurements of spectroscopic redshifts (\u0394<em>z</em> &lt; 0.01, see Lagattuta et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib59\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib59\" data-open=\"bib59\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Richard et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib85\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib85\" data-open=\"bib85\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Grillo et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Jauzac et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016a</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>; Mahler et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib67\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib67\" data-open=\"bib67\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib68\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib68\" data-open=\"bib68\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>; Lagattuta et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>; Remolina Gonz\u00e1lez, Sharon &amp; Mahler <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib80\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib80\" data-open=\"bib80\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). As shown in Johnson &amp; Sharon (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>), Cerny et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), and Remolina Gonz\u00e1lez et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib80\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib80\" data-open=\"bib80\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), the spectroscopic redshift information is mandatory in order to obtain precise strong-lensing mass models.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The Multi-Unit Spectroscopic Explorer (MUSE; Bacon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib4\" data-open=\"bib4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) is a second-generation integral field spectrograph at the Very Large Telescope (VLT). MUSE large field of view of 1\u2009arcmin<sup>2</sup> is perfectly adapted to the observation of the core of galaxy clusters (Richard et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib85\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib85\" data-open=\"bib85\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib86\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib86\" data-open=\"bib86\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2021</a>; Grillo et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Caminha et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017a</a>,<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">b</a>; Chiriv\u00ec et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Rescigno et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib81\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib81\" data-open=\"bib81\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>), where most multiple images are likely to be observed (e.g. Kneib &amp; Natarajan <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>). Its high sensitivity between 4750\u2009\u00c5 and 9350\u2009\u00c5 enables the detection of sources with redshifts up to <em>z</em> = 6 (Bacon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). Over the past 6\u00a0years, strong cluster lenses have been commonly observed with MUSE, leading to the measurement of spectroscopic redshifts for multiple images, their multiplicity confirmation, as well as the identification of new multiple image systems which are not even detected in <em>HST</em> observations (e.g. Richard et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib85\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib85\" data-open=\"bib85\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Jauzac et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016a</a>; Caminha et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017a</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>; Lagattuta et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In this paper, we present MUSE observations, and their subsequent strong-lensing analyses, for three well-known galaxy clusters: RX\u2009J2129.4\u00a0+\u00a00009, MS\u20090451.6\u00a0\u2212\u00a00305, and MACS\u2009J2129.4\u00a0\u2212\u00a00741. These clusters have been observed with <em>HST</em>, and already have strong-lensing mass models published in the literature (more details are given bellow, but e.g. Richard et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib83\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib83\" data-open=\"bib83\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Zitrin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib104\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib104\" data-open=\"bib104\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011b</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib105\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib105\" data-open=\"bib105\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; MacKenzie et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Monna et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Caminha et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>) which are used as references in this analysis, and referred to as <em>fiducial models</em> in the rest of the paper).</p><ul class=\"roman-lower\"><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">RX\u2009J2129.4 + 0009 (<em>z</em> = 0.235, RX\u2009J2129 hereafter) was observed as part of the CLASH survey, and was first modelled with <span class=\"small-caps\">Lenstool</span> for the Local Cluster Substructure Survey (LoCuSS, PI: G. P. Smith, see Richard et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib83\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib83\" data-open=\"bib83\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>). This model relied on a single system of multiple images which redshift was updated by Belli et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). Then, Zitrin et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib105\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib105\" data-open=\"bib105\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) published a model which uses four multiple image systems, two being spectroscopically confirmed. Desprez et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) presented a revised model, including one galaxy\u2013galaxy lensing system located \u223c80\u00a0arcsec from the cluster centre, in the vicinity of an isolated cluster galaxy. Finally, Caminha et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>) presented a strong-lensing mass model which takes advantage of the MUSE observations presented in this paper.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">MS\u20090451.6\u00a0\u2212\u00a00305 (<em>z</em> = 0.55 \u2212 MS\u20090451 hereafter) is originally known for its large brightness in the X-rays (e.g. Ellingson et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>; Molnar et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib71\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib71\" data-open=\"bib71\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>; LaRoque et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib61\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib61\" data-open=\"bib61\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>; Gioia et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1990</a>; Donahue et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>; Geach et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>), and hosts several strongly lensed submillimetric sources with radio counterparts (e.g. Takata et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib93\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib93\" data-open=\"bib93\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>; Borys et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>; Berciano Alba et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib11\" data-open=\"bib11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; MacKenzie et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). Increasingly precise strong-lensing mass models were obtained by Borys et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>), Berciano Alba et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>), Zitrin et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib104\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib104\" data-open=\"bib104\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011b</a>), and most recently by MacKenzie et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>), where they included sub-millimetre detections. The latter relies on 8 multiple image systems located in the south of the cluster, leaving the north poorly constrained. However, more recent imaging with <em>HST</em>, and spectroscopy with VLT/X-Shooter and Keck/LRIS, allowed the identification of 8 new multiple image systems, including a quintuple image at redshift <em>z</em> = 6.7 in the north (Knudsen et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Richard et\u00a0al. in preparation). The giant arc identified in Borys et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>), and the system at redshift <em>z</em> = 6.7, are the only multiple image systems with confirmed spectroscopic redshifts.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">MACS\u2009J2129.4\u00a0\u2212\u00a00741 (<em>z</em> = 0.589 \u2212 MACS\u2009J2129 hereafter; Ebeling et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib27\" data-open=\"bib27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>) is part of the Cluster Lensing And Supernova survey with <em>Hubble</em> (CLASH; Postman et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib79\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib79\" data-open=\"bib79\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). It was modelled by Zitrin et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib103\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib103\" data-open=\"bib103\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011a</a>) and more recently by Monna et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) using CLASH photometry (Zitrin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib105\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib105\" data-open=\"bib105\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>), and VLT-VIMOS spectroscopic data (Rosati et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib88\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib88\" data-open=\"bib88\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). Among the 9 multiple image systems used in the mass model presented by Monna et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), two systems are not spectroscopically confirmed. Then, Caminha et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>) presented a strong-lensing model using <span class=\"small-caps\">Lenstool</span>, which takes advantage of the MUSE observations presented in this work.</p></li></ul><p class=\"chapter-para\">This paper is organized as follows. Section \u2009<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">2</a> presents the details of the pipeline used to extract the spectra from the MUSE datacubes. Section\u2009 <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2-4\"></span><a href=\"#sec2-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">2.4</a> describes redshift measurements, and presents our results for the three galaxy clusters. Section\u2009<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">3</a> details the strong-lensing mass models of RX\u2009J2129, MS\u20090451, and MACS\u2009J2129. Section\u2009<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4</a> presents our results and discusses them with regards to previous strong-lensing analyses of these clusters. We finally conclude in Section\u2009<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5</a>. Throughout the paper, we assume a standard cosmological model with \u03a9<sub><em>M</em></sub> = 0.3, \u03a9<sub>\u039b</sub> = 0.7, and <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> = 70\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u2009Mpc<sup>\u22121</sup>. At the redshift of RX\u2009J2129 (<em>z</em> = 0.235), 1\u00a0arcsec covers a physical distance of 3.3734\u2009kpc. At the redshift of MS\u20090451 (<em>z</em> = 0.55), 1\u00a0arcsec covers a physical distance of 6.412\u2009kpc. Finally, for MACS\u2009J2129 (<em>z</em> = 0.589), 1\u00a0arcsec corresponds to 6.63\u2009kpc. All magnitudes are measured using AB system.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=304594316 id=\"304594316\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2>2 MUSE OBSERVATIONS AND ANALYSIS</h2>\r\n                    <h3 scrollto-destination=304594317 id=\"304594317\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-1>2.1 Observations and data reduction</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">RX\u2009J2129, MS\u20090451, and MACS\u2009J2129 were observed with MUSE on the VLT. Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> gives the details of the observations, including dates, pointing positions, ID, seeing conditions, and total exposure time for each data set. Observations were taken using MUSE WFM-NOAO-N mode, in good seeing conditions with full width at half maximum (FWHM) of \u2248\u20090.5, 0.8, and 0.9\u00a0arcsec for RX\u2009J2129, MS\u20090451, and MACS\u2009J2129, respectively. At each pointing, three exposures were taken, slightly shifted (by \u223c0.5\u00a0arcsec) in order to mitigate systematics from the image slicer and detectors.</p>                        <a id=\"304594319\" scrollto-destination=\"304594319\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl1\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl1\" data-id=\"tbl1\"><span class=\"label\">Table 1.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Summary of MUSE observations for all three clusters. Columns\u00a01\u20133 indicate, respectively, the name of the cluster, its average redshift, and the ID of the ESO programme (PI: Kneib for all observations). For each pointing, we give the observation date in column\u00a04, the total exposure time in column\u00a05, the right ascension (R\u2009A), and declination (Decl.) of the centre of the field of view in columns\u00a06 and\u00a07, and the FWHM of the seeing during the observations in column\u00a08.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Cluster<span aria-hidden=\"true\"
