aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>[J2000]<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>(arcsec)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>RX\u2009J2129\u00a0</td><td>0.235\u00a0</td><td>097.A-0909(A)\u00a0</td><td>2016-08-05\u00a0</td><td>8940\u00a0</td><td>322.42149\u00a0</td><td>0.09310\u00a0</td><td>0.5\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>2016-09-04\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>322.41189\u00a0</td><td>0.08682\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>MS\u20090451\u00a0</td><td>0.55\u00a0</td><td>096.A-0105(A)\u00a0</td><td>2016-01-10\u00a0</td><td>8682\u00a0</td><td>73.55165\u00a0</td><td>\u22123.01837\u00a0</td><td>0.8\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>2016-01-11\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>73.54106\u00a0</td><td>\u22123.00965\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>MACS\u2009J2129\u00a0</td><td>0.589\u00a0</td><td>095.A-0525(A)\u00a0</td><td>2015-06-17\u00a0</td><td>8772\u00a0</td><td>322.36602\u00a0</td><td>\u22127.69040\u00a0</td><td>0.9\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>322.35192\u00a0</td><td>\u22127.69040\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/304594319\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The data were reduced with version 1.6.4 of the standard MUSE pipeline (Weilbacher et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib100\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib100\" data-open=\"bib100\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib99\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib99\" data-open=\"bib99\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>). We use a set of standard calibration exposures taken daily to produce bias, arcs, and flat-field master calibration files. Dark current is neglected due to its very low value with MUSE (\u22481\u2009electron\u00a0h<sup>\u22121</sup>; Bacon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). We first subtract the master bias exposures from each data set, and perform an illumination correction using in combination the master flat-field, the twilight sky exposures taken at the beginning of the night, and the illumination calibration taken soon before/after the science observations. We carry out wavelength, geometrical and astrometric calibrations in order to assign the World Coordinate System (WCS) right ascension and declination, and the wavelength to each pixel of the datacube. The flux calibration is carried out using standard star observations taken at the beginning of the observing night. For each pointing, the three individual exposures are then combined into a full datacube using a single interpolation step.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We apply the <span class=\"small-caps\">Z\u00fcrich Atmosphere Purge</span> (<span class=\"small-caps\">zap</span>; Soto et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib91\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib91\" data-open=\"bib91\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) software version 1.0, which uses a principal components analysis to analyse objects-free regions in the datacube and subtract systematics due to sky subtraction residuals. To create the <span class=\"small-caps\">zap</span> objects mask, we use the segmentation map obtained by applying the <span class=\"small-caps\">Sextractor</span> software (Bertin &amp; Arnouts <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib12\" data-open=\"bib12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>) on a white-light image collapsing the datacube along its wavelength axis.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The wavelength range of the final datacube stretches from 4750 to 9350\u2009\u00c5 in steps of 1.25\u2009\u00c5, and the spaxel size is 0.2\u00a0arcsec.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=304594323 id=\"304594323\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-2>2.2 Spectrum extraction</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We combine MUSE observations with high-resolution images from <em>HST</em> to detect small and faint sources that remain invisible in the image obtained when the MUSE datacube is collapsed along the wavelength axis. This combination was notably used by Bacon et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) for the analysis of MUSE observations of the <em>Hubble</em> Deep Field South.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">For MACS\u2009J2129 and RX\u2009J2129, we use <em>HST</em> data obtained with the <em>Advanced Camera for Surveys</em> (ACS; Ford et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>) as part of the CLASH survey in the F475W, F625W, and F814W pass-bands. We also use imaging by the <em>Wide Field Camera 3</em> (WFC3) in the F110W and F160W pass-bands to cover a larger wavelength range for the source identification. For MS\u20090451, we use the <em>HST</em> data available in the MAST website.<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn5\" data-open=\"fn5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">5</a></sup> We present in Tables\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>\u2013<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>, a summary of the <em>HST</em> observations used for this work for RX\u2009J2129, MS\u20090451, and MACS\u2009J2129, respectively, including the observation ID, the PI, the exposure time, and the observational date. For all three clusters, we applied standard data-reduction procedures. We used <em>HST</em><span class=\"small-caps\">cal</span> and the most recent calibration files. The co-addition of individual frames was done using <span class=\"small-caps\">Astrodrizzle</span> after registration to a common reference image using <span class=\"small-caps\">Tweakreg</span>. After an iterative process, we achieve an alignment accuracy of 0.1\u2009pixel. Our final stacked images have a pixel size of 0.03\u00a0arcsec.</p>                        <a id=\"304594326\" scrollto-destination=\"304594326\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl2\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl2\" data-id=\"tbl2\"><span class=\"label\">Table 2.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Summary of the <em>HST</em> observations used in this analysis to carry out the source identifications for RX\u2009J2129. In the context of the CLASH survey (Proposal ID 12457), observations in the UV were also carried but we do not list them as they are not used in this analysis.</p></div> </div><div        .\u00a0</span></th><th>Obs. date<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr><tr><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/304594326\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl2\" data-id=\"tbl2\"><span class=\"label\">Table 2.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Summary of the <em>HST</em> observations used in this analysis to carry out the source identifications for RX\u2009J2129. In the context of the CLASH survey (Proposal ID 12457), observations in the UV were also carried but we do not list them as they are not used in this analysis.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Band<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>PID<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>(s)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>ACS/F435W\u00a0</td><td>12100\u00a0</td><td>Postman\u00a0</td><td>932\u00a0</td><td>2011-07-14\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>ACS/F475W\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>1110\u00a0</td><td>2011-06-03\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>1110\u00a0</td><td>2011-07-14\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>ACS/F555W\u00a0</td><td>9722\u00a0</td><td>Ebeling\u00a0</td><td>4440\u00a0</td><td>2003-09-11\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>ACS/F606W\u00a0</td><td>12100\u00a0</td><td>Postman\u00a0</td><td>932\u00a0</td><td>2011-05-15\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>932\u00a0</td><td>2011-06-24\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>ACS/F625W\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>932\u00a0</td><td>2011-05-16\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>991\u00a0</td><td>2011-06-24\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>ACS/F775W\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>1029\u00a0</td><td>2011-05-16\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>995\u00a0</td><td>2011-07-14\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>ACS/F814W\u00a0</td><td>9722\u00a0</td><td>Ebeling\u00a0</td><td>4530\u00a0</td><td>2003-09-11\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>10493\u00a0</td><td>Gal-Yam\u00a0</td><td>2168\u00a0</td><td>2005-06-18\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>12100\u00a0</td><td>Postman\u00a0</td><td>932\u00a0</td><td>2011-06-24\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>ACS/F850LP\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>1020\u00a0</td><td>2011-05-15\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>932\u00a0</td><td>2011-06-03\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>1020\u00a0</td><td>2011-06-24\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>932\u00a0</td><td>2011-07-14\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>WFC3/F105W\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>1006\u00a0</td><td>2011-05-16\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>1409\u00a0</td><td>2011-08-03\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>13459\u00a0</td><td>Treu\u00a0</td><td>812\u00a0</td><td>2014-05-28\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>356\u00a0</td><td>2014-05-29\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>356\u00a0</td><td>2014-08-14\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>812\u00a0</td><td>2014-08-15\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>WFC3/F110W\u00a0</td><td>12100\u00a0</td><td>Postman\u00a0</td><td>1409\u00a0</td><td>2011-05-15\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>1006\u00a0</td><td>2011-07-20\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>WFC3/F125W\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>1409\u00a0</td><td>2011-05-16\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>1006\u00a0</td><td>2011-08-03\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>WFC3/F140W\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>1006\u00a0</td><td>2011-06-03\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>1306\u00a0</td><td>2011-06-24\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>13459\u00a0</td><td>Treu\u00a0</td><td>812\u00a0</td><td>2014-05-29\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>1574\u00a0</td><td>2014-08-14\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>WFC3/F160W\u00a0</td><td>12100\u00a0</td><td>Postman\u00a0</td><td>1006\u00a0</td><td>2011-05-15\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>1409\u00a0</td><td>2011-06-03\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>1206\u00a0</td><td>2011-06-24\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>1409\u00a0</td><td>2011-07-20\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>Band<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>PID<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>P\u2009I<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Exp. time<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Obs. date<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr><tr><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>(s)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>ACS/F435W\u00a0</td><td>12100\u00a0</td><td>Postman\u00a0</td><td>932\u00a0</td><td>2011-07-14\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>ACS/F475W\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>1110\u00a0</td><td>2011-06-03\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>1110\u00a0</td><td>2011-07-14\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>ACS/F555W\u00a0</td><td>9722\u00a0</td><td>Ebeling\u00a0</td><td>4440\u00a0</td><td>2003-09-11\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>ACS/F606W\u00a0</td><td>12100\u00a0</td><td>Postman\u00a0</td><td>932\u00a0</td><td>2011-05-15\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>932\u00a0</td><td>2011-06-24\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>ACS/F625W\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>932\u00a0</td><td>2011-05-16\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>991\u00a0</td><td>2011-06-24\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>ACS/F775W\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>1029\u00a0</td><td>2011-05-16\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>995\u00a0</td><td>2011-07-14\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>ACS/F814W\u00a0</td><td>9722\u00a0</td><td>Ebeling\u00a0</td><td>4530\u00a0</td><td>2003-09-11\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>10493\u00a0</td><td>Gal-Yam\u00a0</td><td>2168\u00a0</td><td>2005-06-18\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>12100\u00a0</td><td>Postman\u00a0</td><td>932\u00a0</td><td>2011-06-24\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>ACS/F850LP\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>1020\u00a0</td><td>2011-05-15\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>932\u00a0</td><td>2011-06-03\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>1020\u00a0</td><td>2011-06-24\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>932\u00a0</td><td>2011-07-14\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>WFC3/F105W\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>1006\u00a0</td><td>2011-05-16\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>1409\u00a0</td><td>2011-08-03\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>13459\u00a0</td><td>Treu\u00a0</td><td>812\u00a0</td><td>2014-05-28\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>356\u00a0</td><td>2014-05-29\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>356\u00a0</td><td>2014-08-14\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>812\u00a0</td><td>2014-08-15\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>WFC3/F110W\u00a0</td><td>12100\u00a0</td><td>Postman\u00a0</td><td>1409\u00a0</td><td>2011-05-15\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>1006\u00a0</td><td>2011-07-20\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>WFC3/F125W\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>1409\u00a0</td><td>2011-05-16\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>1006\u00a0</td><td>2011-08-03\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>WFC3/F140W\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>1006\u00a0</td><td>2011-06-03\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>1306\u00a0</td><td>2011-06-24\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>13459\u00a0</td><td>Treu\u00a0</td><td>812\u00a0</td><td>2014-05-29\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>1574\u00a0</td><td>2014-08-14\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>WFC3/F160W\u00a0</td><td>12100\u00a0</td><td>Postman\u00a0</td><td>1006\u00a0</td><td>2011-05-15\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>1409\u00a0</td><td>2011-06-03\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>1206\u00a0</td><td>2011-06-24\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>1409\u00a0</td><td>2011-07-20\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/304594328\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We use the <span class=\"small-caps\">ifs-redex</span> software to align the datacubes with the corresponding <em>HST</em> high-resolution images (Rexroth et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib82\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib82\" data-open=\"bib82\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). We then run <span class=\"small-caps\">SExtractor</span> on the <em>HST/ACS</em> F814W pass-band image for each cluster to automatically measure the position and FWHM of the sources in the MUSE field of view. <span class=\"small-caps\">ifs-redex</span> uses the catalogue of detected sources to extract the signal in the datacube within a circle of radius 3\u20135\u2009pixels according to the FWHM measurement. Sources with FWHM &lt; 2\u2009pixels are considered spurious detections, and are rejected.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In order to maximize the number of extracted spectra, we carry out a blind search in the datacube using <span class=\"small-caps\">muselet</span>.<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn6\" data-open=\"fn6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">6</a></sup> This software is part of the MUSE <span class=\"small-caps\">Python Data Analysis Framework</span> (<span class=\"small-caps\">mpdaf</span>; Bacon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). It builds a new datacube, the narrow-band datacube, within which each wavelength plane is the mean of the 5 closest wavelength planes in the science datacube. <span class=\"small-caps\">muselet</span> then uses <span class=\"small-caps\">SExtractor</span> to extract a catalogue of sources at each wavelength in the narrow-band datacube. The latter are finally merged and sorted, providing a continuum and a single line emission catalogues.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Finally, all catalogues are merged to provide a master catalogue, which is then displayed on the high resolution image so that the user can determine whether <span class=\"small-caps\">muselet</span> and <span class=\"small-caps\">SExtractor</span> detections are matching the same source. This results in a set of spectra that we then analyse to measure the associated redshifts.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=304594332 id=\"304594332\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-3>2.3 Redshift measurements</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\"><span class=\"small-caps\">ifs-redex</span> has an interactive interface that displays each extracted spectrum and its corresponding source in <span class=\"small-caps\">saods9</span> (Joye &amp; Mandel <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib50\" data-open=\"bib50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>). It allows the user to modify the source redshift to match the position of an emission/absorption line template to its most likely position in the spectrum. (The template contains \u223c60 lines including notably Ly\u00a0\u03b1, [O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>], [O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>], and H\u00a0\u03b2 emission lines, and Ca\u2009H&amp;K, Mg, Fe, and Na absorption lines.) To simplify the redshift identification, it is possible to smooth the signal with a Gaussian filter, and then perform a wavelet-based spectrum cleaning (Rexroth et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib82\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib82\" data-open=\"bib82\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). The systematic error is calculated by quadratically adding the wavelength calibration error provided by the MUSE data reduction pipeline, and the error given by fitting a Gaussian to the most prominent line in the spectrum. For each redshift, we assign a quality flag (QF) of 3 if the redshift is secure, 2 if likely (e.g. only one characteristic line \u2013 for example the [O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] doublet or Ly\u00a0\u03b1 line with consistent photometric redshift), 1 if insecure, and 0 otherwise, i.e. in case of visually flat continuum or highly polluted spectrum.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We sequentially analyse all spectra extracted from the MUSE datacubes of the three clusters using the aforementioned method. The measured redshifts are sorted depending on whether they belong to a source located in the foreground of the cluster, in the cluster, or in the background.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=304594335 id=\"304594335\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-4>2.4 Results of the redshift extraction</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> shows the distribution of redshifts for the extracted sources for RX\u2009J2129, MS\u20090451, and MACS\u2009J2129. Lists of the extracted redshifts with QF larger than 2 are given in Appendix\u2009\u00a0<a class=\"js-jumplink\" href=\"#sec8\">A</a>, where Tables \u2009<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl11\" data-open=\"tbl11\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A1</a>\u2013<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl13\" data-open=\"tbl13\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A3</a> give the results for RX\u2009J2129, MS\u20090451, and MACS\u2009J2129, respectively. The redshift intervals to consider galaxies as cluster members are established using the definition given in Ma et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib69\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib69\" data-open=\"bib69\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>), combined with the criteria defined in Rexroth et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib82\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib82\" data-open=\"bib82\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). For each cluster, we include all galaxies with a redshift flagged as secure or likely (QF = 2, 3), and which present a continuum plus characteristic absorption lines. We here only summarize the redshift extraction.</p>                        <a id=\"304594337\" scrollto-destination=\"304594337\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" \u2265 2 extracted within the MUSE datacubes for RX J2129, MS 0451, and MACS J2129.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" alt=\"Redshift distribution of the sources with QF \u2265 2 extracted within the MUSE datacubes for RX J2129, MS 0451, and MACS J2129.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab2270fig1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig new tab</a><a data-section=\"304594337\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/508/1/10.1093_mnras_stab2270/1/stab2270fig1.jpeg?Expires=1639262452&Signature=e-drRAOuLyNEbCx8IE-SKQwQh-J9vnsbVBSwBzzB-uDVDHJ8qcqlFNkuhFWaYXWNUHslzYkIhBbPqdvZwBpkfhkmFS4RH~5s-68OVvOwcYiJsh~BdP7hX98eAeqvKLeOJjK~apQDvuizLXaQqPOR0a0YJF9PP9Qss2-ZU5-9hO8PkCszfJnA5vp5DOSKbHCvQGvM4Bs4QxdBAuTnlp3lkKLYRp6T6g9~VxeT499rQjQRR3-TnRlUvO4~G99R52UtDqSMCif0wnRyEu5lnVRr-guAf0bY9wFwet-rsBnLNHLzDpsA5T70ISs-N93rGOHoxTVR6is3chVoJv1d4CGAlg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=304594337&ar=6350584&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab2270fig1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Redshift distribution of the sources with QF \u2265 2 extracted within the MUSE datacubes for RX J2129, MS 0451, and MACS J2129.</p></div></div>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=304594338 id=\"304594338\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-4-1>2.4.1 RX\u2009J2129</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We extracted 158 sources with redshifts ranging from 0.0 to 5.53 in RX\u2009J2129. Among them, 43 are identified as cluster members with 0.2145 &lt; <em>z</em> &lt; 0.2410, 24 as foreground objects, and 91 as background sources (i.e. total number of sources without accounting for image multiplicity).When comparing our results to those reported in Caminha et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>), we measure 22 new redshifts not reported in their analysis, and miss 34 of their identifications. Most of the sources we disagree on are faint cluster members. We attribute these differences to the different methods used for the extraction of spectra.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=304594340 id=\"304594340\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-4-2>2.4.2 MS\u20090451</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We extracted 171 sources with redshifts ranging from 0.0 to 4.85 from the MUSE datacube. Among them, 112 are identified as cluster members, with 0.5307 &lt; <em>z</em> &lt; 0.5652, 24 sources are identified as foreground objects, 35 are identified as background sources.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=304594342 id=\"304594342\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-4-3>2.4.3 MACS\u2009J2129</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We extracted 189 sources with redshifts ranging from 0.0 to 4.92. Among them, 89 are identified as cluster members with 0.5737 &lt; <em>z</em> &lt; 0.6032, 39 as foreground objects, and 61 as background sources. The comparison of our measurements with those reported in Caminha et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>) yields similar results to RX\u2009J2129, with 16 new redshifts not reported in their analysis, and 25 of their measurements that we miss.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=304594344 id=\"304594344\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3>3 STRONG-LENSING ANALYSES</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We use the <span class=\"small-caps\">Lenstool</span> software (Kneib et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib57\" data-open=\"bib57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>; Jullo et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>) to perform the strong-lensing analysis of each cluster. We started from existing strong-lensing models, referred to as <em>fiducial models</em> in the following, which were either already published, or shared privately with our team. Starting from these <em>fiducial models</em>, we use the newly measured redshifts to carry out the identification of new cluster members, and multiple image systems. When possible, we also add the spectroscopic redshift information to already identified multiple image systems, and/or confirm counter-images of the same system.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=304594346 id=\"304594346\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-1>3.1 Mass modeling method</h3>\r\n<div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">With <span class=\"small-caps\">Lenstool</span> (Jullo et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>), we decompose the cluster gravitational potential into large-scale haloes to model the main dark matter component(s) of the clusters, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\Phi _{c_{i}}$|\u2060</span>, and subhaloes to model the cluster galaxies, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\Phi _{p_{j}}$|\u2060</span>, according to <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ1\" content-id=\"equ1\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\Phi _{tot} = \\sum \\limits _{i} \\Phi _{c_{i}} + \\sum \\limits _{j} \\Phi _{p_{j}}.\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(1)</span></div>Large-scale haloes and subhaloes are described with Pseudo Isothermal Elliptical Mass Distribution profiles (PIEMD; Kassiola &amp; Kovner <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib54\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib54\" data-open=\"bib54\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1993</a>; Limousin, Kneib &amp; Natarajan <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib62\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib62\" data-open=\"bib62\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>; El\u00edasd\u00f3ttir et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib28\" data-open=\"bib28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>), which are parametrized with a core radius, <em>r<sub>c</sub></em>, and a truncation radius, <em>r<sub>t</sub></em>, to calculate the projected mass density: <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ2\" content-id=\"equ2\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\Sigma (R) = \\frac{\\sigma ^{2}}{2G} \\frac{r_{t}}{r_{t}-r_{c}} \\left(\\frac{1}{\\root \\of {R^{2} + r_{c}^{2}}} - \\frac{1}{\\root \\of {R^{2} + r_{t}^{2}}} \\right),\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(2)</span></div>where <em>G</em> is the gravitational constant. The projected radius, <em>R</em><sup>2</sup> = <em>x</em><sup>2</sup>/(1 + <em>e</em>)<sup>2</sup> + <em>y</em><sup>2</sup>/(1 \u2212 <em>e</em>)<sup>2</sup>, is defined with the module of the complex ellipticity, <strong>e</strong> from Natarajan &amp; Kneib (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib73\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib73\" data-open=\"bib73\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1997</a>), <em>e</em> = (<em>a</em><sup>2</sup> \u2212 <em>b</em><sup>2</sup>)/(<em>a</em><sup>2</sup> + <em>b</em><sup>2</sup>). In practice, <strong>e</strong> = <em>e</em> \u00d7 <em>e</em><sup>2<em>i</em>\u03b8</sup>, where \u03b8 is the orientation angle of the ellipse seen in the cluster from the observer point of view. <em>a</em> and <em>b</em> are, respectively, the semimajor and the semiminor axes of the mass distribution, and \u03c3 is the 1D-velocity dispersion. The position of the centre, defined by (<em>x, y</em>), the module of the ellipticity, <em>e</em>, the orientation angle, \u03b8, the truncation and core radii, <em>r<sub>c</sub></em> and <em>r<sub>t</sub></em>, and the velocity dispersion, \u03c3, are the seven parameters needed to describe a PIEMD.</div><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">As pointed out by Jullo et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>), the optimization of seven parameters per subhalo would lead to an underconstrained mass model. We thus consider that the luminosity of cluster galaxies is a good tracer of their mass (see the discussion in Harvey, Kneib &amp; Jauzac <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). Following such assumption, the position and ellipticity of each subhalo are fixed to their luminous counterpart, measured with <span class=\"small-caps\">Sextractor</span> (Bertin &amp; Arnouts <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib12\" data-open=\"bib12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>). The total mass of the subhalo is then measured by rescaling the remaining PIEMD parameters for each cluster galaxy, \u03c3, <em>r<sub>c</sub></em>, and <em>r<sub>t</sub></em>, to the ones of a reference galaxy with a luminosity <em>L</em>*, following the Faber &amp; Jackson (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1976</a>) relation: <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ3\" content-id=\"equ3\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\left\\lbrace \\begin{array}{c @{=} c}\\sigma &amp; \\sigma ^{*} \\left(\\frac{L}{L^{\\ast }} \\right)^{1/4}\\\\\r\nr_{c} &amp; r_{c}^{*} \\left(\\frac{L}{L^{\\ast }} \\right)^{1/2}\\\\\r\nr_{t} &amp; r_{t}^{*} \\left(\\frac{L}{L^{\\ast }} \\right)^{1/2}\\\\\r\n\\end{array} \\right.,\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(3)</span></div>from which the total mass of each subhalo is derived following: <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"update1629386811350\" content-id=\"update1629386811350\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\nM = \\frac{\\pi }{G} (\\sigma ^{*})^{2} r_{c}^{*} \\left(\\frac{L}{L^{\\ast }} \\right),\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(4)</span></div>where \u03c3*, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$r_{t}^{*}$|\u2060</span>, and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$r_{c}^{*}$|\u2060</span>, are the reference velocity dispersion, truncation, and core radii, respectively. It was shown in previous models that <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$r_{c}^{*}$|</span> is small in galaxy-scale haloes and thus plays a minor role in the mass models (e.g. Covone et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Limousin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib63\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib63\" data-open=\"bib63\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>; El\u00edasd\u00f3ttir et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib28\" data-open=\"bib28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>). We thus adopt a conservative value of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$r_{c}^{*} \\sim 0.15$|</span>\u2009kpc for all three clusters.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">For each model, we start by optimizing one large-scale halo per cluster. The brightest cluster galaxy (BCG), and cluster members located in the vicinity of multiple images are individually optimized as they act as small-scale perturbers. We then add a second large-scale potential in the optimization process when a set of multiple images concentrated in a given region of the cluster core cannot be reproduced with a simple one-halo mass model.</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \"><span class=\"small-caps\">Lenstool</span> uses a Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) process to sample the posterior density of the model, expressed as a function of the likelihood of the model, defined in Jullo et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>). In practice, we minimize <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ5\" content-id=\"equ5\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\chi ^{2} = \\sum \\limits _{i} \\chi _{i}^{2}\\ ,\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(5)</span></div>where <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"update1629386972557\" content-id=\"update1629386972557\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\chi _{i}^{2} = \\sum _{j=1}^{n_{i}} \\frac{(\\theta ^{j}_{\\rm obs} - \\theta ^{j}({\\boldsymbol p}))^{2}}{\\sigma _{ij}^{2}}\\ .\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(6)</span></div><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\theta ^{j}_{obs}$|</span> is the vector position of the observed multiple image <em>j</em>, \u03b8<sup><em>j</em></sup> is the predicted vector position of image <em>j, n<sub>i</sub></em> is the number of images in System <em>i</em>, and \u03c3<sub><em>ij</em></sub> is the error on the position of image <em>j</em> (fixed at \u223c 0.5\u00a0arcsec for multiple images to account for both errors on image positions between MUSE and <em>HST</em> images and line of sight effects as described in Jullo et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib52\" data-open=\"bib52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010a</a>). As a consequence, the most likely model minimizes the distance between the observed positions of the multiple images and their predicted position by the model, the rms.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">In what follows, we describe the set of multiple image systems used to constrain the new mass models for each cluster, and then detail the selection of independently optimized haloes.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=304594352 id=\"304594352\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-2>3.2 Multiple images</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We use the catalogues of sources described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2-4\"></span><a href=\"#sec2-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">2.4</a> to carry out the search for multiple images. We start by comparing our data to the lists of multiple images used in the <em>fiducial models</em>, and thus add the spectroscopic redshift information when available. For each sources identified as background in our catalogues, and not already identified by previous strong-lensing analyses, we use the <em>fiducial models</em> to predict their multiplicity.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">If a background source is confirmed as multiple, the narrow-band datacube at the wavelength corresponding to its maximum emission is used, and combined with composite colour images made from different combinations of <em>HST</em> filters, to identify all the multiple images of the system. When a multiple image system is then confirmed, it is added as a constraint to the new mass model. The lists of multiple image systems used in RX\u2009J2129, MS\u20090451, and MACS\u2009J2129 are given in Tables \u2009<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl5\" data-open=\"tbl5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>\u2013<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl7\" data-open=\"tbl7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>, respectively. They are also highlighted with white circles in Figs <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>\u2013<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>, respectively. Further details about the redshift measurements of multiple image systems are presented in Appendix \u2009\u00a0<a class=\"js-jumplink\" href=\"#sec9\">B</a> for MS\u20090451 (e.g. the strongest spectral lines, together with <em>HST</em> stamps of the multiple images), and we refer the reader to Caminha et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>) for similar information regarding RX\u2009J2129 and MACS\u2009J2129.</p>                        <a id=\"304594355\" scrollto-destination=\"304594355\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl5\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl5\" data-id=\"tbl5\"><span class=\"label\">Table 5.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">List of the multiple images used as constraints in our new <span class=\"small-caps\">Lenstool</span> strong-lensing mass model of RX\u2009J2129. System 1 was identified by Richard et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib83\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib83\" data-open=\"bib83\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>), and its spectroscopic redshift first measured by Belli et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). Systems 2 was studied in detail in Desprez et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). Systems 3 and 5 were reported in Zitrin et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib105\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib105\" data-open=\"bib105\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). Systems 6, 7, and 8 are new identification from the MUSE observations. Column 1 is the ID of the image, columns 2 and 3 give the RA and Decl. in degrees (J2000) of each image, column 4 the spectroscopic redshift measured if available, and column 5 the redshift predicted by the best model when no spectroscopic information is available. Spectroscopic redshifts are highlighted in bold when confirmed/measured with MUSE. The rms for each image is given in column 6 in arcseconds. *We here fix the redshift of System 2 to the photometric redshift measured by Desprez et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>).</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>ID<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>RA<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Decl.<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>z</em><sub>spec</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>z<sub>m</sub></em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>rms<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr><tr><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>[J2000]<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>[J2000]<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/304594355\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl5\" data-id=\"tbl5\"><span class=\"label\">Table 5.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">List of the multiple images used as constraints in our new <span class=\"small-caps\">Lenstool</span> strong-lensing mass model of RX\u2009J2129. System 1 was identified by Richard et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib83\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib83\" data-open=\"bib83\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>), and its spectroscopic redshift first measured by Belli et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). Systems 2 was studied in detail in Desprez et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). Systems 3 and 5 were reported in Zitrin et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib105\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib105\" data-open=\"bib105\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). Systems 6, 7, and 8 are new identification from the MUSE observations. Column 1 is the ID of the image, columns 2 and 3 give the RA and Decl. in degrees (J2000) of each image, column 4 the spectroscopic redshift measured if available, and column 5 the redshift predicted by the best model when no spectroscopic information is available. Spectroscopic redshifts are highlighted in bold when confirmed/measured with MUSE. The rms for each image is given in column 6 in arcseconds. *We here fix the redshift of System 2 to the photometric redshift measured by Desprez et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>).</p></div> </div><div images used as constraints in our new <span class=\"small-caps\">Lenstool</span> strong-lensing mass model of MS\u20090451. Systems A, B, and C were reported by Borys et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>). Systems E, F, G and I were identified by MacKenzie et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). Systems D, H, and J to P were detected by our team, and will be presented in an upcoming analysis (Richard et\u00a0al. in preparation). Systems R and S are new detections from this analysis. d><td>1.359\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>0.13\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>*14.1\u00a0</td><td>322.36131\u00a0</td><td>\u22127.68590\u00a0</td><td>1.452\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>*14.2\u00a0</td><td>322.36248\u00a0</td><td>\u22127.69142\u00a0</td><td>1.452\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>*14.3\u00a0</td><td>322.36259\u00a0</td><td>\u22127.69360\u00a0</td><td>1.452\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/304594357\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=304594358 id=\"304594358\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-2-1>3.2.1 RX\u2009J2129</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Our <em>fiducial model</em> was built from the parametric model presented in Zitrin et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib105\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib105\" data-open=\"bib105\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>), which includes four multiple images, and adapted within the <span class=\"small-caps\">Lenstool</span> framework. We here present the results out of our redshift extractions from the MUSE datacube, and compare them with the results presented in Caminha et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>) who analysed the same MUSE observations.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Our spectroscopic redshift measurements for System 1 (<em>z</em> = 1.522, QF = 3, Mg/Fe absorber), System 5 (<em>z</em> = 0.916, QF=2, O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> emitter), and System 3 (<em>z</em> = 1.52, QF = 3, Mg absorber) are in excellent agreement with the previous measurements presented by Caminha et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>). One will note that the redshift of System 1 was initially measured by Belli et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). Moreover, we confirm the initial identification of 4 new multiple image Systems reported in Caminha et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>). System 4 (<em>z</em> = 3.4270, QF=3, [O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] emitter), System 6 (<em>z</em> = 0.6786, QF = 3, [O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] emitter), System 7 (<em>z</em> = 3.08, QF = 3, Ly\u00a0\u03b1 emitter), and System 8 (<em>z</em> = 1.52, QF = 3, Mg and Fe absorbers) are confirmed triply imaged systems.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The main difference between the constraints used by Caminha et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>) and our analysis is the inclusion of System 2 here, a galaxy\u2013galaxy lensing system. It is located relatively far from the cluster center, 81\u00a0arcsec from the BCG, in the vicinity of a massive isolated galaxy outside the field of view covered by MUSE (i.e. R\u2009A = 322.429, Decl. = 0.1082), and can be seen in Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>. Desprez et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) studied this System in detail, and its impact on the overall mass reconstruction of the cluster. For the analysis presented here, we assume the photometric redshift measured by Desprez et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), <em>z</em> = 1.61.</p>                        <a id=\"304594362\" scrollto-destination=\"304594362\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/508/1/10.1093_mnras_stab2270/1/m_stab2270fig2.jpeg?Expires=1639262452&amp;Signature=f5nmmGOcQhi~giK3QMm0zLVrHyWNfI87VR7kTZdzwUITbaytHJJkeT8hIH75Unof72GY1ekeOTPMxuPMwdW~hnXuWKi66ITT-b2wbgSi8chnbjp2jvPJU9AoeS56X9sg1hTd9V~bvIXN6xQlFZENSf-uETPYbExiDPgW0hfegNphiUeN1p8zg92KpO8zVVfU8GQRO-qyOLoZ2sbhxtAMiPPQiB8hUw0Rq~t9KHxFlAGd~5-4rlmEiMx-3j3cFZhK~1IwDKnhVO52rSc9JpKclwIOmLMlDFremLfn8lUM3EIYVNVpbZ0sJ6u0dzmKEieF7JuHPIWilX9-UNE2IArqyg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"HST composite colour image of System 2 in RX\u2009J2129 using F475W, F606W, and F814W pass-bands. Multiple images used as constraints are highlighted by white circles.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab2270fig2.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/304594362/stab2270fig2.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab2270fig2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"304594362\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/508/1/10.1093_mnras_stab2270/1/stab2270fig2.jpeg?Expires=1639262452&Signature=g9T54ooc4Hrc9UU5JfWMx21AIQsoWEeufmYwuqv57Zl3szG~xACroJzt1S~3stSNlQpJXbrWwTkAY94vzY9gRpfRcsb0wOF7pE6Y1FYHDE-Wy-Z5-N3KoOWFEJcxG45BL3Gm7g6b4i9QcW1-Nf87r0xozzpAtn57gLgQmD0SDIIcYl~TLVEyr7aZ1ClyexBn~9GtVPa25yyXFahYVymbUVcKI0t2hnnZwvg9UeIiz73rvnx~y4LO-WxsGx1dNLSSirn-D~MyOrtWWQhM35r34yA1Vxex7iW6dU-sFH5y1OfOOzwUYoaJWGtcU2xBdg-cb62SXgpKHvd~ceahCXmMNw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=304594362&ar=6350584&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab2270fig2.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>HST</em> composite colour image of System 2 in RX\u2009J2129 using F475W, F606W, and F814W pass-bands. Multiple images used as constraints are highlighted by white circles.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/508/1/10.1093_mnras_stab2270/1/m_stab2270fig2.jpeg?Expires=1639262452&amp;Signature=f5nmmGOcQhi~giK3QMm0zLVrHyWNfI87VR7kTZdzwUITbaytHJJkeT8hIH75Unof72GY1ekeOTPMxuPMwdW~hnXuWKi66ITT-b2wbgSi8chnbjp2jvPJU9AoeS56X9sg1hTd9V~bvIXN6xQlFZENSf-uETPYbExiDPgW0hfegNphiUeN1p8zg92KpO8zVVfU8GQRO-qyOLoZ2sbhxtAMiPPQiB8hUw0Rq~t9KHxFlAGd~5-4rlmEiMx-3j3cFZhK~1IwDKnhVO52rSc9JpKclwIOmLMlDFremLfn8lUM3EIYVNVpbZ0sJ6u0dzmKEieF7JuHPIWilX9-UNE2IArqyg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"HST composite colour image of System 2 in RX\u2009J2129 using F475W, F606W, and F814W pass-bands. Multiple images used as constraints are highlighted by white circles.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab2270fig2.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/304594362/stab2270fig2.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab2270fig2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"304594362\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/508/1/10.1093_mnras_stab2270/1/stab2270fig2.jpeg?Expires=1639262452&Signature=g9T54ooc4Hrc9UU5JfWMx21AIQsoWEeufmYwuqv57Zl3szG~xACroJzt1S~3stSNlQpJXbrWwTkAY94vzY9gRpfRcsb0wOF7pE6Y1FYHDE-Wy-Z5-N3KoOWFEJcxG45BL3Gm7g6b4i9QcW1-Nf87r0xozzpAtn57gLgQmD0SDIIcYl~TLVEyr7aZ1ClyexBn~9GtVPa25yyXFahYVymbUVcKI0t2hnnZwvg9UeIiz73rvnx~y4LO-WxsGx1dNLSSirn-D~MyOrtWWQhM35r34yA1Vxex7iW6dU-sFH5y1OfOOzwUYoaJWGtcU2xBdg-cb62SXgpKHvd~ceahCXmMNw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=304594362&ar=6350584&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab2270fig2.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>HST</em> composite colour image of System 2 in RX\u2009J2129 using F475W, F606W, and F814W pass-bands. Multiple images used as constraints are highlighted by white circles.</p></div></div>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=304594363 id=\"304594363\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-2-2>3.2.2 MS\u20090451</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Our <em>fiducial model</em> is based on the <span class=\"small-caps\">Lenstool</span> model from MacKenzie et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>), then revised by the identification of 8 new multiple image systems, including a <em>z</em> = 6.7 quintuple image in the north of the cluster (Knudsen et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>, and will be presented in detail in Richard et\u00a0al. in preparation). We now present the new measurements for MS\u20090451, and thus the constraints added to our new mass model.</p>                    <h5 scrollto-destination=304594365 id=\"304594365\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-2-2-1>3.2.2.1 New multiple image systems</h5>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We report the identification of two new systems of multiple images at high redshifts. System <em>R</em> (<em>z</em> = 3.7645, QF = 3) is composed of three multiple images, and is located in the poorly constrained northern region of the cluster. System S (<em>z</em> = 4.4514, QF = 3) is predicted to be quadruply imaged but only two multiple images could be identified. These sources are Ly\u00a0\u03b1 emitters identified thanks to the blind-search carried out directly in the datacube with <span class=\"small-caps\">muselet</span>. These two systems are located within two poorly constrained regions of the cluster, and are playing a substantial role in the improvement of the accuracy of the model as described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4</a>. The strongest MUSE spectral lines of Systems R and S are presented in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-figB1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"figB1\" data-open=\"figB1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">B1</a>.</p>                    <h5 scrollto-destination=304594367 id=\"304594367\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-2-2-2>3.2.2.2 Confirmation and measurement of known systems</h5>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We report the measurement of a spectroscopic redshift for all three multiple images of System G, <em>z</em> = 2.93 (QF=3, Ly\u00a0\u03b1 emitter). We also measure a spectroscopic redshift for System A, <em>z</em> = 2.92, which is in agreement with the previous measurement from Borys et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>) and Berciano Alba et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib11\" data-open=\"bib11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>). The strongest MUSE spectral lines of System G are presented in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-figB2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"figB2\" data-open=\"figB2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">B2</a>.</p>                    <h5 scrollto-destination=304594369 id=\"304594369\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-2-2-3>3.2.2.3 Other systems</h5>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The redshift of System H is measured at <em>z</em> = 6.7 by Knudsen et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) and Richard et\u00a0al. (in preparation). Image P.2 is located in a bright region surrounding the BCG which makes it difficult to identify. Moreover Image P.1 is located in the vicinity of a cluster member which increases the uncertainty on the location of the system. Therefore, System P was flagged as insecure and is not used in the model. For the remaining 11 systems without spectroscopic confirmation, their redshift is being optimized by the model.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=304594371 id=\"304594371\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-2-3>3.2.3 MACS\u2009J2129</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Our <em>fiducial model</em> was built from the model presented in Monna et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) combining CLASH photometry (see Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>) and VLT/VIMOS spectroscopy (PI: Rosati, ID: 186.A-0798). It relies on 9 multiple image systems, 7 of which were spectroscopically confirmed back then. We then extracted spectroscopic redshifts from the MUSE datacubes, and compared our results with Caminha et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>) who analysed the same MUSE observations.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Our analysis measures similar redshifts to Caminha et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>) for Systems 1, 2, 3, 7, and 8, in good agreement with Monna et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) measurements. We measure a redshift of <em>z</em> = 4.41 (QF = 3, Ly\u00a0\u03b1 emitter) for Images 8.1, 8.2, and 8.3, in agreement with the redshift of 8.1 measured by Monna et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), and confirmed by Caminha et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>). The fourth image of System 8, Image 8.4, is outside the MUSE field of view. Caminha et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>) identified the counter-image 8.5 which we confirm as well. We show in Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>\u2009 composite colour <em>HST</em> stamps of the five images, narrow-band images, and their spectra extracted from the MUSE datacubes. We cannot obtain reliable redshift measurements from the extracted spectra of Systems 4, 5, and 9. We thus use the spectroscopic redshifts measured with VIMOS in Monna et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) for Systems 4 and 9 (QF=2), and optimize the redshift of System 5 in our mass model. The redshift of System 6 (<em>z</em> = 6.85) was spectroscopically confirmed by Huang et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>), and could not be measured with MUSE since the wavelength corresponding to the maximum emission is greater than the upper limit of the MUSE wavelength range (\u223c9350\u2009\u00c5), as in the case of the <em>z</em> = 6.7 quintuply imaged system in MS\u20090451 (Knudsen et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Richard et\u00a0al. in preparation).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">With this work, we confirm the four new spectroscopic identifications of multiple image systems identified by Caminha et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>), and present the new identification of one system: Systems 10 (<em>z</em> = 4.41, QF=3, Ly\u00a0\u03b1 emitter), 11 (<em>z</em> = 3.1081, QF = 3, Ly\u00a0\u03b1 emitter), 12 (<em>z</em> = 3.897, QF = 3, Ly\u00a0\u03b1 emitter), 13 (<em>z</em> = 1.3585, QF=2, [O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] emitter), and 14 (<em>z</em> = 1.4519, QF=1, [O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] emitter). System 10 is not identified by Caminha et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>), however they detect Image\u200910.1 which is listed in the public release of their catalogue.<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn7\" data-open=\"fn7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">7</a></sup> Our model predicts it as quadruply imaged, although only two multiple images could be confirmed with MUSE. This system seems to be linked to System 8, composed of 5 multiple images. Image 10.1 appears to be located close to the Ly\u00a0\u03b1 emission of image 8.3, although the two emission regions are well separated. This could imply that the two systems highlight two physically connected lensed galaxies at <em>z</em> = 4.41, System 8 being more UV bright and detected in the <em>HST</em> images. Image 10.2 is located relatively close to Image 8.5, separated by a cluster galaxy (G3 in our model discussed in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">3.3</a> and visible in Fig.\u2009<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>); however, the feature is similar to what is visible in the case of Images 8.3/10.1. We find a possible candidate for another image of system 10 located close to Image 8.2, as a faint Ly\u00a0\u03b1 tail. However, the detection has a low signal-to-noise ratio, we therefore do not include that image in our model. System 10 is extremely faint in the <em>HST</em> image, it is thus difficult to securely identify its fourth counter-image which is predicted outside the MUSE field of view, relatively close to Image 8.4. Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a> shows composite <em>HST</em> stamps of Images 10.1 and 10.2, their narrow-band images, and the spectra extracted from the MUSE datacubes, along with the five multiple images of System 8. We therefore include the five images for System 8 in our model, and the two images of System 10 detected in the MUSE datacubes. Regarding System 14 (System 5 in Caminha et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>), our spectroscopic measurement is flagged as unsecure, we therefore decide to not include this system as a constraint in our strong-lensing mass model, but list it in Table\u2009 <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl7\" data-open=\"tbl7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a> for consistency with Caminha et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>). Caminha et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>) also lists a counter-image for System 12, Image 12.3 in Table \u2009<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl7\" data-open=\"tbl7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>, System 9 and Image 9c in their analysis. This counter-image is not spectroscopically confirmed, and we are not convinced by its colour and morphology in the <em>HST</em> imaging. We thus only consider it as a candidate.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=304594375 id=\"304594375\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-3>3.3 Cluster- and galaxy-scale components</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">For each cluster, we compare the MUSE spectroscopically confirmed cluster members to the list of cluster galaxies used in the <em>fiducial models</em>. MUSE observations allowed us to identify 43, 112, and 89 cluster galaxies for RX\u2009J2129, MS\u20090451, and MACS\u2009J2129, respectively. Among those, 15 in RX\u2009J2129 and 4 in MACS\u2009J2129 are new detections, i.e. not reported by Caminha et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>). We combine those with the cluster member galaxies identified by previous works, using standard colour-magnitude red-sequence selections as well as spectroscopic identifications with different instruments. We use cluster identifications from Desprez et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), Monna et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), and Richard et\u00a0al. (in preparation) for RX\u2009J2129, MS\u20090451, and MACS\u2009J2129, respectively. In total, we used 70, 144, and 151 cluster members for the modelling of RX\u2009J2129, MS\u20090451, and MACS\u2009J2129, respectively. We used the method presented in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2-4\"></span><a href=\"#sec2-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">2.4</a> to optimize the parameters of each subhalo. As explained before, we optimize a selection of large-scale and galaxy-scale haloes for each cluster. The best-fitting parameters obtained are listed in Table\u2009 <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl8\" data-open=\"tbl8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a>, and discussed in this section. For scaling relations, the reference magnitudes are mag<sub>F814W</sub> = 17.49, mag<sub>F814W</sub> = 18.69, and mag<sub>F814W</sub> = 19.19 for RX\u2009J2129, MS\u20090451, and MACS\u2009J2129, respectively. The shapes of the individually optimized potentials from the best fit are shown in the right-hand panel of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"304594377\" scrollto-destination=\"304594377\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl8\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl8\" data-id=\"tbl8\"><span class=\"label\">Table 8.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Best-fitting parameters of the mass models for all three clusters. Column (1) gives the cluster name. In brackets, we list the rms, the number of degrees of freedom, <em>dof</em>, and the number of multiple images respectively for each best-fitting model. Column (2) is the ID of the optimized potential. The IDs of the large-scale haloes are highlighted in bold. Columns (3) to (9) are respectively the R\u2009A and Decl. of the center for each halo and subhalo in arcseconds relative to the chosen center as given in Sect. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">3</a>, the ellipticity, the orientation angle, the core radius, the truncation radius, and the velocity dispersion for each optimized potentials. The position angle, \u03b8, is given in degrees and is defined as the direction of the semimajor axis of the iso-potential, counted counterclockwise from the horizontal axis (being the R\u2009A axis). For each free parameter of the models, we indicate the 1\u03c3 error bars computed from the posterior distribution of the MCMC samples. For scaling relations, the reference magnitudes are mag<sub>F814W</sub> = 17.49, mag<sub>F814W</sub> = 18.69, and mag<sub>F814W</sub> = 19.19 for RX\u2009J2129, MS\u20090451, and MACS\u2009J2129, respectively. Values in brackets are fixed in the model.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Cluster<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$140_{-30}^{+19}$|</span>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>G4\u00a0</td><td>[11.68]\u00a0</td><td>[23.47]\u00a0</td><td>[0.79]\u00a0</td><td>[34.4]\u00a0</td><td>[0.15]\u00a0</td><td>102\u00a0\u00b1\u00a044\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$45_{-22}^{+45}$|</span>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>G5\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/304594377\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl8\" data-id=\"tbl8\"><span class=\"label\">Table 8.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Best-fitting parameters of the mass models for all three clusters. Column (1) gives the cluster name. In brackets, we list the rms, the number of degrees of freedom, <em>dof</em>, and the number of multiple images respectively for each best-fitting model. Column (2) is the ID of the optimized potential. The IDs of the large-scale haloes are highlighted in bold. Columns (3) to (9) are respectively the R\u2009A and Decl. of the center for each halo and subhalo in arcseconds relative to the chosen center as given in Sect. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">3</a>, the ellipticity, the orientation angle, the core radius, the truncation radius, and the velocity dispersion for each optimized potentials. The position angle, \u03b8, is given in degrees and is defined as the direction of the semimajor axis of the iso-potential, counted counterclockwise from the horizontal axis (being the R\u2009A axis). For each free parameter of the models, we indicate the 1\u03c3 error bars computed from the posterior distribution of the MCMC samples. For scaling relations, the reference magnitudes are mag<sub>F814W</sub> = 17.49, mag<sub>F814W</sub> = 18.69, and mag<sub>F814W</sub> = 19.19 for RX\u2009J2129, MS\u20090451, and MACS\u2009J2129, respectively. Values in brackets are fixed in the model.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Cluster<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03b8<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>r<sub>c</sub></em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>r<sub>t</sub></em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03c3<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display:
