The contours are displayed in magenta for 2, 3, and 4\u2009\u00d7 10<sup>\u221220</sup>\u2009erg\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u2009arcsec<sup>\u22122</sup>. <em>Bottom:</em> Extracted spectra from the MUSE datacube centred on the most prominent lines for images of System 8 (left) and System 10 (right).</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"304594417\" scrollto-destination=\"304594417\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig7\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 7.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/508/1/10.1093_mnras_stab2270/1/m_stab2270fig7.jpeg?Expires=1639262452&amp;Signature=SaLndIW-EHh9x73a77~ZIt3TMxs3O4Tl8xHbA8n5tPTE874hnvhMrTHaLKnE7PSe1zQ~zhRweSfzUSfRFul6P2ABLJ7koURiNFz~3CucL-7vYbiwGaw2TjVK6j-Nw6PB-BTScSE6DK6k1R0sJG1vc-x2~u4142~F-2~RVl7TWhyO3lsMBIflP0~p3qdSh6zPDiyajWD58gc5oEnYSyj0CDliV2WvM7-vxrdRUrEnCbwjCtVZ45w1YNTetQj9KG~IbXHhDc-SQNOVjnRgl8tfTHCpRmsGPRPGsCqCZLRwguCCn8~tE4VMX1ZkTOvNrbVQTWBGEv0nkzXpzkjnT0rPSw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Left: RMS for each multiple image system in RX\u2009J2129 (top), MS\u20090451 (middle), and MACS\u2009J2129 (bottom). The red dashed line shows the rms of the best-fitting mass model. Right: Optimized potentials displayed on a composite colour image using HST images in the F475W, F814W, F160W pass-bands for RX\u2009J2129 (top) and MACS\u2009J2129 (bottom), and in the F814W, F110W, F160W pass-bands for MS\u20090451 (middle).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab2270fig7.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/304594417/stab2270fig7.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab2270fig7.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"304594417\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/508/1/10.1093_mnras_stab2270/1/stab2270fig7.jpeg?Expires=1639262452&Signature=x2qfdqs62tA~gPwLAqBxSdWufyrpVbASiBXfyT72X8STbUHeGAAZ3J3tKUv-RXr3xgIB1~H5oe9AMt8xUEJ-QNdJv1UM~OHJrZAQYHxrqOQtpR~3AOZmLPoVUTp8uwJYlNCW7BZ3Xll5ZkupTLG3vEe-UApXoRBL4-HRN6u1qqroAB9MfUQeXzP1eIyLkxHUrRHBGv9QOQ8IN~PGZyACcSjo2HQbwwLSOfLCeNaM1z3~ZZCAXSt-VOLP8okoNuWPAZTXQ6BdQ5Ls~v~OJWB3Zg5KKglbDBzltu5yOIBKL522LSXVVU5IujAB~8B~w-d62GDa5vH3N4Ag19FUvJn-7w__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=304594417&ar=6350584&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab2270fig7.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Left:</em> RMS for each multiple image system in RX\u2009J2129 (top), MS\u20090451 (middle), and MACS\u2009J2129 (bottom). The red dashed line shows the rms of the best-fitting mass model. <em>Right:</em> Optimized potentials displayed on a composite colour image using <em>HST</em> images in the F475W, F814W, F160W pass-bands for RX\u2009J2129 (top) and MACS\u2009J2129 (bottom), and in the F814W, F110W, F160W pass-bands for MS\u20090451 (middle).</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig7\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 7.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/508/1/10.1093_mnras_stab2270/1/m_stab2270fig7.jpeg?Expires=1639262452&amp;Signature=SaLndIW-EHh9x73a77~ZIt3TMxs3O4Tl8xHbA8n5tPTE874hnvhMrTHaLKnE7PSe1zQ~zhRweSfzUSfRFul6P2ABLJ7koURiNFz~3CucL-7vYbiwGaw2TjVK6j-Nw6PB-BTScSE6DK6k1R0sJG1vc-x2~u4142~F-2~RVl7TWhyO3lsMBIflP0~p3qdSh6zPDiyajWD58gc5oEnYSyj0CDliV2WvM7-vxrdRUrEnCbwjCtVZ45w1YNTetQj9KG~IbXHhDc-SQNOVjnRgl8tfTHCpRmsGPRPGsCqCZLRwguCCn8~tE4VMX1ZkTOvNrbVQTWBGEv0nkzXpzkjnT0rPSw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Left: RMS for each multiple image system in RX\u2009J2129 (top), MS\u20090451 (middle), and MACS\u2009J2129 (bottom). The red dashed line shows the rms of the best-fitting mass model. Right: Optimized potentials displayed on a composite colour image using HST images in the F475W, F814W, F160W pass-bands for RX\u2009J2129 (top) and MACS\u2009J2129 (bottom), and in the F814W, F110W, F160W pass-bands for MS\u20090451 (middle).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab2270fig7.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/304594417/stab2270fig7.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab2270fig7.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"304594417\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/508/1/10.1093_mnras_stab2270/1/stab2270fig7.jpeg?Expires=1639262452&Signature=x2qfdqs62tA~gPwLAqBxSdWufyrpVbASiBXfyT72X8STbUHeGAAZ3J3tKUv-RXr3xgIB1~H5oe9AMt8xUEJ-QNdJv1UM~OHJrZAQYHxrqOQtpR~3AOZmLPoVUTp8uwJYlNCW7BZ3Xll5ZkupTLG3vEe-UApXoRBL4-HRN6u1qqroAB9MfUQeXzP1eIyLkxHUrRHBGv9QOQ8IN~PGZyACcSjo2HQbwwLSOfLCeNaM1z3~ZZCAXSt-VOLP8okoNuWPAZTXQ6BdQ5Ls~v~OJWB3Zg5KKglbDBzltu5yOIBKL522LSXVVU5IujAB~8B~w-d62GDa5vH3N4Ag19FUvJn-7w__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=304594417&ar=6350584&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab2270fig7.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Left:</em> RMS for each multiple image system in RX\u2009J2129 (top), MS\u20090451 (middle), and MACS\u2009J2129 (bottom). The red dashed line shows the rms of the best-fitting mass model. <em>Right:</em> Optimized potentials displayed on a composite colour image using <em>HST</em> images in the F475W, F814W, F160W pass-bands for RX\u2009J2129 (top) and MACS\u2009J2129 (bottom), and in the F814W, F110W, F160W pass-bands for MS\u20090451 (middle).</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"304594418\" scrollto-destination=\"304594418\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig8\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 8.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/508/1/10.1093_mnras_stab2270/1/m_stab2270fig8.jpeg?Expires=1639262452&amp;Signature=pJ6wyGbHihQflqlAX2J46eRDuu0HGYlzBC2FW55Vrdlmoom8~7hlDrbsk7ML83C9FY3C7xmLnQsB-ORSKkq6MFTCkv65qXe5kiA-0~pHxcPQtrIjTmlHnFH~INPkAUcdKn79hTmLC7qXJxR4pepvIePmgzSY76VKH1Xd5eV1uwy5x6yWRo7zEifB~8EoD--KDysSnPoyA9WkcHG01W5FvU3eC20UW0VxvePLjC3S69yvgXvQh9ig81RrrVfnTU2M72x57J~0~kVJNp4bzsrmHsnraOg2XsRk7dkcB7TqWgIzRIeJ-fVhVlWQUMG1BS4NIPBHRzTK9pQbx2Eht5er6g__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Radial surface density profiles for RX\u2009J2129 (left), MS\u20090451 (middle), and MACS\u2009J2129 (right) derived from the strong-lensing mass models described in this work. Measurements from the fiducial model are shown in grey, and measurements with our new mass models are shown in green. Fiducial models were built based on the analyses of Caminha et\u00a0al. (2019) and Monna et\u00a0al. (2017) for RX\u2009J2129 and MACS\u2009J2129. In each plot, the dashed line stands for the mean surface density, and the shaded areas indicate the 1\u03c3 error bars. The two magenta dashed lines highlight the positions, from the cluster centre, of the closest and most distant multiple image used as constraints for each model.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab2270fig8.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/304594418/stab2270fig8.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab2270fig8.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"304594418\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/508/1/10.1093_mnras_stab2270/1/stab2270fig8.jpeg?Expires=1639262452&Signature=LYMX~gIko6V5WC4wjEcpHVL2ATNPUaqaxwjbLqows9~khHSnj2J5Ug-qAK3qpdnsRu7Zb01tyUa90XgRH1OCj4rTpQ2SGk17TmnAzOlHnfibUlIxldK~AtcGd3B0TrYOXyIeWhuFgKi3oNLecemXW59xPQYapE04CTSt1j265zPjp-J817kXYM3SiC-zZEa-UNZYDVQ16UGWKSwrtK9L0nnXEabEZLNq8k-m9IUQQmeFqCjpRbjutuTv~3kvKlLXk1eXILD1hBL1cjre89vm5J5zLXG~Hf4V9DlpQWuuD1XyVRHHHfJCJU9GRJT8RhU9Y1IyAg6X7jsAGunzPMPQGA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=304594418&ar=6350584&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab2270fig8.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Radial surface density profiles for RX\u2009J2129 (left), MS\u20090451 (middle), and MACS\u2009J2129 (right) derived from the strong-lensing mass models described in this work. Measurements from the <em>fiducial model</em> are shown in grey, and measurements with our new mass models are shown in green. Fiducial models were built based on the analyses of Caminha et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>) and Monna et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) for RX\u2009J2129 and MACS\u2009J2129. In each plot, the dashed line stands for the mean surface density, and the shaded areas indicate the 1\u03c3 error bars. The two magenta dashed lines highlight the positions, from the cluster centre, of the closest and most distant multiple image used as constraints for each model.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig8\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 8.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/508/1/10.1093_mnras_stab2270/1/m_stab2270fig8.jpeg?Expires=1639262452&amp;Signature=pJ6wyGbHihQflqlAX2J46eRDuu0HGYlzBC2FW55Vrdlmoom8~7hlDrbsk7ML83C9FY3C7xmLnQsB-ORSKkq6MFTCkv65qXe5kiA-0~pHxcPQtrIjTmlHnFH~INPkAUcdKn79hTmLC7qXJxR4pepvIePmgzSY76VKH1Xd5eV1uwy5x6yWRo7zEifB~8EoD--KDysSnPoyA9WkcHG01W5FvU3eC20UW0VxvePLjC3S69yvgXvQh9ig81RrrVfnTU2M72x57J~0~kVJNp4bzsrmHsnraOg2XsRk7dkcB7TqWgIzRIeJ-fVhVlWQUMG1BS4NIPBHRzTK9pQbx2Eht5er6g__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Radial surface density profiles for RX\u2009J2129 (left), MS\u20090451 (middle), and MACS\u2009J2129 (right) derived from the strong-lensing mass models described in this work. Measurements from the fiducial model are shown in grey, and measurements with our new mass models are shown in green. Fiducial models were built based on the analyses of Caminha et\u00a0al. (2019) and Monna et\u00a0al. (2017) for RX\u2009J2129 and MACS\u2009J2129. In each plot, the dashed line stands for the mean surface density, and the shaded areas indicate the 1\u03c3 error bars. The two magenta dashed lines highlight the positions, from the cluster centre, of the closest and most distant multiple image used as constraints for each model.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab2270fig8.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/304594418/stab2270fig8.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab2270fig8.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"304594418\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/508/1/10.1093_mnras_stab2270/1/stab2270fig8.jpeg?Expires=1639262452&Signature=LYMX~gIko6V5WC4wjEcpHVL2ATNPUaqaxwjbLqows9~khHSnj2J5Ug-qAK3qpdnsRu7Zb01tyUa90XgRH1OCj4rTpQ2SGk17TmnAzOlHnfibUlIxldK~AtcGd3B0TrYOXyIeWhuFgKi3oNLecemXW59xPQYapE04CTSt1j265zPjp-J817kXYM3SiC-zZEa-UNZYDVQ16UGWKSwrtK9L0nnXEabEZLNq8k-m9IUQQmeFqCjpRbjutuTv~3kvKlLXk1eXILD1hBL1cjre89vm5J5zLXG~Hf4V9DlpQWuuD1XyVRHHHfJCJU9GRJT8RhU9Y1IyAg6X7jsAGunzPMPQGA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=304594418&ar=6350584&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab2270fig8.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Radial surface density profiles for RX\u2009J2129 (left), MS\u20090451 (middle), and MACS\u2009J2129 (right) derived from the strong-lensing mass models described in this work. Measurements from the <em>fiducial model</em> are shown in grey, and measurements with our new mass models are shown in green. Fiducial models were built based on the analyses of Caminha et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>) and Monna et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) for RX\u2009J2129 and MACS\u2009J2129. In each plot, the dashed line stands for the mean surface density, and the shaded areas indicate the 1\u03c3 error bars. The two magenta dashed lines highlight the positions, from the cluster centre, of the closest and most distant multiple image used as constraints for each model.</p></div></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=304594419 id=\"304594419\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5>5 SUMMARY AND CONCLUSIONS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In this paper, we present new strong-lensing mass models for three galaxy clusters, MS\u20090451, MACS\u2009J2129, and RX\u2009J2129, which include new VLT/MUSE observations. We combine the MUSE datacubes with high-resolution imaging from <em>HST</em> available for each cluster to maximize the number of extracted spectra. We measure the redshift of each source with a dedicated software, <span class=\"small-caps\">ifs-redex</span> (Rexroth et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib82\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib82\" data-open=\"bib82\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), allowing for a wavelet-based filtration of the spectra. Our conclusions are as follows:</p><ul class=\"roman-lower\"><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">We measure 158, 171, and 189 secured or likely spectroscopic redshifts in the RX\u2009J2129, MS\u20090451, and MACS\u2009J2129 MUSE datacubes, respectively. For MS\u20090451, we identify two new systems of multiple images located in the north of the cluster core, the least constrained region, confirm the redshift of System A measured by Borys et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>), and measure the redshift of the three multiple images of System G. For RX\u2009J2129 and MACS\u2009J2129, we obtain measurements in excellent agreement with Caminha et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>). We report a new multiple image system detection, System 10 at <em>z</em> = 4.41, in MACS\u2009J2129. Finally, the MUSE datacubes allowed us to spectroscopically confirm 43, 112, and 89 cluster members in RX\u2009J2129, MS\u20090451, and MACS\u2009J2129, respectively. Among those, in RX\u2009J2129 and MACS\u2009J2129, 15 and 4 cluster members, respectively, are new identifications, i.e. not reported by Caminha et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>).</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">We carried out a fruitful blind search while combining <em>HST</em> imaging with MUSE datacubes using <span class=\"small-caps\">muselet</span>. It played a decisive role in the identification of multiple image systems, since it highlighted strong emission lines invisible in the <em>HST</em> images due to either the faintness of the sources at wavelengths not corresponding to maximum emissions, or their proximity to luminous emitters in the foreground. This was particularly interesting for MS\u20090451 where the blind search revealed Systems R and S, both located in the north of the cluster, which before this analysis was lacking strong-lensing constraints.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">Our models are optimized using the parametric version of the <span class=\"small-caps\">Lenstool</span> algorithm (Jullo et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>). The multiple image systems in the three clusters were reproduced with an rms of 0.28, 0.6, and 0.74\u00a0arcsec in RX\u2009J2129, MS\u20090451, and MACS\u2009J2129, respectively. We measure integrated aperture masses in good agreement or within the error bars of the ones published in previous analyses (Berciano Alba et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib11\" data-open=\"bib11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Richard et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib83\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib83\" data-open=\"bib83\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Zitrin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib104\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib104\" data-open=\"bib104\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011b</a>; Zitrin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib105\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib105\" data-open=\"bib105\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Monna et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Desprez et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Caminha et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>).</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">The addition of a second cluster-scale halo in MS\u20090451 and MACS\u2009J2129 mass models are necessary to minimize the rms of the two models, and to recover the multiple image systems geometry in the north and north-east of the two clusters, respectively. Caminha et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>) presented a similar mass model for MACS\u2009J2129, with their second cluster-scale halo located in the same region as us, slightly closer to the BCG than in our case, \u223c250\u2009kpc away from the BCG compared to \u223c320\u2009kpc in our case. Similarly, the addition of some cluster galaxies located in the vicinity of multiple images played a decisive role in the reconstruction of the mass distribution, e.g. the rms of MACS\u2009J2129 improved from 0.95 to 0.74\u00a0arcsec just by the addition of G4.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">We compare our magnification measurements of the submillimetric galaxy group multiply lensed by MS\u20090451, at <em>z</em> = 2.91, with the results published by MacKenzie et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). The two analyses show excellent agreement, with some differences for the most highly magnified images. This was to be expected as magnification measurements close to the critical line, mathematically a region where magnification is supposed to be infinite, have high uncertainties.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">Our mass model of MACS\u2009J2129 allowed us to measure the magnification of the singly imaged <em>z</em> = 2.1472 galaxy identified by Toft et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib95\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib95\" data-open=\"bib95\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), \u03bc = 3.7\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.2. This values is within the error bars of the initial measurement from Toft et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib95\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib95\" data-open=\"bib95\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), \u03bc<sub>Toft + 17</sub> = 4.2\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.6, which was derived using a mass model only constrained by two systems of multiple images, namely Systems 1 and 3 from our analysis.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">Further investigations have to be carried out to identify the missing counter-images presented in Table\u2009 <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl9\" data-open=\"tbl9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a>, and confirm System P in MS\u20090451. Moreover, we identify a group of galaxies at <em>z</em> = 0.06 in MS\u20090451 that impacts the multiple image geometry, strengthening the need to properly implement multiplane optimization in <span class=\"small-caps\">Lenstool</span>.</p></li></ul><p class=\"chapter-para\">More generally, our analysis highlights again the power of MUSE to secure and identify strong-lensing features in cluster cores. Such observations are mandatory to recover precisely and accurately the mass distribution in cluster cores. Without such lensing mass models, cluster lenses cannot be used efficiently as gravitational telescopes, as the mass distribution needs to be known in order to recover the intrinsic physical properties of the lensed galaxies (Vanzella et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib98\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib98\" data-open=\"bib98\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Patr\u00edcio et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib78\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib78\" data-open=\"bib78\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Toft et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib95\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib95\" data-open=\"bib95\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Johnson et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Claeyssens et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>). Moreover, the physics in place in clusters themselves is highly dependent on how well we can recover their mass distribution. Indeed, while a multiwavelength analysis is needed to observe all their components (stars and gas), only gravitational lensing gives us an estimate of their total mass, and thus indirectly of their dark matter content and distribution. With such knowledge, we can hope to use galaxy clusters as probes of the nature of dark matter (Jauzac et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016b</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Robertson et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib87\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib87\" data-open=\"bib87\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>).</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=304594423 id=\"304594423\" class=\"backsection-title js-splitscreen-backsection-title\" data-legacy-id=sec7>SUPPORTING INFORMATION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\"><strong>Table A1</strong>. List of redshifts measured with a quality flag larger than 2 in RX\u2009J2129.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><strong>Table A2</strong>. List of spectroscopically confirmed redshifts in MS\u20090451.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><strong>Table A3</strong>. List of measured redshifts in MACS\u2009J2129.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Please note: Oxford University Press is not responsible for the content or functionality of any supporting materials supplied by the authors. Any queries (other than missing material) should be directed to the corresponding author for the article.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=304594428 id=\"304594428\" class=\"backacknowledgements-title js-splitscreen-backacknowledgements-title\" data-legacy-id=ack1>ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">MJ is supported by the United Kingdom Research and Innovation.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=304594430 id=\"304594430\" class=\"backsection-title js-splitscreen-backsection-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6>DATA AVAILABILITY</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The data underlying this article will be shared on reasonable request to the corresponding author.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=304594432 id=\"304594432\" data-id=\"bib9\"><div class=\"mixed-citation citation\"><p class=\"mixed-citation-compatibility\"><span class=\"person-group\"><span class=\"name string-name\"><div class=\"surname\">Belli</div>  <div    <h3 scrollto-destination=304594442 id=\"304594442\" class=\"appendix-title js-splitscreen-appendix-title\" data-legacy-id=sec8>APPENDIX A: LIST OF SECURE AND LIKELY REDSHIFTS EXTRACTED FROM THE MUSE DATACUBES</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We here give the redshifts extracted with a quality flag greater than 2 (i.e. secure or likely) from the MUSE datacubes in Tables <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl11\" data-open=\"tbl11\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A1</a>\u2013<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl13\" data-open=\"tbl13\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A3</a> for RX\u2009J2129, MS\u20090451, and MACS\u2009J2129, respectively.</p>                        <a id=\"304594444\" scrollto-destination=\"304594444\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl11\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl11\" data-id=\"tbl11\"><span class=\"label\">Table A1.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">List of redshifts measured with a quality flag larger than 2 in RX\u2009J2129. Column (1) is the ID of the source (\u2018sing\u2019 and \u2018cont\u2019 stand for singular and continuum emission line in the <span class=\"small-caps\">muselet</span> catalogue). If it exists, the index stands for the pointing\u2019s number. Columns (2) and (3) are the RA and the Dec. in degrees (J2000). Column (4) is the redshift of the source, and column (5) is the systematic error on the redshift. Column (6) is the QF of the determination. Full table is available as online material.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>ID<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=304594447 id=\"304594447\" class=\"appendix-title js-splitscreen-appendix-title\" data-legacy-id=sec9>APPENDIX B: MULTIPLE IMAGE SYSTEMS WITH MUSE SPECTROSCOPY</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We here provide the MUSE spectra of the newly identified multiple image systems in MS\u20090451, System R and S, and display each system on a composite colour <em>HST</em> stamp in Fig.\u2009<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-figB1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"figB1\" data-open=\"figB1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">B1</a>. We provide similar information for System G in Fig.\u2009<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-figB2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"figB2\" data-open=\"figB2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">B2</a>. We refer the reader to Caminha et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>) for RX\u2009J2129 and MACS\u2009J2129.</p>                        <a id=\"304594449\" scrollto-destination=\"304594449\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"figB1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure B1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/508/1/10.1093_mnras_stab2270/1/m_stab2270figb1.jpeg?Expires=1639262452&amp;Signature=YsODyUO9FRqf9lkVqV3kwErirQVHSPvHtH~ffeZxYlyMItiOxtH1LpxarriuHuavQtfqBuWCwTwYh-KerCLHt2FguAm7qVOMbZ4yY8ieqOZvtDP5Lt3w83Bqvad8G0wOQDA-jgjz2AlDSNj7qEH8yUpH50dD8FlGzVxWihtn~AJQBuSjQ8p-AytdubDUJG76lmmefZ8SyUqmOgURrm8X1TEKe~kj8QRdk7R0LtmroMiLCQrR9jRhaNpWW84oBYF8YmXrrm4Z82lpYn-KPWKvZihFmGZ7ZdnNcnFFIlQMwr5ePC70O-6nRkjvYNg95eFJY~wncqAWoNyRnRL7SMTSCg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"MS\u20090451 \u2013 Newly identified multiple image systems with MUSE. Top: Systems R (left, z = 3.7645) and S (right, z = 4.4514) on a composite colour HST image. Middle:muselet narrow-band datacube at the wavelength corresponding to the maximum emission of the source, i.e. \u03bb = 5793\u2009\u00c5 for System R (left) and \u03bb = 6628\u2009\u00c5 for System S (right). Magenta contours are computed at intensities of 2.0, 3.0, and 4.0\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010\u221220\u2009erg\u00a0s\u22121\u00a0cm\u22122 for both systems, except for image R.3, where the contours are computed for an intensity of 1.0\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010\u221220\u2009erg\u00a0s\u22121\u00a0arcsec\u22122. Magenta contours are computed at intensities of 2.0, 3.0, and 4.0\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>\u221220</sup>\u2009erg\u00a0s<sup>\u2212</sup><sup>1</sup>\u00a0cm<sup>\u2212</sup><sup>2</sup> for both systems, except for image R.3, where the contours are computed for an intensity of 1.0\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>\u221220</sup>\u2009erg\u00a0s<sup>\u2212</sup><sup>1</sup>\u00a0arcsec<sup>\u22122</sup>. <em>Bottom</em>: MUSE spectra of the multiple images centred on the most prominent line.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"figB1\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure B1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/508/1/10.1093_mnras_stab2270/1/m_stab2270figb1.jpeg?Expires=1639262452&amp;Signature=YsODyUO9FRqf9lkVqV3kwErirQVHSPvHtH~ffeZxYlyMItiOxtH1LpxarriuHuavQtfqBuWCwTwYh-KerCLHt2FguAm7qVOMbZ4yY8ieqOZvtDP5Lt3w83Bqvad8G0wOQDA-jgjz2AlDSNj7qEH8yUpH50dD8FlGzVxWihtn~AJQBuSjQ8p-AytdubDUJG76lmmefZ8SyUqmOgURrm8X1TEKe~kj8QRdk7R0LtmroMiLCQrR9jRhaNpWW84oBYF8YmXrrm4Z82lpYn-KPWKvZihFmGZ7ZdnNcnFFIlQMwr5ePC70O-6nRkjvYNg95eFJY~wncqAWoNyRnRL7SMTSCg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"MS\u20090451 \u2013 Newly identified multiple image systems with MUSE. Top: Systems R (left, z = 3.7645) and S (right, z = 4.4514) on a composite colour HST image. Middle:muselet narrow-band datacube at the wavelength corresponding to the maximum emission of the source, i.e. \u03bb = 5793\u2009\u00c5 for System R (left) and \u03bb = 6628\u2009\u00c5 for System S (right). Magenta contours are computed at intensities of 2.0, 3.0, and 4.0\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010\u221220\u2009erg\u00a0s\u22121\u00a0cm\u22122 for both systems, except for image R.3, where the contours are computed for an intensity of 1.0\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010\u221220\u2009erg\u00a0s\u22121\u00a0arcsec\u22122. Bottom: MUSE spectra of the multiple images centred on the most prominent line.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab2270figb1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/304594449/stab2270figb1.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab2270figb1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"304594449\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/508/1/10.1093_mnras_stab2270/1/stab2270figb1.jpeg?Expires=1639262452&Signature=1L62jAhiQW4HYHqSe6S~tk3anS65Rv24WSlqkgo7-Er1d4btWLFZiFbLB6H0KHM3ZS8dtEIsckAiU8DT9I8CGEdogc5MUBbxFcqGs9KbpLEfq0pU9rLsPwo85fXKBWzUCPMPXXdIbctoFiDADCoHc5yc-znBpaSChlD0AI2xbl~VuFFfZLn6A2htj4eUgLY871yAbALPFsgKoNqNwWNDElyfjoi9T87xSEnQjMZnerUAkFMyTR1GFE49HnszpDkuSBlKd9UllKjbFXvPyMcK-Pyf-Sxl1Jfb5ngmB-cAwBeRCeU~U-CzHLWdVDcaCQkDAVidBp2e9UBjldHuZywtTA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=304594449&ar=6350584&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab2270figb1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><strong>MS\u20090451 \u2013</strong> Newly identified multiple image systems with MUSE. <em>Top:</em> Systems R (left, <em>z</em> = 3.7645) and S (right, <em>z</em> = 4.4514) on a composite colour <em>HST</em> image. <em>Middle:</em><span class=\"small-caps\">muselet</span> narrow-band datacube at the wavelength corresponding to the maximum emission of the source, i.e. \u03bb = 5793\u2009\u00c5 for System R (left) and \u03bb = 6628\u2009\u00c5 for System S (right). Magenta contours are computed at intensities of 2.0, 3.0, and 4.0\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>\u221220</sup>\u2009erg\u00a0s<sup>\u2212</sup><sup>1</sup>\u00a0cm<sup>\u2212</sup><sup>2</sup> for both systems, except for image R.3, where the contours are computed for an intensity of 1.0\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>\u221220</sup>\u2009erg\u00a0s<sup>\u2212</sup><sup>1</sup>\u00a0arcsec<sup>\u22122</sup>. <em>Bottom</em>: MUSE spectra of the multiple images centred on the most prominent line.</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"304594450\" scrollto-destination=\"304594450\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"figB2\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure B2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/508/1/10.1093_mnras_stab2270/1/m_stab2270figb2.jpeg?Expires=1639262452&amp;Signature=u8uS7ACKnw6rwZ-Lh~~CfUS879g~7R8wAozA~k6kpd0q5gboQwAJJk6tnEjUNp2IFhoHX-vwnncScyVfpd29UWjWBwyrCGzrFXOO3iLA1SPS1ukGFrAHCiz3UY1WA6klQYytLbxn~CwGPn1PuI5B8xh36JpUnukPMUI8l8mjEfEnC6t-S6FsCsZkrtmR0ECLDkz3FlIv5QyTv~ySbxFHAjRK4AYqWjyP5RWB-YlxSZmHCEPwbKzDlC-AW9CVPLQFaGp3JxA01MjvWB4A2J2inkI8cXYJgS4f66VXQEwDMiP1U8Si0gq6aWGrsLHX6~fOg179-YOI46jqeHY-8DfwBg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"MS\u20090451 \u2013 System G (z = 2.93) identified by Takata et\u00a0al. (2003), and spectroscopically confirmed with MUSE. Top: Composite colour HST images. Middle: muselet narrow-band datacube stamp at the wavelength of the maximum emission of the source, i.e. \u03bb = 4780\u2009\u00c5. The contours are displayed in magenta for 2, 3, and 4\u2009\u00d7 10\u221220\u2009erg\u00a0s\u22121\u00a0arcsec\u22122. Bottom: MUSE extracted spectra of the multiple images.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab2270figb2.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/304594450/stab2270figb2.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab2270figb2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"304594450\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/508/1/10.1093_mnras_stab2270/1/stab2270figb2.jpeg?Expires=1639262452&Signature=q9gC-WSWCNw8P8mdpAFmPPtlzWOPY6YUdGUw6WL1FpSlG~a-CehjVTrNtWQXyw26g9dcxx0K2MXpfrH1r1aXMkCU8M1BEygqfJ1HsoyG8rQZfgUDcRmJKPpVBl2NjJZm9vsvA4VspFaEqOYgZ1MY19hhhlJ4u~-YnIQX12izzN7zlwDMo8Z~p4KvReBbaz6vsJCsAgK8hy4x0owFGzXtoiRJMb127caheZc1vrC~NzV9KKA~6D8Yscs0mcHQLvKE1AJy9kOaGo7n7qe5t~E2webjm0JAqzQ3UXT84LbTJAtb4UdmCfqrNkNwyLzQFaXYCBzwxFLBghmvx9p~~KZ-wQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=304594450&ar=6350584&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab2270figb2.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><strong>MS\u20090451 \u2013</strong> System G (<em>z</em> = 2.93) identified by Takata et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib93\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib93\" data-open=\"bib93\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>), and spectroscopically confirmed with MUSE. <em>Top:</em> Composite colour <em>HST</em> images. <em>Middle</em>: <span class=\"small-caps\">muselet</span> narrow-band datacube stamp at the wavelength of the maximum emission of the source, i.e. \u03bb = 4780\u2009\u00c5. The contours are displayed in magenta for 2, 3, and 4\u2009\u00d7 10<sup>\u221220</sup>\u2009erg\u00a0s<sup>\u2212</sup><sup>1</sup>\u00a0arcsec<sup>\u22122</sup>. <em>Bottom</em>: MUSE extracted spectra of the multiple images.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"figB2\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure B2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/508/1/10.1093_mnras_stab2270/1/m_stab2270figb2.jpeg?Expires=1639262452&amp;Signature=u8uS7ACKnw6rwZ-Lh~~CfUS879g~7R8wAozA~k6kpd0q5gboQwAJJk6tnEjUNp2IFhoHX-vwnncScyVfpd29UWjWBwyrCGzrFXOO3iLA1SPS1ukGFrAHCiz3UY1WA6klQYytLbxn~CwGPn1PuI5B8xh36JpUnukPMUI8l8mjEfEnC6t-S6FsCsZkrtmR0ECLDkz3FlIv5QyTv~ySbxFHAjRK4AYqWjyP5RWB-YlxSZmHCEPwbKzDlC-AW9CVPLQFaGp3JxA01MjvWB4A2J2inkI8cXYJgS4f66VXQEwDMiP1U8Si0gq6aWGrsLHX6~fOg179-YOI46jqeHY-8DfwBg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"MS\u20090451 \u2013 System G (z = 2.93) identified by Takata et\u00a0al. Column (1) gives the cluster name. In brackets, we list the rms, the number of degrees of freedom, <em>dof</em>, and the number of multiple images respectively for each best-fitting model. Column (2) is the ID of the optimized potential. The IDs of the large-scale haloes are highlighted in bold. Columns (3) to (9) are respectively the R\u2009A and Decl. of the center for each halo and subhalo in arcseconds relative to the chosen center as given in Sect. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span>3, the ellipticity, the orientation angle, the core radius, the truncation radius, and the velocity dispersion for each optimized potentials. The position angle, \u03b8, is given in degrees and is defined as the direction of the semimajor axis of the iso-potential, counted counterclockwise from the horizontal axis (being the R\u2009A axis). For each free parameter of the models, we indicate the 1\u03c3 error bars computed from the posterior distribution of the MCMC samples. For scaling relations, the reference magnitudes are mag<sub>F814W</sub> = 17.49, mag<sub>F814W</sub> = 18.69, and mag<sub>F814W</sub> = 19.19 for RX\u2009J2129, MS\u20090451, and MACS\u2009J2129, respectively. Values in brackets are fixed in the model.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Cluster<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/[XSLTSectionID][QueryString]\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl8\" data-id=\"tbl8\"><span class=\"label\">Table 8.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Best-fitting parameters of the mass models for all three clusters. Column (1) gives the cluster name. In brackets, we list the rms, the number of degrees of freedom, <em>dof</em>, and the number of multiple images respectively for each best-fitting model. Column (2) is the ID of the optimized potential. The IDs of the large-scale haloes are highlighted in bold. Columns (3) to (9) are respectively the R\u2009A and Decl. of the center for each halo and subhalo in arcseconds relative to the chosen center as given in Sect. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span>3, the ellipticity, the orientation angle, the core radius, the truncation radius, and the velocity dispersion for each optimized potentials. The position angle, \u03b8, is given in degrees and is defined as the direction of the semimajor axis of the iso-potential, counted counterclockwise from the horizontal axis (being the R\u2009A axis). For each free parameter of the models, we indicate the 1\u03c3 error bars computed from the posterior distribution of the MCMC samples. For scaling relations, the reference magnitudes are mag<sub>F814W</sub> = 17.49, mag<sub>F814W</sub> = 18.69, and mag<sub>F814W</sub> = 19.19 for RX\u2009J2129, MS\u20090451, and MACS\u2009J2129, respectively. Values in brackets are fixed in the model.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Cluster<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n Column (1) stands for the identifier of the image with respect to the system it belongs to. Columns (2) and (3) are, respectively, the R\u2009A and Decl. in degrees (J2000) of the images. Column (4) gives the measured magnification of the images at their predicted positions. The images are highlighted as cyan circles in Fig.\u2009 <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span>3.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Image ID<span Columns\u00a01\u20133 indicate, respectively, the name of the cluster, its average redshift, and the ID of the ESO programme (PI: Kneib for all observations). For each pointing, we give the observation date in column\u00a04, the total exposure time in column\u00a05, the right ascension (R\u2009A), and declination (Decl.) of the centre of the field of view in columns\u00a06 and\u00a07, and the FWHM of the seeing during the observations in column\u00a08.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Cluster<span aria-hidden=\"true\" System 1 was identified by Richard et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib83\"></span>2010), and its spectroscopic redshift first measured by Belli et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span>2013). Systems 2 was studied in detail in Desprez et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span>2018). Systems 3 and 5 were reported in Zitrin et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib105\"></span>2015). Systems 6, 7, and 8 are new identification from the MUSE observations. Column 1 is the ID of the image, columns 2 and 3 give the RA and Decl. in degrees (J2000) of each image, column 4 the spectroscopic redshift measured if available, and column 5 the redshift predicted by the best model when no spectroscopic information is available. Spectroscopic redshifts are highlighted in bold when confirmed/measured with MUSE. The rms for each image is given in column 6 in arcseconds. *We here fix the redshift of System 2 to the photometric redshift measured by Desprez et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span>2018).</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>ID<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n 5.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">List of the multiple images used as constraints in our new <span class=\"small-caps\">Lenstool</span> strong-lensing mass model of RX\u2009J2129. System 1 was identified by Richard et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib83\"></span>2010), and its spectroscopic redshift first measured by Belli et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span>2013). Systems 2 was studied in detail in Desprez et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span>2018). Systems 3 and 5 were reported in Zitrin et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib105\"></span>2015). Systems 6, 7, and 8 are new identification from the MUSE observations. Column 1 is the ID of the image, columns 2 and 3 give the RA and Decl. in degrees (J2000) of each image, column 4 the spectroscopic redshift measured if available, and column 5 the redshift predicted by the best model when no spectroscopic information is available. Spectroscopic redshifts are highlighted in bold when confirmed/measured with MUSE. The rms for each image is given in column 6 in arcseconds. *We here fix the redshift of System 2 to the photometric redshift measured by Desprez et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span>2018).</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>ID<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n 6.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">List of the multiple images used as constraints in our new <span class=\"small-caps\">Lenstool</span> strong-lensing mass model of MS\u20090451. Systems A, B, and C were reported by Borys et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span>2004). Systems E, F, G and I were identified by MacKenzie et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span>2014). Systems D, H, and J to P were detected by our team, and will be presented in an upcoming analysis (Richard et\u00a0al. in preparation). Systems R and S are new detections from this analysis.
